There are serious flaws in the study. The woman at 03:05 is on to something: "I need to know, what's the rash...etc". While it's not necessary, as she says, to know what kind of creme is applied, the statistics don't really mean much as long as you don't know how many participants are in every cohort, which is never stated explicity. If, like in the gun study, there where 1111 participants in total, it's not clear how they split the people in two even cohorts. Let's assume there were 555 in every one. While it makes mathematical sense to say that given the first version of the question, more people got relatively better, because a higher percentage got better than worse in comparison to the second cohort (of course, more people got better in both groups in the first version of the question), it is questionable  in general if a sub-group of either 21 or 75 percent having their condition getting worse would be considered acceptable. 21 people of 555 are still 3.8 percent. But 75 out of 555 are 13.6 percent. Having so many people worse off than before, of course the creme wouldn't be considered safe, but not for the explanation given (relative numbers)! But it would help to know, what skin disease we're actually talking about and how exactly "getting worse" or "getting better" is precisely defined!  That's only to show that even the first medical example is flawed. Now, as to the second invented study. This is comparing apples and oranges. Pro second amendment folks, usually reply in respect to gun control laws in cities that you can't ignore the fact that the respective city isn't isolated from the rest of the country and they're right about this one. Mind you, I'm a person who thinks that the absence of sensible gun-laws in the US is insane! Nevertheless, the way in which the question is presented here, does in no way reflect all the factors that influence crime statistics. It's way more complex.  That being said, checking the comment section, it seems no-one is surprised that our convictions, preconceptions, values etc. influence our perception of statistics and most people would admit that they aren't free from bias. Surprise, surprise! It is worth pointing out again that the statistics are - as is explicity stated - invented. Now, are the people who interpret them according to their preconceptions (which might just be brainwashing or actually real knowledge about the question) really that wrong?  The whole study seems to me to be an example of a useless study that "proves" something we knew all along, failes to provide crucial information - therefore presents unanswerable questions as answerable (it's not possible to say, given the information, if the creme betters the condition) and then misinterprets the data.  Edit: I must admit that I didn't even watch the video completely. But having read some more comments, I realized that I might have misunderstood the first alleged study in one detail. It seems that there weren't even 555 people in every cohort, but 298 in the first and 128 in the second. This makes it even worse! Though it's not unusual in medical studies that the control group is smaller, that increases the percentage of participants who get worse to 34 percent. I assumed that there were more people who neither got worse nor better. In any case, none of those important details are given. My conclusion is that either the study is worthless, or the presentation sucks or both.
I like your channel but this is I think maybe the only video I've watched of yours that was somewhat disappointing.  The title is a little misleading.  And the conclusion seems hasty.   I mean, it's not the case that there are a special class of math problems on which smart people do worse.  Instead all it shows is that some topics have a ton of baggage and will cause people not to view them as mathematical problems, or at least not entirely mathematical.  And to ascribe it all to tribalism seems premature without having ruled out other flaws in the questions, like for instance, a tendency to conflate with data the subjects have seen before, silently considering other factors that could be at play in a real world setting but not presented in the problem, strong emotional reaction to the topic, etc.  From what I saw, the study's questions seemed to share a common flaw in that they were asking about complex systems.   Those really invite people to stray outside the bounds of the problem, in terms of their reasoning.  I would have liked to have seen questions that limit scope a little more and yet are still quite loaded in partisan terms.  So something like vaccine injury is far more comparable to the skin cream question, for instance.  Or common core curriculum and its effects on test scores - still complex but not as complex as gun policy effect on crime or questions about the climate, and more directly connected to the outcomes being tested.  And I would also have liked to have seen questions that are less likely to evoke visceral emotion.  Because gun control does evoke on both sides, not just because "it's partisan" but because of horrific mass shootings on one side and fear of government oppression and such on the other.  A better question might have centered on the efficacy of higher tax and spend policies vs lower tax and spend.  It's a little emotional perhaps but not nearly as emotional as a thing like gun control.  Or maybe  a more specific policy concept like cap and trade, tariffs, rent control, etc.  With a greater variety of questions I wonder if you'd find the partisan effects weaken significantly or even disappear for certain questions while remaining strong for others, and that would lend more confidence in the conclusions, whatever they might be.  EDIT:  also I think the video just kind of glosses over the fact that people on the more intelligent side lean more fiercely partisan, and this is in part because they tend to have ingested and analyzed more evidence and argumentation than others have, before you ever ask them the question.  So psychologically when you present new data, it's competing with a mountain of past thought and analysis, instead of a hill.  And that's not actually a bad thing.  The more one has seen a lot of reporting and data, the more skeptical they become of new data, and part of that is because of the way science literature filters into the mainstream.  I.e., media doesn't tend to highlight the most solid and well-founded conclusions, instead it usually highlights the most speculative and sensational, and often, the most partisan.  People have become conditioned to tune out isolated bits of data to some extent.

The problem I have with this is that the accuracy wasn't dipping because the minds of the ignorant sheeple were hopelessly brainwashed to the point that they refused to sway even in the face of damning evidence. The accuracy was dipping because rewording the problem to be about gun control engaged viewers‚Äô prior knowledge in a way that face cream and skin rashes did not.  Consider this problem:  Is it worth paying $1,000 for a small but non-zero chance of receiving effectively infinite money?  Any rational person would say yes. But present the same person with Pascal's wager, and they are likely to get the "wrong" answer, despite the problem being nearly identical.  Or consider an even simpler problem that makes the issue blatantly obvious:  It took Marie ten minutes to fold two paper cranes. If she works just as fast, how long will it take for her to fold three more paper cranes?  The answer is clearly 15 minutes. Now, "reword" the problem like so:  It took Marie 10 minutes to saw a board into two pieces. If she works just as fast, how long will it take for her to saw another board into three pieces?  Now, the attentive viewer who correctly objects to using the same method to solve this problem (which uses the exact same numbers) and gives the answer "20 minutes" is, Veritasium would argue, the narrow-minded fool who let their opinions on the matter (i.e., common sense) get the better of them.  My point is that the moral of the story is not that people's opinions skew their ability to reason, but that context is important when considering problems. Real-life issues are not tidy word problems. Conflict arises not because people are irrational tribalists and one side is just wrong but won't admit it, but because different sides have different facts because of failures in communication, and even on the same facts, there are different interpretations.

To be fair, the question is ill-posed, at least in this video. We don't know the number of people per group and if making rash worse counteracts making rash better 1:1. One thing that this video leaves out (or at least the first 7 minutes) is the difference between correlation and causation. Correlation doesn't prove causation, it can only disprove a hypothssis that preducts causation, if it is lower than what it should be according to the hypothesis.  Now how to apply this to the examples in this video? - in the case of a skin cream applied to people who have rashes, if these people are chosen randomly, there isn't much chance that there is any unknown variable that affects both the probability of using the cream and the development of the rash, if you prepare the study correctly. So you can actually test the theory with a simple study with just these numbers. - in the case of gun control and crime rates, this isn't a controlled experiment, but it's a study that takes place in a complex society, in which many variables can influence each other, so you can't just test a causation of just 2 variables of the kind of gun control and crime rate by just finding out their correlation, because there are many possibilities that influence both at the same time. Even if you chose "similar" cities, there will still be a lot of things different between them. For example, if geography isn't concerned in the choice of cities, there might be geographical differences that impact both the likelihood of the increase in crime rate and of the implementation of gun control. Or there might be some unconsidered variable that influences both crime rate and which party rules at state and/or city level, which influence gun control. So just comparing crime rates and gun control might be as bad as the sokewhat famous study about climate change and pirates (google it if you don't know it).  In cases if it is unclear if a correlation implies causation, people tend to have confirmation bias, i.E. they respect correlations that confirm their believes, while ignore or argue away the ones that contradict them. This could explain, why in the skin cream case, there is no difference between republicans and democrats, but in the case of gun control there us

False. Skin cream is perceived to be drastically unlikely to have second order effects.  For example, banning guns increases possible crimes as it criminalises new behaviour, as well as drastically affect law enforcement (eg gun registration previously allowed crime to be tracked more easily, police were coperated with more, etc)  The investigation is flawed, and not the recipients in either case, the difference based on perception of second or third order effects and direct experience. The political divide isn't purely tribal at all, that is a false assumption. Questions are political precisely because they involve complex second order effects. The more literate, the more they've seen incongruent data on certain topics.   This merely proved medical ignorance,  as it does not account for the real and efficacious placebo, ignoring repeat test samples for the best data, application of cream will involve ablutions, and a non contact period for most participants, etc.  The cream does not defeat the null hypothesis, nor is it proven to make rashes worse because factors are not sufficiently controlled.  In political questions, usually they cannot be controlled. In your firearms example the study may be conducted in the UK in which people do not know they have a right to bear arms here. Thus all that data would merely be within normal crime fluctuations which are unaccounted for. It also lacks comparable enforcement of carrying firearms. Any public change may affect crime, stronger than placebo.  If you are literate you may consider say Switzerland, with enforced automatic weapon requirements and 2,000 rounds and low crime rate. Then you consider strong social, cultural, economic, even ethnic differences that are likely stronger factors.  Passing a gun control measure is a symptom of a social and political shift and is not actually the first order effect.  For example in New York gun control was a racially targeted action to deweaponise black political militant groups that were gaining political capital. This breeds resentment and oppressive feelings which may manifest in either more or less criminality based on culture and socialisation.

The question is not very well formed as it's not clear how big the groups are. It's intuitively obvious that there are also people for whom the cream will make no difference and thus it's natural to assume the groups were bigger (maybe the same size as that's a usual design). It's just very counterintuitive that cream make a difference (one way or another) for everyone and that's the source of confusion.   Ask a better question and you will get better answers (as is usual in those kind of experiments which are often based on confusing people). In this particular question if you just add that the first group had 398 participants and the second only 128 people make correct conclusions more often.

Numeracy's relationship with political polarization is complex and not universally established. Some research suggests numeracy may increase polarization by enabling individuals to interpret data in a way that confirms their existing beliefs. Conversely, other studies indicate that numeracy does not necessarily lead to polarization or enhanced bias, especially when considering other factors like cognitive ability.  Elaboration: Motivated Numeracy: One theory suggests that individuals with higher numeracy skills might selectively use their skills to interpret data in a way that reinforces their pre-existing political views. This is known as "motivated numeracy".  Enhanced Bias: Some studies have found that individuals with higher numeracy may express more polarization in their subjective risk perceptions, particularly when they hold opposing worldviews, according to a study published by the American Psychological Association (APA).  Cognitive Ability: Research on COVID-19 risk perception has shown that numeracy may not be a direct predictor of polarization when verbal ability is also considered. This suggests that the observed effect of numeracy might be linked to broader cognitive abilities, according to a study published in PLOS ONE.  Knowledge and Power: Some studies argue that numerate individuals, being more knowledgeable, can leverage their skills to understand and interpret data, potentially leading to more informed opinions, according to a study published on ResearchGate.  Interplay with Political Outlook: Research indicates that the impact of numeracy on political judgments can be conditional on an individual's political worldview. For instance, individuals with high numeracy and an egalitarian-communitarian orientation might show more favorable views on immigration compared to those with high numeracy and a hierarchical-individualistic orientation, according to a study published in PLOS ONE.  In summary: The relationship between numeracy and political polarization is complex and multifaceted, with some evidence suggesting that numeracy may exacerbate polarization through motivated reasoning, while other studies indicate that it may not be a primary driver of polarization when considering other factors like cognitive ability and individual worldviews.

That‚Äôs kind of like asking whether or not ice cream sales increase violent crime.  The question being asked is not what is being answered.  In fact, the question cannot be answered without a belief set. Hence the answers are actually rational, while the question itself is a misappropriation of ‚Äúscientific‚Äù reasoning. Academics are equally susceptible to ‚Äúscientific reasoning,‚Äù which means they can misinterpret common sense.   The two scenarios are not actually the same question at all.  Controversial issues are non-binary. Hence trying to frame them as a binary choice will get instantly rejected. People understand there are hundreds if not thousands of uncontrollable factors which feed into a seemingly simple ‚Äúfact.‚Äù The question implies causality and linear relationships, which a considerate person will reject based on their personal beliefs.   Most people intuitively recognize this inconsistency with data and hence will reject the implication of a study rather than the numbers themselves. In other words, they are answering the question ‚Äúshould gun control be enacted‚Äù rather than ‚Äúis gun control correlated to a numerical result.‚Äù  It all depends on how you present something. When it comes to deciding a course of action, people will often rely on their personal beliefs (I.e. principles). This is both rational and arguably the best way to answer questions like this, since the data itself in this category cannot be tied to a single factor as if it were a linear relationship.

Ummm, did anyone else see major logical fallacies in the Yale study?   I work with a high performing team of (mostly) PhDs and I spend a lot of time going through the scientific principle, logical fallacies, and errors in reasoning in instances where Bayesian statistics are involved.   I'll admit something upfront; I have not read the Yale paper -- and I should.  So I accept that I may not have all of the relevant information but there is an implied experimental control that results in a false equivalency fallacy. The skin cream question was straight forward but then they jumped to the question of gun control, under the pretense that the issue of gun control now introduces 'a single controlled variable' that is political bias.  The false equivalency is that in the skin cream example we can reasonably assume that the groups were randomized to control for other variables. The skin cream example is a 'static in time' snapshot of response to cream vs a control, while the gun control example is a 'change over time'  study that implies multi-variate effects (gun-control laws, political bias *AND* time).  Note, the gun study is described as "cities that recently enacted concealed carry gun laws'.   I'm somewhat shocked that @Veritasium,   a channel about science, fails to point out the weakness of the study design (or they flubbed the description of the studies from the paper).  The description of the gun study in the video is poor.  The video states that 'cities enacted gun control laws' while other cities didn't.   That can't be right because why would there be an increase, or decrease, in the cities that didn't change laws?  If that is truly the control group in the Yale study then something else is driving the change in the gun related crime statistics, and by definition this is a multi-variate problem. Taken on face value (as described by the video), in the case (question #1) where gun laws are enacted and effective  in reducing gun related crime (i.e. the fractional increase is lower), the implication is that there is a time dependent variable increasing the incidence of overall gun crimes in both types of cities *AND*  the gun laws are an additional negatively correlated  parameter to the incidence of gun crimes (a good thing). In the second question,  the incidence of gun crimes is lower where (presumably and it's unclear) people are allowed to conceal carry. In this case, there is an additional negative correlation to gun crime incidence, when concealed carry is allowed.  This is either a very poor study design or Veritasium has done a poor job of explaining the study. In both cases Veritasium has failed to point out study fallacies and poor experimental design.  If Veritasium is interested to explore the topics of poor experimental design and 'how smart people can be wrong' or innumeracy, they should do a video about how all of the studies that showed 'one glass of wine a day is healthier' than no alcohol consumption.     Couple of additional notes: -  Let's be clear: I love the Veritasium, we are all lucky to have it but with great respect comes great responsibility. - the gun control study is a measure of 'incidence' in an attempt to infer prevalence.  - I wonder whether the cream study example actually used a placebo cream rather than no cream?  Taken on face value the study does not take into consideration the placebo effect that is always a part of prospective studies.

Many important points. But I do believe it is valid to question statistical results. As a student of Economics, we learn how to analyze data and differentiate between correlation and causation. Within every sample study, there is nearly an infinite amount of variables present in reality, that is impossible to account for when you run regressions and other analytics. The point is that we can look at the results, but we have to apply theory as a sort of ‚Äúsanity check‚Äù in interpreting the results. This ofc brings in human bias, but statistics can largely be misleading if it doesn‚Äôt account for all prominent explanatory variables. I think one factor could be the reluctance to accept singlevariate analysis as a reason to alter one's worldview. For example, you could show with statistical certainty that complete isolation stops the spread of a disease. By literally preventing every single person on earth coming into contact with anyone else on earth, the disease will stop spreading, and so you could conclude that it is a statistically irrefutable method of addressing the problem. But, there is so much more to the issue that, even presented with those statistics, you'd refuse to agree that isolation is a worthwhile method of stopping the spread. This example is obviously inspired by recent events.  I'd be interested to see how these tests did when more of a complete picture was presented and not just have a single statement of "we have problem X, based on these specific statistics we have solution Y, therefore we must to Y to solve X. Do you agree?". It's just too low resolution an approach to inspire a change of mind to such topics, even in principle.

The thing about gun violence stats in city vs rural in the US is people take raw data and reword it to support their side of the arguement while ignoring the other wording. If comparing frequency (number of cases per year) you conclude that rural communities are safer than cities. But when comparing per capita (number of cases per population) you conclude that cities are safer. Pay attention to whether the dat is interpreted as per capita or frequency when presented with these stats

As a math guy myself, while I do see the validity to this idea, I think the bigger problem about doing a study like this is that numbers AREN'T the way we make political decisions. They're just not. And I don't mean this from like a "tribal thinking over evidence" kind of way, I mean if it was JUST a numbers problem, the issues wouldn't be political in the first place, they'd be solved. When talking about gun control, it's not just about rates of violent crime, it's about how the violent crime comes about. When shown that gun control increases crime, a democrat can argue that it's because they're not enforcing the law as much as they should and people are still getting them illegally. When shown that it decreases crime, a Republican can argue that the crimes were more severe because it took longer for anyone to do anything about it, or that a decrease of crime isn't worth the rights it's taking away. Both pretty valid arguments imo, and both go into scopes beyond the numbers themselves.  When you try to get people to solve issues that can't be solved in numbers alone by just showing them numbers, then yeah I feel like you're not gonna get much of a change even if their ability to read numbers goes up. I don't think this study shows what the video purports it to. I think perhaps this is more a study of how people process information, and I think the results are highly dependent on how people thought about the question. If it was just the question, look at this data and tell me which side is more effective, I think anyone with good math reasoning skills can do it. The problem is that most people don't process the question like that. They process what they perceive to be the linked implications. If you can separate the linked implications from the question at hand, all's well. Most can't or don't, and so the next way of thinking takes hold: We all have settled questions in our minds and, more to the point, in our systems of thinking. It seems, regardless of how you came to settle them, when something challenges those settled questions, we are skeptical. Maybe this shows that people with more literacy on the subject have considered (or maybe believe they have considered) the subject more carefully than others and therefore the question is more settled, and it takes more counter information to move off the settled answer. But then I realized that the sample sizes would most likely be the same size, with there just being more people who's rashes stayed the same on the side with no cream. Assuming this, the cream was far more likely to improve the rash, regardless of the fact that it is also more likely to make it worse.  It's honestly just a bad question. The set up is vague and the question itself doesn't have an answer. There is no answer to "Does the cream make the rash better or worse" since this is a problem of probabilities. It made the rash better on some people and worse on others. A better question would be 'Does the cream improve the chances of the rash getting better,' to which there is still no answer because it depends on the sample size.
As a med student, this was exciting to be challenged but this was so easy.

We have no idea of the total population size in each group and so can't draw any conclusions about whether the cream helped. We are missing information about the number of rashes that stayed the same (neither improving or getting worse). The most rational thing would be to assume that the population sizes were the same - thus the cream more than doubled the chances that your rash improves, but also more than tripling the chances that it gets worse.

Mathematically, here's my analysis of the generic problem we have here:       B      B' A 223 75 A' 107 21  p1=223+75=298, p(B|A)=223/(223+75)~0.748 p2=107+21=128, p(B|A')=107/(107+21)~0.836  Expectation of B|A' based on A' population size equal to p1 is: 0.836 * 298 ~ 249 => 249-223=26 less than expected for A|B .  Expectation of B'|A' based on A' population size equal to p1 is: 0.836 * 298 ~ (1-0.836)* 298 ~ 48 => 75-48=27 more than expected for A|B'.  Overall, the criteria A (apply cream/ ban guns) favours B' (worse rash/ less crime).   HOWEVER, MODEL OPTIONS ARE TOO SIMPLISTIC FOR THE GUN CONTROL CASE!!!

One thing I would like to be examined and disseminated more is whether this effect is due to tribal thought, or if it is simply due to distrust.   For example. If I was a dentist and participated in a toothpaste study where I rate the efficacy and personal recommendation of brands, I would likely rate all big consumer brands fairly high. BUT, I know that the reason the study is made is to promote ONE brand with the "9/10 dentists ...", so I deliberately answer the lowest on all other brands beside the one I actually would recomment first in my own practice. When measuring my answer, it shows that I was biased against all other brands. Was this due to tribalism, or because of the understanding of how easily numbers could be manipulated to support the wrong conclusion?   The same can be applied to politically loaded topics. Are the people questioned here pulled towards tribalistic thought, or are they pitting themself against the study since they have the knowledge on how their answers can be used against them, causing their answers to seem irrational when their answers are analyzed outside of this context.  This is important because it could be the case that missinformation and dishonest scientific research practices are the main evil in this situation, and they are fighting against it to promote what they believe is "actually true" using the few tools they have available to them, which is their critical thinking, their voice, and their vote. That is an entirely different problem based on people's rational decision-making process as opposed to unconcious though process with completely different solutions to both.   If I was in that situation, I would also present myself as an open-thinking rational person despite my answers because I am willing to change my mind given credible opposing strong reasoning and evidence, because it is you, your evidence, and how you choose to present me that I do not trust.   But that is just a theory.

8:23  When the question is about skin cream, most people that answer the question don't have any outside knowledge about what the real answer is. I think this can be seen earlier at 3:02, where a person wants to know more information about the rashes and skin cream and is unable to answer just about the fake study. Maybe the differences for the political questions could just be explained by the difference between a person's perceived knowledge, the reality of the statistics, and whether the fake study is more like reality or less like reality. In political contexts, its often good to be a little less credulous when someone cites a random thing to you.

Numbers don't lie, but liar's use numbers.   When there is a study about something people care very little about, people don't look to see if their is a magician trying to do a use misdirection to lead them to a certain conclusion. But when people are presented something that is politically charged, something they know thousands of liars have used numbers with in the past, they start looking at the person, not the charts.  For example, if your gave a chart with the number of people by demographic who have been, or have not been arrested, a statistician could say X demographic is more likely to be arrested, and then Y newsperson could misinterpret that to mean X demographic is more likely to commit a crime. People who are familiar with these numbers need to be careful about what conclusions they draw rom them and how the data is collected. For example, there could be more arrest due to over/under policing instead of likelihood to commit a crime.   When presented with an issue that tons of people have made mistakes with in the past, people tend to think more about why the data is saying something, and put less thought into what the data is indicating. The 2nd amendment activist is going to spend more time thinking about why they data is BS and shouldn't be used, and less thinking about the proper way to read the graph. Johnathan Haidt wrote in his books about how people use reasoning, (often stretching it and bending it) to justify their moral beliefs rather than form beliefs based on what they conclude through reasoning. This video is a nice confirmation of that theory.
There's an interesting wrinkle in all this that I think the video kinda skips over- Namely, that there's a *reason* this is how people work, why 'smarter' people might be more willing to reject data that contradicts their worldview. And it's a simple one: With a greater understanding of math, science, etc, comes a greater understanding of the sheer complexity of the world. And with that, comes the understanding that no single set of numbers can ever adequately describe the parameters of a complex real-world issue.  This is something some of the quotes from interviewed people demonstrate even in the skin cream issue really. The woman saying "I'd need to see the actual rash" might be 'wrong' mathematically, but like... She has a point? Maybe the 'bad' cream is great for bad rashes but can cause or prolong minor ones. Maybe it's great in the majority of people but causes an allergic reaction reversing its effects in about 10% of people, easily tested for ahead of time. And on and on, so many more factors always exist, but most people only think about those factors when it's an important enough topic TO focus more on the topic itself than the math question within the topic.  When you're dealing with problems that effect an entire populace, a single study is really no more than a single data point in the big picture of attempting to construct a mental model of human society. And from that perspective... Of course people don't throw out their worldview due to one data point, no matter how clear-cut that data point might be - It's easy, arguably even correct, to throw it out as an outlier. The problem is, that kinda leaves us without a clear path forward to fixing it, people build up their worldviews one data point at a time, but... The world is endlessly spamming us with data points, and it's HARD to distinguish which ones are strong, solid evidence, from the ones that are slapdash or even actively manipulated.

This is not only the dumbest ever created rationality, but also it couldn't be more wrong. The guy said the number of people participating in the two groups of the experiment is equal for both groups. So, all the people from each group had rush. Now, let's consider that the total number of volunteers per group is at least the sum of the people counted per row. That means, at least 298. If you check how many were left in the same condition from the group of the no-cream volunteers, you will see that about 57% have the condition unchanged, while about 36% got their rush improved and the rest (7%) got worse. On the other hand, for those who decided to use the cream, the unaffected population is 0%, 75% showed condition improvement and 25% showed condition deterioration. If we would have the total number of participants per group, we could draw some conclusions. But, from the given numbers, one can draw the following conclusion: if you don't use the cream, the odds for your condition to get worse is 1 in 14, while if you use the cream, the odds for your condition to get worse is 1 in 4. Yet, if you look at the bright side, you can see that the odds to get better are 3 in 4 if you use the cream and only 1 in 3, if you don't use it. This is the correct interpretation. The part with how many times one is bigger than the other depends on the statistic relevance (which is much lower in the case of no-cream, meaning, 63% relevance vs 100% relevance in case if using the cream). Just being ignorant on statistics theory does not make you smarter, it makes you propagate false conclusions.

There's always nuance. And I think that's what is lost too much in today's world. When you go to university to learn about something, it is completely different from learning about it on your own, because they teach you every angle and theory, all the history, and all the applications. And that's why people educated people are considered experts on something. It's not that they know more than you. It's that they have more context than you. I spent my entire life studying entomology for fun. Then I discover one single university YT Channel that has entomology lectures, and I immediately realize how much I don't know. Just because I own a whole book on army ants doesn't mean I know a single thing about rove beetles. Just because I can name every genus of mantis doesn't mean I know anything about the reproduction of thrips. And the thing is, this applies to everything. When good, solid data is produced on anything by truly educated people, you should believe it. You have to be able to verify that the data is good, but if you can, it should be believed. Even if it conflicts with your worldview. Because that means your worldview is too narrow. I walked out of there realizing that the truth was probably somewhere between what these people were preaching and what my parents believed, because both seemed to have good ideas. And that's the thing. Good data, good ideas, they can come from anywhere. You have to open your mind to all the possibilities, and find the middle ground that makes all the data make sense. Education naturally helps with this because they show you all the possible extremes in something that have ever existed, and then you find the midpoint of all the data yourself. So I guess what I am saying is... always try to broaden your mind. You get closer and closer to the real answer the more that you broadly discover. And it seems to me that the rash is very likely to go away on its own if the control group improved at that high a percentage (107 improved and only 21 got worse). So I‚Äôm already leaning toward the cream not making the rash better.  If we double the control group numbers to (nearly) equalize them with the test group, only 42 people‚Äôs rash would worsen compared to 75 of the test group. So without doing any precise math, I would assume the cream does nothing as those numbers aren‚Äôt different enough to predict that the cream makes the rash worse. And we have to account for small variations in numbers as no two groups will be exactly the same in outcomes. With precise math, 75/298 is 25.16% of the test group getting worse. 21/128 is 21.09% of the control group getting worse. Only a 4 percent difference. I don't fully agree with this, while the study shows that political beliefs influence how people interpret data, it may have mischaracterize the nature of this influence. What appears to be worse performance might actually represent a more nuanced approach to data analysis - one that considers broader contextual factors beyond raw numbers.  This is very similar with the survivor bias phenomenon in military helmet statistics, what seems like poor numerical reasoning might instead reflect an understanding that numbers alone don't tell the complete story. The real reason isn't that political beliefs impair reasoning, but rather that they affect which contextual factors we consider relevant when interpreting data.

1:42 "significantly more likely to improve". There are in fact statistical tests to assess that. One of them is Chi2. Turns out the right statement would be: "likely, but not _significantly_ likely." (Chi2 p-value: 0.063)
I think there's another issue at play here. With a study in skin cream, there's an expectation that it's a controlled study that removes variables. When you talk about societal issues, variables can't be removed and the results are much more likely to be inaccurate or manipulated to show a certain thing.  For example, if you did a study about the effect of a gun control policy that was enacted in 2018 on crime rate, and the study covered the next 3 years, almost every policy will appear to make the problem worse, whether it increases or decreases access to guns, because there was an increase in crime that most people associate with Covid-19 and associated policies during that timeframe.  The fact that people are less likely to give you the "correct" answer when the answer is sociological doesn't necessarily point to tribalism. It may also point to a population that is intelligent enough to recognize poor quality information, and weigh it less heavily than other sources of information or reasoning.
The problem is, as the saying goes, there are lies, damned lies and statistics. And that's where the scepticism arises. Has all the data been used or just the data that backs up their point off view?

Drug efficacy is never tested with one group receiving no treatment, instead they receive a placebo that is packaged the same and is physically indistinguishable.  Or they receive an existing accepted treatment regimen, like an existing drug, since generally a new drug isn't marketable if it isn't an improvement.  But in general efficacy is relative to placebo.

It's not because it's political, it's because you're new study on guns is a correlational study. The rash cream study is not. Correlation studies are garbage and people are starting to understand that now. Here's a better example, make the same chart and show that people who own red cars are more likely to get in an accident. From that, you could draw the conclusion that painting your car red inherently makes you more likely to crash your car, but that's a ridiculous assumption. The more obvious conclusion is that generally, sports cars are painted brighter colors, and people who own sports cars are more likely to drive wildly and crash. But to say the paint has an effect on the outcome is ridiculous. THAT'S the difference between these studies. Smarter people realize that those numbers don't mean anything in a correlational study

Could it be that high-numeracy respondents of each political party are getting the answer wrong for slightly different reasons?   In example 1 respondents are comfortable "playing the game" and using their best critical thinking to arrive at the correct answer in order to "win". It is neither true nor false that the non-existent skin cream improves/worsens the non-existent rash. There are no stakes in this game. Regardless of which data set the respondents received,  results of the skin cream study are not at odds with reality, but entirely separate from it.    But in the REAL world there is REAL data on how gun control laws affect crime rates. One of the two fictional data sets on crime & gun control happens to align (more or less) with reality. At this point, those whose receive the data that is at odds with reality AND their personal politics may prioritize "being right in the real world" over correctly solving the hypothetical. One side is getting it wrong because the correct (hypothetical) answer is at odds with their personal beliefs. The other side is getting it wrong because the correct (hypothetical) answer is at odds with their personal beliefs BUT ALSO at odds with reality. In other words, they had a second mental barrier to overcome. And they would rather state what they know to be true that correctly solve a hypothetical.  Imagine a third nonsensical study in which two groups of patients drink motor oil in hopes of curing baldness. In one data set it works, in the other study it doesn't. Same numbers as the two examples in the video. Well, in one case you're going to have the numerically-unintuitive-but-correct answer that drinking motor oil did in fact cure baldness. Well, in addition to overcoming the numerical obstacle (people bad at ratios vs raw numbers) the respondents in this group also have to content with the obvious reality that drinking motor oil doesn't cure anything. And some may even knowingly give the wrong answer for the hypothetical (but correct for reality) because they don't want to say something that sounds stupid. While the other group only has deal with comparing ratios and doesn't also have to suspend their disbelief for the sake of a hypothetical scenario.

This segment, to be honest, I thought was a little too simplistic compared to other veritasium segments.  It seems to me that "results" and "cause" or "meaning" are the things that get confused.  In the cream example, the question is very simple - and while there are undoubtedly variables in the two groups that may or may not have been the same, crime is a very, very complext issue that may be the results of many, many variables.  So, to use your example, in the second set, if the question was, "Was the crime lower or higher in the gun control cities after the institution of the laws?" then perhaps the "correct" answer would be based upon the numbers shown.  However, the problem is when we attempt to ascribe a cause to the results - i.e., did gun control laws increase or decrease crime?  This cannot be answered in any way by the data shown; one can't even know if it is a "good" study that might even show a possibility.  Unfortunately, I believe that the authors of the study tried to find a "cause" - they tried to draw too much from a very small and highly complex issue.  And, I believe, that is a problem with many of our so-called pundits - they attempt to find causality when it is not even clear that all the important known variables (and undoubtedly unknown ones which might be evened out with a large enough sample size) have been evenly distributed between the two groups (and propensity scoring is a very poor attempt at doing such a thing).
This is why you need both quanitative and qualitative measures.

This first question is too vague IMO. Better and worse in this context is too subjective.   For example, let us assume the population tested was 1000 people. This means the percentage breakdowns are as follows:                cream |    no cream better  | 22.3% |       10.7% worse  |   7.5% |         2.1% same   | 70.2% |       87.2%  If you showed this chart to people with a rash and asked them which option they would choose, I would presume their answer would be overwhelmingly 'cream'. This isn't just because of the higher' better' percentage. It is also because of the lower 'same' percentage. Also, the sheer act of proactivity is considered better by most. Also, do these statistics hold true over multiple applications? If they do, then cream is the better answer because the average applications required for cream to converge (>98% have gotten better) is ~16 less (40.25 vs 56.786 over 1000 trials)  Overall, one can correctly conclude that a 22.3% rate of improving the patient's health IS BETTER than 10.7%, even if the rate of decline is even worse.

I'm sorry but, hypothetically you have 426 people for a skin cream test and your control is less than half your test sample size? Couldn't that skew your data? I'd imagine unaccounted variables would have a more noticeable impact if the sample sizes are so different. Say 20% of people have an unknown allergy to the drug. You shoved 60% of your people in one group. Every person you add to the test group increases the chance of the next having that allergy until you get one that does. Wouldn't you overpopulate the test group with unidentified variables with thus skew?
The problem is they done this near a university? ü§°üåèü§¶‚Äç‚ôÇÔ∏èü§¶‚Äç‚ôÇÔ∏èü§¶‚Äç‚ôÇÔ∏èü§¶‚Äç‚ôÇÔ∏è
p_value = 0.9999580616671025 >> 0.05 Which means that observations from the cream group have a high probability of happening randomly. So, we cannot reject the null hypothesis that the cream did not work. I'd like to present a statistical analysis of the cream problem: Data Considered : The one given in the video Its fair to assume cream works independently on each person so the set of trials follow a Binomial Distribution Null Hypothesis : Applying cream is no better than not applying cream Given the null hypothesis, P(Rash Cures)  = 107/128 = p  Using the python code given below to calculate the p-value:  from math import comb p_val = 0 for i in range(223, 298): 	binomial_coeff = comb(298, i) 	p = 107/128 	t1 = p**i 	t2 = (1-p)**(298-i) 	p_val += binomial_coeff *t1*t2 print(p_val)  p_value = 0.9999580616671025 >> 0.05  Which means that observations from the cream group have a high probability of happening randomly. So, we cannot reject the null hypothesis that the cream did not work.

I think that a more sensible way to look at this is.. accommodating prior principles and utilizing them abstractly when looking at data makes sense even if it contrasts the numerical data that they see... I would say that if someone has strong, logically coherent principals which are based on prior data... new data should not throw off their entire set of conclusions away.. it should only deviate it slightly given that it is a single new piece of data ... (Bayes theorem is a lovely example to look into where we update prior believes whilst staying consistent with the prior believes)...  the simplest example would be that if you believe... say the Earth is round, based on scientific faith, appearance of horizon, observed gravity, and observed shape of the moon.... a single piece of data which says a hypothetical (or even real situation) of '97 out of a 100 people believe that the Earth is flat', would at most make you extremely extremely mildly skeptical of your prior belief that the Earth is round, because even if what appears in front of you claims itself to be a 100% reliable information, it wouldn't make sense to now believe 0% of the 4 factors you've personally experienced...   and since you hold strong to what you know, you would either mildly adjust your prior believes to accommodate this new data... or you would reject the validity of the data in front of you when contrasted with what you know so far  another example is.... you've tossed a 100000 coins, which averaged to 49700 heads and 50300 tails... and then you tossed another coin 50 times out  of which 45 of them were tails... undoubtedly, there is a statistically significant oddity in the coin you've tossed 50 times... but you would either now say... 'it is less reliably unbiased now and has a 'chance' of not being exactly unbiased'... or you would claim that this coin is different to the others

What I find misleading about the rash question is that the two numbers that are given do not total up to the sample size. A rash does not get either better or worse, the same is true for crime.  If not mentioned and not deductible, sample sizes are assumed to be the same, which in turn makes the cream more likely to improve the skin. I argue that this is the exact reason this question was proposed. It is ironically a misleading study about the dangers of misleading studies.  I propose a different question that does not have the same flaw as either the cream or the guns: Does spraying an apple slice with white Monster energy drink prevent browning?                                            browning | no browning Sprayed with monster :           223 | 75 Control                           :           107 | 21  By creating a question where the situation improving is not an option, the sample size becomes derivable from two data points.  What is misleading about the experiment is that they claim people's logical reasoning changes based on pre-assumptions about the subject; however, what really changes is merely somebody's interpretation of the question.¬†Which is far less of a groundbreaking result.

This isn't really a valid comparison though. A skin cream meant to treat rashes is a one variable problem, gun control and the relation to crime is very different as it's not a controlled experiment. It's not the only variable that affects the outcome. Where is the city located? What was the local/national economy like during the study timeframe? What "crimes" are being counted in the study? All of those variables affect the outcome. There are a lot of unknowns and when that happens people are more likely to rely on their prior knowledge of a subject to reach a determination. No one's mind is going to be changed due to a single data point. It's a multi-dimensional issue while the skin cream is one-dimensional issue and you have no prior knowledge of the cream to draw on.

Honestly, as a person who has a deep interest in math, I find that the skin cream question, if you have some sort of knowledge in statistics and how different types of frequency work, is totally easy to figure out using relative frequency.   To proceed explaining why this activity nulls out the hypothesis, or atleast makes it less secure, you have to think of it this way:  - Since its not easy to depict a 2x2 square in words, lets name them using the two-way frequency tables mixes.  - Now, let's take the relative frequencies of each row, those being: + ~0.75 improved w/ cream, ~0.25 worsened w/ cream  + ~0.84 improved w/o cream, ~0.16 worsened w/o cream  Now, we all know basic arithmetic here, right?  So, let's compare the two "improved" values, and whichever is bigger, means it was more accurate in fixing the rashes.  Improved w/ cream = 0.75 Improved w/o cream = 0.84  improved w/o cream "is bigger or smaller?" than improved w/ cream  Seeing the numbers, the improved w/o cream definitely, with not really a superior diference, was over the improved w/ cream.  ‚àµ 0.84 > 0.75 ‚Üí w/o cream had higher effectiveness.

1:52 you could draw 2 conclusions:  among subjects who have a change in their rash (either for the better or for the worse), cream users have a higher chance of getting worse rather than better (25.17% of all change got worse) compared to non cream users (only 16.41% got worse of all change).  However, with an assumption that there are a similar number of test subjects in both groups, the total number of people whose rash got better compared to total group members is better for cream users (assumption of total members  is at least 223+75, with at least 74.83% of cream users got better compared to only 35.91% of non cream users).  So if your rash changes, there is greater chance that it gets worse because you used the cream vs. not using it.  However, there is a greater chance that your rash gets better if you use it vs not using it.

I think it's crucial to communicate math problems clearly, as confusion can arise from poorly presented information. For instance, in the guns legal/illegal sheet shown at 7:51, the arrow system is counterintuitive: "Crime improved" uses an upward arrow, and "Crime worsened" uses a downward arrow. Intuitively, you'd expect a downward arrow to signify crime decreasing (which is better) and an upward arrow to signify crime increasing (which is worse). This mixed messaging makes the wording unclear and risks misunderstanding. It‚Äôs also not comparable to the cream-testing example, where a higher number of creams improving rashes is inherently positive. In the case of crime, the direction of change has opposite implications.

The entire study is flawed. You can't compare statistics with a varied level of participants. Sample size affects the numbers. So you would need to have say precisely 300 people with rashes use cream, and 300 other people with rashes not use cream. But even then, there's other factors. Say the first 300 people were from California and the other 300 people were from Florida. Well it's much more humid in Florida, and it's easier for bacteria to grow with moisture, so perhaps the Floridians would have less success with the rash getting better regardless of a cream or not. A good study will attempt to reduce as many of the variables as possible, so again, starting off with two different group sizes already flaws the study..

While not actually important to the overall experiment bc it's related to bias involved rather than the correct answer itself, I'd like to point out that the original cream question has problems.   In this situation, there was one person to answer right; the lady at 3:02. The numbers really don't mean anything, because you don't have enough. The most important comparison in a situation like this would be the ratio of examined:improved rather than improved:worsened for two reasons. First, even if the worsening rate is 0, you can't consider it effective if the improvements are also low compared to total tested, and the number of tested is never stated. Second, it's assuming mutual exclusivity between the remedy improving and worsening a condition. It is very possible that an effective remedy on a compatible person is harmful on an  incompatible one. Combining these considerations, I would argue that with these numbers, the cream seems pretty effective if the sample was small and equal size between the two, but less effective if the sample size is on the larger end.

Anyone else find it off-putting that in the original study, the full text of the skin cream question was included, but the politically charged question only had snippets? Given how important wording is for survey questions, it's really odd to omit that. The skin cream question made quite clear that the subjects should "indicate whether the experiment shows that using the new cream is likely to make the skin condition better or worse". In the second case, from the snippets we were given, it merely says that subjects were instructed to indicate whether "cities that enacted a ban on carrying concealed handguns were more likely to have a decrease in crime" or "more likely to have an increase in crime than cities without bans", but whether a distinction was as clearly made between the results of the specific study and the general question (that is, the instruction was clear that the participants should be answering solely based on the numbers in the table and not any other information) is not apparent. If the wording was poor, it may be that some people simply aren't engaging with the question the way we would expect them to, which if instructions are unclear isn't entirely unreasonable. The study was meant to identify politically motivated irrational behavior, and being provided data from a supposed study (that in actuality is indeed fictional) without citation or description of methodolody that contradicts prior information that may itself be scientific research (regardless of whether it came to the correct conclusion) and deciding to reject the provided information as insufficiently trustworthy or rigorous isn't exactly irrational, if the question was not sufficiently specific to demand that it be treated hypothetically. This is also a problem that could reasonably be expected to increase with numeracy.  I don't doubt that people frequently leverage greater reasoning skills to explain away discrepancies of encountered facts with existing positions in irrational ways, but even if it's a reasonable and possibly correct conclusion, a study should be judged on its methodology and not just the future confirmation of its conclusion. And in a sociological study relying on surveys, not including the full text provided to participants for both questions strikes me as awfully odd. From what I can tell, other researchers haven't had great success replicating the stufy's findings, and perhaps issues with question wording may have been a factor (although it could be lots of things). It would be interesting to see how people engage with being expected to give a noncontroversially false answer (a study that allegedly shows the earth is flat, for instance), and whether or not they reject the expectation that they give an answer based solely on the provided data regardless of its veracity.  In any event, I thought it was standard procedure to include full text for all questions provided to participants in this sort of study, and when reading the study I was quite surprised only to see it for the question where wording would have less significant influence.

I understand the point of this video, but the problem isn't as simple as "being good at math makes you worse at this", it's more a tangent to the Dunning-Kruger effect in that the people who answer based solely on which number is largest may _understand_ math, but don't have a fundamental concept of how to read graphs or decipher them logically and rationally to ask the right questions from the data given. It's the same reason word problems have always been a bugaboo on standardized exams. People fundamentally struggle more with "Dan has 5 apples and gives away 4, how many are left?" than they do simply seeing "5 - 4 = ?" on paper. It could also have something to do with being asked the straightforward question of "Which is better?" as people are not as likely to respond that there isn't enough data to conclude, because having the graph and question in front of them makes it seem like there IS an answer, but they're just not "smart" enough to find it. So they'd rather guess and possibly be wrong than what they would consider going out on a limb.

This study conflated objective and subjective reasoning.  In objective reasoning the object (in this case the study results) are observed and the individual modifies themselves in relation to the object.   In subjective reasoning however, the individual first inquires into their own status, then evaluates the object and manipulates the object to comport with themselves.   This is simple, but not easy to disentangle.  First you must establish what relationships an individuals self concept is dependent upon and then control for it.   This is determined by a person's metaphysical/physical dominance.  Physical types predicated thier identities on physical object relations, not concepts.  Since numbers are conceptual they do not have high numeracy.   Metaphysical types predicated their identities on concept relationships and since numbers are concepts are unlikely to modify themselves in the face of concepts because it results in a less stable self, or ego deflation as it has been otherwise described.

The data seems kind of obvious. Since the total participants aren't equal in number for the studies you would have to derive the results as a percentage. Add the number of skin cream worked + skin cream worse for total  skin cream participants. Divide skin cream worse by total skin cream participants which will give you a %. Do that for non skin cream. Whichever percentage shows up higher will show which caused more rash. In the first example approximately 25% of participants using skin cream experienced a worse rash and only 16% not using skin cream experienced a worse rash. So for skin cream participants 75% got better but 25% got worse, for non skin cream 84% got better but 16% got worse.

In college I had an excellent statistics instructor. What I mostly learned from that class was you can take most any data, and pull information from it to make it indicate what you want it to show. Always look at numbers with a suspicious eye unless you collected the data yourself.  He gave us a single page document with all kinds of age groups and statistics regarding driving then broke the class into groups and assigned each group an age group. We were supposed to prove that our assigned age group was the safest drivers. From age 16-100, ever single age group could be shown to be the safest. It's all how one disseminates the data. For instance, my assigned group in this (likely fictitious) data experiment I had to prove 80-100 year olds were the safest drivers. They were; on weekdays from 2-4pm.

This video is majorly flawed. You want to believe ‚Äúnew evidence‚Äù can change someone‚Äôs opinion but you fail to understand it‚Äôs the evidence itself that is always changing. Don‚Äôt believe me? Try fact checking.
That proportional solution in the question about cream doesn't account for 3rd possibility - rash didn't change. I think the solution presented in the video assumes that if rash worsened even by minuscule amount that's still worsening and the same for the variant where rash becomes better. In this case we could really divide all test subjects into 2 groups - got worse/got better. However I highly doubt that it's possible to have such incredible precision.  In the problem we don't have some critical information - how many people are in each group, which would be relevant if we have that 3rd possibility where rash didn't got better or worse, i.e. stayed roughly the same. In this case each group would be divided into 3 subgroups by result - got worse, didn't change, got better. And results shown to us show only 2 of these 3 groups, which means we have no information how many people didn't have changes in their condition.  Here's an example how that would change things: Let's assume that both groups have the same number of people(we have no evidence for that, it's just an example): N = 223+75+X = 107+21+Y or we can simplify: Y = X + 223 + 75 - (107+21) = X + 170; Where X is the number of people that didn't have changes while using cream and Y - number of people that didn't have changes while not using cream. And N is the number of all people in a group which is equal to both groups. Now we'll have to split question "Did the skin cream make the rash better, or did it make worse" into two questions: 1) "Did the skin cream make the rash better?" 2) "Did the skin cream make the rash worse?" And now we can use proportions to answer both questions. Question number 1 can be answered by comparing 2 numbers. First number is - how many people got better? Second number is - how many people DIDN'T get better? For the group that used cream those numbers are 223(i.e. got better) and 75+X(i.e. got worse plus didn't change) For the group that didn't use the cream those numbers are 107(got better) and 21+Y(got worse plus didn't change) We know that Y = X+170. Let's substitute Y. so for the group that didn't use cream numbers are: 107(better) and 21+X+170=X+191 So proportionally speaking 223 over 75+X is bigger than 107 over X+191. That's also obvious from the fact that we assumed that both groups have the same number of people and 223 is a bigger fraction from the same number than 107: 223/N > 107/N (because in our case N is always positive) So the answer to the first question "Did the skin cream make the rash better?" is Yes! But it DOESN'T mean that answer to the second question is No. We can check it by looking at numbers for the second question we have: For the group that used cream 75 is how many people got worse, and 223+X is how many people didn't get worse And for the group that didn't use the cream - 21 is how many people got worse and 107+Y is how many people didn't get worse. Similarly 75/N is bigger than 21/N, so the answer for the question "Did the skin cream make the rash worse?" is also Yes! In our example skin cream accelerates both people getting better and getting worse. And in control group that didn't use cream more people kept their state unchanged. So the cream both made the rash better and worse at the same time! If you'd like to answer the initial question "Did the skin cream make the rash better, or did it make worse?" the answer is YesüòÅ "Yes - the skin cream makes the rash better OR worse"üòÑ

I can't believe both Dereck and the researches made such an obvious 'numeracy' mistake WHILE TALKING ABOUT NUMERACY.   THEY DIDN'T SAY WHAT SIZES THE GROUPS WERE! (in the fictitious experiment). Dereck makes no mention of it, and the researchers, when presenting the results of the fake study to the participants of this one, say only "Because participants do not always complete studies, the total number of patients in each of the two groups is not exactly the same", and I'm not even sure that this is meant to clarify the sizes of the groups, because 298 and 128 are more than not 'exactly' the same.   We are of course meant to assume that every participant in either group is counted in the results table, that everyone had their rashes either improve or worsen, because only then does it make sense to use the proportion of rashes worsened to rashes improved to conclude whether the cream helped or harmed.   But this is not the most natural assumption to make. Most studies of this kind are designed with groups of the same size, and so even considering that not everyone completes studies, the number of people in each group who report results is roughly the same.  If we assume this for the skin cream experiment, then we cannot draw from the result the conclusion that the cream makes the rashes worse (in the first case). The proportion of people who got worse with respect to those who got better with the cream is still larger than for those without the cream, but now the proportion of those who got better with the cream with respect to the TOTAL number of people in the group is also much larger than for the control group.   We realize that in order to reason about the results we were making another simplifying assumption: that everyone gets affected by the cream in the same way, or at least in the same direction. Either the cream improves everyone's rashes (even if to different degrees), or it worsens everyone's rashes.  If the results show that a higher proportion of people have their rashes improve with the cream vs without it, but ALSO that a higher proportion have their rashes worsen with the cream vs without it, then this second assumption cannot be true. We can imagine, for example, that different kinds of skin are affected by the cream differently.   In short, if we assume both groups to be roughly the same size, then we cannot conclude in the first version shown that the cream makes the rashes worse.   It would have been so easy for both Dereck and the researchers to clarify what the sizes of the groups were. They could have just said: "at the end of the two weeks, each member of each of the groups was categorized into having had their rashes improve or worsen" They could have just said that! It would have been a little obscured, I would still have wanted them to be more explicit in their speech, but it would have at least been right.   Unfortunately, Dereck said: "at the end, they count up how many rashes improved and how many got worse in each treatment group", leaving it entirely unclear whether there were participants in either group whose rashes didn't change. And the researchers didn't do any better: "In each group, the number of people whose skin condition got better and the number whose condition got worse are recorded in the table below."  How?! It seems almost impossible to me that such a blunder would get past everyone writing up the prompt for the participants of the study, everyone recording the results of the (real) studies, the people writing up the paper  AND the folks who wrote this video about the paper. All while thinking and talking about people's ability and disposition to make sound sense of quantitative information. Incredible.  I'm beginning to become concerned that I might be the one in the wrong here. But I see several comments here about the group sizes, so I'm not the only one for whom making the assumption that everyone in each group is counted in the results wasn't instinctual. Unless the vast majority of everyone encountering Dereck's video or the prompt written up for the experiment in the paper immediately conclude that the size of each group is the sum of those in both categories, I think this a blunder on the researchers' part.

I see a problem with this study. The gun control issue isn't just "political" in the sort of vague sense we use it to mean "polarized" or "belongign to party or ideological affiliation". Gun control (and other social issues) are truly "political" in the same sense that plato talks about it. In the very first page of plato's "Politics" he says that "politics" is not a science. It's not a field of knowledge that is arrived at with certitude ever, and is definietly not one that you would use the scientific method to reach a conclusion with. It is an opinion arrived at with reasoning. That is a form of knowledge, but it's not the same as statistics, math, and science. Plato was asked "what is the best constitution" and he responded with "Which nation". Policy is something that is highly dependent on the conditions of the society that it is in, so when you try and put a state number from a sample up, you are making a fundamental category error. Most people pick up on this intuitively but don't understand their rationale enough to argue the point. So of course people basically take the stat with a grain of salt. Scientist here.   Numbers are numbers. But one part of science is to interpret numbers.   In the example, the calculations based on the numbers are too basic because they only deal with simple proportions. We don't get a sense of the numbers, we don't examine dispersions, variances, dependencies, or anything. The entire experimental setup is unclear.  So if i come up with a hypothesis in science which i believe is true but my data can't verify it, then i will start looking if i had a wrong setup, interferences or maybe the wrong statistical tests to analyze the data.   If my hypothesis will be rejected many other times, i will start believing that the hypothesis is really to be rejected.    So, when people get their beliefs rejected, most will first think there is some unknown information or interference or error in the calculation. This is also rationale as long after a while, they can change their beliefs if the outcome of their calculations stays the same. "Smarter People Do Worse" ME: Ama ACE this
This video is the danger of putting too much stock in behavioral research. Behavioral experiment design is often lazy, and usually flawed even when it isn't lazy due to the sheer difficulty of capturing such a complex emergent phenomenon.  It's important to note that, simply in the interpretation of statistical data, the question is VERY materially different when asking about a controlled medical trial of a skin cream to treat rashes vs when it is about a diff-in-diff test on the effect of a policy on a tertiary statistic with no specific details offered.  When you ask them about the skin cream, they imagine a controlled medical trial, where the experiment design is such that other possible impacts are minimized.  The cream is (ostensibly) intended to directly cause one of the two possible outcomes. The outcome is a simple and single observable event in each observation. The 'improvement' of a rash is something which is easily understood...it is less visible and/or causes less discomfort. There is no room for interpretation here. When you ask them about the gun laws, none of that is true. The person imagines a very different data generating process. There is no controlled experiment, so the cities are different and in different places, have different cultures, demographics, and histories and different events between the passing of the law and the observations, etc. Also, the laws are likely different in important ways, and so less perfectly comparable. Not only that, but the legal status of gun in the various cities probably varied quite a lot BEFORE the laws were passed, anyway. The law is, at best, intended to INdirectly cause one of the two possible outcomes, with multitudinous omitted variables that active political participants (particularly the more numerate ones) are used to thinking about frequently. And finally, the outcome observed is a simple count of whether or not crime "improved" in each city, with no context, specificity, or detail concerning what the hell that actually means. Were there fewer crimes committed? What kinds of crimes are counted in the analysis? Did the other kinds of crimes also decrease? Was it a reduction in crime severity? Maybe it caused fewer crimes to be reported? What about arrest/conviction rates? You get my point.  The problem is not that numerate people are more polarized. It's that numerate people recognize that the "correct" answer to this question is meaningless and intellectually dishonest without additional context. The asker refuses to provide the necessary contextual information, and so the numerate person inserts their preferred context, which will force the interpretation that the grossly over-simplified (but intended) conclusion which opposes their political position is in fact unreliable. You see it in the video interviews here...THIS claim of unreliability is the 'wrong' answer. They don't misread the numbers. They don't get the answer wrong. They turn the unanswerable question into an answerable one by adding context. It's the fault of the researcher for not recognizing the importance of that context. Then they treat it as though they have found some ground-breaking evidence for systematic cognitive bias in intelligent people and go around giving TED talks and feeling like they're important researchers...

People are just weighing the data against what they already believe. Is that so surprising? With the skin cream they just have that one piece of uncomplicated information and no opinions. The difference with the political issues is that they are nebulous in the degree of data they pertain to, each person seeing a different sample of that data and coming to different conclusions. It's not surprising that people are going to be more dubious and discerning regarding some very sparse data about heavily politicised issues.   To take scientific data at face value is not what the scientific method is about. Every submission to peer review is a contribution to an effort to understand. If you're contributing a piece of data to an area of study that is already well established and quite general, then it's going to be met with more scrutiny than something that represents the first contribution or data. So for these people you're asking about skin cream, it's likely to be the first time they've considered anything to do with skin cream so they'll just take the raw data at face value. But with the political issues it's just going to sit on top of what people already think they know about that.

I'm not sure you can exclusively chalk it up to "tribalism". That needs better evidence to isolate it as the sole or primary source of the issue. I'm sure it's part of this, to be clear, but I don't think "need to adhere to social expectation" and "need to be accepted" are the sole factors.   As pointed out in this video, social dynamics _are_ a rational motivator. I don't think this phenomenon solely occurs because of external pressure to adhere to the tribe; I think it occurs because of another element. We are predisposed to confirmation biases on information we already trust and lean on. No one has the time or energy to think critically about every single thing in their lives. Trust is mandatory to survive, whether it's trusting a scientist to present their findings truthfully, or trusting the grocery store to honestly label what you're buying. Trust makes information processing into a background hum. This is correlated with ingroup behaviors and so-called "tribalism", but it isn't the same. You don't _necessarily_ trust your "tribe"; you just rely on them.   Crucially, scientific curiosity does not overwrite reliance on others or on one's "tribe". It does not negate trust, either. What it _does_ do is retrain the mind: instead of only investigating when information causes friction, it trains a person to investigate habitually, to look for things they do not understand and do something about it. Curiosity is energy-intensive. It is the child repeating "why?" _and_ the adult trying to find answers. It is also harder to maintain for populations who are burnt out, afraid, and overwhelmed. Populations that are exhausted and afraid struggle to be curious. Populations without trust struggle to find safety or ease fears.   I don't have a solution either, really, but I think identifying the role trust and personal energy play in curiosity is more useful than simply saying "we're all the same at the end of the day, can't we get along on non-partisan issues? Can't we disguise issues as being less divisive?" They're both useful strategies, but one runs into roadblocks a lot sooner.
