I don't completely agree with this study for multiple reasons. The conclusions are true and is just bog standard confirmation bias but there's a lot more nuance about WHY people disagree with the numbers.  You see, you try to make things black & white - it's true or not true - but that's not how statistics work. Statistics are data and data is open for interpretation unless you have every single data point you need to come to a clear cut result which is extremely rare in reality.  For example one of the people interviewed asked what kind of crimes you meant and that's a great question. If California makes stealing below $950 no longer a crime, it will make crime figures drop. Combine this with stricter gun control and you have a false image of what really happened since you might think "oh, the drop in crime MUST be because of gun control". Politicians knowingly adjust laws to push statistics in a certain direction just for this very reason and the media usually just laps it up.  HOWEVER smarter people will be able to pick apart such statistics and be sceptical of how valid they are and you counted those as "wrong" which, ironically, is wrong. Doubting & questioning data that lacks enough information to come to a clear answer should NOT make them wrong.   Of course, if the numbers confirm their bias, they're less likely to be sceptical and that's where confirmation bias comes in.  Basically you proved an age old thing by using a flawed study that reached many wrong conclusions but stumbled upon the truth anyway. Interesting.

lovely story and one i aspire to, encouraging everyone to get along with each other. But Mr.Veritasium, I appeal to you, as the critical thinker i feel sure you are, to look at these "social scientists" experiments in more detail. These tests for the last 50 years, as far as I'm concerned, are always "loaded". To help their cause. I'm sure you won't see this post, but reporting "data" like this is always flawed. There is always "bias" toward the total number of results in each category for the "case in point". Reversing the "outcome" with the same numbers does not rectify the bias but exasperates it. Social scientists insist the percentages are what counts, but they never reverse the bias to test their hypothesis. Why is there never an analysis of "equal numbers", ie. 100 for each resulting category? It makes no mathematical difference of course, yet there is no test to account for this. Its why double blind is so important in science.

The core of the issue you were poking around in this video is more specifically an issue of trust than tribalism. Too many people have seen an ever increasing number of reports and findings where both present polar opposite results or the results presented don't match that individual's lived experience in some way. Therefore when presented with some new finding about a nearly innumerably faceted topic like gun control, there will be many willing to see the findings, but they will view them with the utmost level of suspicion and not change their minds on the spot.  Again, because they will have seen a number of other sources that say otherwise and they trust more.  To include sources not directly speaking to the topic at hand (the many faceted aspect).  Like a blister caused by bad footwear takes time to heal, so too will it take an incredible amount of time for people to begin simply being open to trusting information that conflicts with things that have become part of the tribal/political/cultural war.  Trying to figure out some brainy new persuasion technique to get them on side will only serve to continue and escalate the conflict.  For gun control specifically, one question that basically nobody asks is, "Why does somebody living in the middle of the swampiest swamp, the most deserted of deserts or the woodiest woods of trees need to be saddled with the access restrictions whose stated goal is historically to limit the number of kids being killed by guns in the inner cities?" Most people would point out, "I haven't done anything wrong.  Why am I being punished for the problems of people I will never have any interaction with , and likely will never meet?" That question is the seed of the tribal thinking. The way to look at these numbers is not comparing the ratio of one outcome to the other but by comparing the ratio of each outcome to the totality, that is, the sum of the two numbers. There is a serious flaw in the way this is being interpreted, even the reported people in the rash testing didn't actually exist. The cream users clearly have a higher chance of seeing improvement, but they also have a much higher chance of seeing their problem worsen. There are known real-world solutions that have similar results. For instance, about 50% of people with ADHD will have significant reduction of ADHD symptoms when they take Ritalin. But there is also a significant portion whose ADHD symptoms will increase in occurrence and/or intensity. And the control group who take nothing will have almost no difference either way (if they take a pill containing no medication at all, there will be placebo effects). That doesn't make Ritalin worse than doing nothing. 50% of people will show improvement.  I know what this study's results are supposed to make us think, but it makes a logic leap that... is illogical and will not always be correct.

If someone points a live camera in my face and says "These numbers are purely hypothetical, but based on them what conclusion would you come to?", I'm gonna be VERY suspicious of their motives and if they're gonna edit this.   This experiment would have to be presented in a much more clinical setting to reduce the major impact that those factors would have on your data. And maybe the original study did EXACTLY that, but the way things are presented here is very flawed and sensationalistic.
Another takeaway is that, based on the non-political math questions, we can see that regardless of partisanship, the more intelligent people were the more likely they were to get the objectively right answer.  Unfortunately, for the politically loaded questions, we can't draw this conclusion, because that would require we agree on what the "right" answer is.  We also see a relative convergence of answers among the "less intelligent" of both sides... maybe there's some common sense wisdom being demonstrated here, and these folks are in fact finding a happier medium based more on broad intuitions?  Less extreme answers in both directions.  But what it DOES prove, is that getting a politically charged answer wrong does NOT closely correlate with intelligence, unlike the pure math questions.  So whether you're right, or left, if someone disagrees with you, it is not a rational conclusion to assume it's because they're less intelligent than you, because as the graphs showed, you might be a numeracy level 1 and choose answer A, while the other person could be a numeracy level 9 and choose answer B, and either one of you could be right.  The numeracy score doesn't show who's more likely to be right in and of itself, but instead the examples together show that when things are understood as political, intelligence alone is not the determining factor; it's clearly much more complicated.  High IQ people can hold many false beliefs, and low IQ people can hold many true ones - and we might be tempted to mock that they didn't "earn" their right positions, but it's better to be accidentally right, than intentionally (through applied intelligence) wrong.  I don't believe it all boils down to this, but based on this little study, it suggests that whether you're right or not depends mostly on your social (/political) group and identification... if your "side" just so happens to be correct, then you are more likely to be correct, regardless of intelligence.  And let's remember that arguments to authority are flawed, and broad consensus is not a hard proof of anything.  For the benefit of science, I think it would be useful, on any given controversial topic, for one group to gather the objective data, and then completely change or remove the labelling and framing of that data, so some other group who does not know what it's about, can analyze the data without having ANY idea what the data is actually about... they only see the raw numbers.  Now THAT would be a great study... let's see what the smart people conclude when analyzing data they have no context for!
The two questions are not equitable, and the result are extremely predictable.  If one has no beliefs, one can easily just choose the correct response according to the numbers.  However, the stronger the bias a person has for a particular result, the more likely it is that they will challenge the SOURCE of the numbers if they cannot refute the actual numbers in order to confirm their own bias.  This is a problem that is almost impossible to overcome.

The studies are NOT comparable:  a topical skin cream either will or won't have a local impact primarily based on its own inherent properties, secondarily on the properties of the skin to which it is applied, and only slightly based on farther-out causes.  A city's crime rates depend on a LOT of other factors besides gun laws alone (what about prosecution rates, or incarceration rates) even within that city, and also lots on factors outside of the city itself (what about immigration over that same period).  You cannot "control" for these factors even modestly well, as it is too hard to even measure reliably many of the factors.  The study is flawed.  (By the way, one of the things that tends to make an issue "political" is, precisely, how non-amenable it is to simple, one-factor solutions.  You should not expect to be able to model political problems like you can skin care problems.)

Correct me if I'm wrong, but the conclusion 'that the cream, on average, made rashes worse' is an incorrect statement. For 75% of people who used the cream, the rash improved. For the other 25% who used the cream, it got worse. Clearly, the cream, on average, in fact in three quarter of cases, improves the rash.  What they should have said in order to be correct is that using the cream is less likely to improve the rash than not using the cream. The better outcome is more likely to come from not using the cream - that is a true statement. But to say that using the cream, on average, makes the rash worse, is totally incorrect. The rash will improve whether you use the cream or not, it's just more likely to improve if you don't use it.   I think the smarter people are not those who made this video. Derek, this is the problem with current academia. They are all R3tard3d. The lack of critical thinking skills is amazing. You falling for this (not bright) interpretation of the data is profoundly concerning. This is what really happened here:  1.- People are either able or willing to calculate the proportions (in which case, the data there would be meaningful) or they don't (data=meaningless). 2.- If it is meaningful, they can use that to derive conclusions. If not, They will use other background information to achieve a conclusion. 3.- This doesn't say anything about "numeracy" or how people think. This is which dataset you used to achieve conclusion. 4.- The study introduces a variable which some might see it and some won't. 5.- Those who didn't will use assumptions, and those who did si the variables will use that to achieve meaningful conclusions.  The way you present a problem and how you skew people to process it will lead to fallacious conclusions.  What happened is 1 group based their conclusions on a different dataset and information available (based on their beliefs) and others used the data.  A way to prove this study wrong, is to present people with the actual percentage and then see how they interpret the results. (remove the step where people might unveil the actual variable value or not). The results will change dramatically. I'm not following something in the first version of the skin cream question.   If the groups were made of an equal size, which the question certainly implies (they're just assigned randomly, there's no reason for the groups to be significantly different in size unless the question explicitly lays that out) then surely the higher total number in the skin cream group in the table means there were a lot of 'no change' results within the groups, and more of them within the control group.   In that case, potentially, the skin cream is more likely BOTH to improve the rash AND to make it worse. Depending on how many 'no change' answers and on how much better/worse, it's certainly possible that the cream was a net positive. That, even if we assume all improvements and worsenings are equal, you're more likely to get improvement after using the cream than by not using it, and more likely to improve with the cream than to get worse with the cream.   In other words, there is no correct answer, and so there's no incorrect answer (at least in terms of the answer itself, rather than the reasoning for the answer). And this would apply in reverse when you switch things around.   So, unless I'm missing something (and I'm very aware that I may be), the whole experiment is deeply flawed.

The gun control question has a major difference from the cream question you didn't acknowledge. For the cream, which participant goes into which group is decided *randomly*, but for gun control, which city passed gun control legislation is nonrandom; it depends on the politics of that city, which is correlated with all sorts of factors that could also affect crime trends. You're comparing a randomized controlled study to an observational study, and they are not the same. So the answer in the gun control case is no longer clear math, it's only suggestive evidence. So it's reasonable for statistically educated participants say you'd have to look at other factors too before drawing a conclusion.

As a side note, I read a REALLY amazing study on gun control done by Harvard several years ago. Basically, when it came to gun control, the study gave conclusions, but also went through several of the statistical errors that BOTH sides make in these discussions: 1) When it comes to murders, those on the left tend to only count murders COMMITTED BY GUNS. There is evidence that if guns are outlawed more murders tend to be committed by knives, but the total number of murders doesn't change. That includes mass murders, even though people not familiar with weapons at first may not understand why. (It's because although a mass murderer may be able to shoot many people quickly, a gun makes a lot of noise and gives people warning, where a mass murderer who is stabbing many victims can do a lot of silent damage before anyone even realizes there is a risk). As the author points out, the number people should really be using is TOTAL murders, not just murders by gun - unless of course a person has an extra phobia of guns and doesn't mind being murdered by a knife. This is also true of total suicides - more people commit suicide by gun, but evidence shows when guns are outlawed there isn't a decrease in suicides, just a decrease in the number of people who use guns to commit suicide. 2) There is no reliable evidence for lives saved using a gun in self-defense. Period. People on the right wanted to use the evidence and did a very non-scientific study several years ago based solely on anecdotal evidence on a non-scientific population (not randomized or large enough to represent the population) and was then expanded for the whole population. The truth is not every time a person brandishes a weapon for self-defense does the person end up filing a police report. The attacker doesn't want to admit they were attacking anyone, and the person brandishing the weapon in self-defense knows the chances of the anonymous attacker being caught is often almost zero, but the odds they will be prosecuted for brandishing the weapon isn't even close to zero. Anyway, a calculation was done, but according to this Harvard study the error on that calculation is almost never quoted. The number is estimated at anywhere between 3,000 and 3,000,000 per year. So yes, it is a real calculation that real scientists can go back and calculate an estimated error rate on the calculation, but the range for the calculation is so ridiculously extreme that anyone who quotes it is likely being disingenuous or is completely uninformed, but thinks they know what they are talking about. 3) Gun rights activists often quote self-defense, but rarely quote how many accidental deaths occur with gun ownership. A significant number of people - often curious children getting ahold of a gun that wasn't stored safely enough - are injured or killed by guns every year. Another category is, of course, drunk people, and another category is people who have never learned the rules of gun safety and seem to think a gun is practically a toy. 4) Gun control advocates compare the US to the UK and Australia. The Harvard study goes into great detail about why these are not even remotely scientific comparisons. Also, they mention that crime went down significantly after guns were banned, but they don't mention that crime was ALREADY going down significantly before guns were banned, and we know the factors that were causing crime to go down, and it isn't guns being banned. Gun rights advocates regularly use Brazil as a false equivalence, and the Harvard study explains why this is also not an even remotely scientific equivalent, because the violence in Brazil can also be attributed to other known factors. The study points out that the actual best equivalent is Russia, and Russia shows that owning guns or not owning guns does not have a significant impact on total deaths.  Anyway, I found this study EXTREMELY interesting and valuable. I tend to trust it a lot because they demolished the most common arguments made by both the left and the right and showed how both the left and the right cherry pick and massage the data to get the results they want and ignore the factors that are inconvenient truths for their side.  I know this is more about people's ability to understand/parse data, but I think the Harvard Study is a great addition to this information. I recognize that basically this video is only proving that cognitive dissonance is a thing, but the great thing about the Harvard study is it goes into the sources of cognitive dissonance on both sides, which I find to be absolutely fascinating.

Your answer to question #1 is BS.  You're forgetting that there's a third group, those who show no difference.  A study would normally have equal-size control and experimental groups.  Say both groups were 1000 people.  Chance of improvement is 10% vs. 20% or so.  Chance of worsening is 7% vs. 2%.  More people are harmed by the cream, yes, but even more people are helped.  Compared to the baseline, an extra 1 in 10 is helped and 1 in 20 is hurt.  I'd totally prefer to be in the experiment group.  Secondly, if the cream is the CAUSE of the improvement and the CAUSE of the worsening, you can try it, and if it gets worse, you can discontinue.

Actually the data is presented in a very misleading manner. What you can do with it, is proportionally increase the sample size of the second option to make sure the total number of outcomes is equal. Currently, we got: 223 + 75 = 298 107 + 21 = 128.  We need to divide 298 by 128 and multiple the outcomes of the second option by that number. Now, the question is asked on a street, so let‚Äôs assume we are not allowed to use the calculator. What do we do? What‚Äôs 298/128?   Well, 128 times 2 is 256. 298 - 256 is 43. How much is a 43 to 256? 10% is 25.6, 20% is 51.2. 43 is somewhere in between so we‚Äôre safe to assume it‚Äôs 15%. We‚Äôll have to redo this part more accurately only if the result does not clearly favor 1 of the options.   So, we multiple both numbers by 2, then by another 1.15.   107 *2 = 214. 214 * 0.15 = 21.4 + (10.5 +0.2) = 32.1. 32.1 + 214 is 246 rounded   21*2 = 42. 42 *1.15 = 6.3. 42 + 6.3 = 48 rounded  This leaves us with:   223 75 (298 total) 248 48 (296)  This way we see that for the second option, with an almost equal sample size, there are more positive outcomes and less negative outcomes. A clear winner.  And yes I did these maths in my head before typing the answer. Took a few minutes. You can easily cut more corners: simply multiplying by 2 is sufficient to demonstrate that the second option is superior. I just was not satisfied with 214 still being lower than 223. It would mean someone accidentally still might favor option one.

This aligns with some of the studies on effect political position has on discerning fake and real news, in that critical thinking had a positive relationship with ones ability to detect a fake news story; infact people would be less bias, showing increased accuracy with news reflecting their political position. What showed the most negative effect on accuracy was simply "lazy" thinking, people not reasoning or engaging critically with the news were far more inaccurate and more likely to believe fake news that reflected their political bias.   Now how and when people decide to "critically think" does raise its own question, where this and those studies diverge is that bias is clearly still present; that the decision to properly engage and consider information can be subject to what one wants to believe is true. It makes sense that when you see something you don't agree with, you would want to make sure it is true and and the best way to do that is to engage in critical reasoning. When it is something you want to be true, you feel comfortable and maybe confident and thus are less willing to spend the time thinking about it, letting that "lazy" thinking take the wheel.

Something I am regularly noticing in political conversations is that people on opposite sides are not talking with one another; they are talking past each other. The way that they frame the issues in their own minds are different, so everything is analyzed from different reference frameworks.  Abortion is a good example (and I will refrain from stating my own position on the topic). On one side, there are people who say that they are "pro-choice." Their understanding of the issue is that this is an issue about the autonomy of a woman's body, and that they should not be forced to carry a pregnancy to term. On the other side, there are people who say that they are "pro-life." They don't view the issue from the framework of the woman's body but on the fetus, which they see as a living human being. This often is underpinned by religious beliefs, but not always.  There are also a lot of people that are between the extremes, but they are pushed to accept this as a dichotomy and adopt one of the labels: "Are you pro-life or pro-choice?" Because they have this difference in framework, they will see the exact same set of circumstances in different ways.  People do not do a good job of even trying to understand the opposition's framework of reference, whether they would agree with it or not. I think that is a critical piece of this. When you make no effort to understand the other person's framework, you might as well be talking different languages.   None of this directly addresses the findings that people with higher numeracy or science literacy might be more likely to misinterpret data that conflicts with their prior understanding of an issue. I do feel that having those conversations between those of high aptitude on whatever metric but opposite camps depends on this ability to see things from the other person's perspective, though, even when you disagree.

This is a well-done video, but it overlooks some critically important issues about when and how statistics should inform our beliefs. In particular, it overlooks an extremely important difference between the fictitious skin cream example and the fictitious gun control example. It might be true that the more numerate people are, the more likely they are to misinterpret results that challenge their beliefs, but bear with me as I go on about how what you found doesn't tell us that.  Briefly, the difference between the skin cream and gun control studies was more than a question of whether the topic of the study was political or not. The difference was whether the study compared similar cohorts vs. dissimilar cohorts. This directly impacts the ability to infer a cause-and-effect relationship, which is what people were asked to assess from the numerical results.  In the skin cream example, participants were assigned to be in the control group or the treatment group, and outcomes were evaluated after two weeks. No specific basis for the assignment is mentioned in the video, and though it's not stated to be random, one might imagine it was, as that's the kind of "all other things about the groups being equal" study typically run to evaluate medications.  In the gun control example as well, the cases (cities) were divided into two groups, but crucially, this assignment was explicitly based on a pre-existing difference. Cities were divided based on whether or not they had "recently enacted legislation to make it illegal to carry a concealed handgun." It is untrue that "all other things about the cities were equal" and unlikely that all other potential causal factors were unbiased between the groups. In fact, they were probably not. Whether this kind of legislation succeeds in a city likely depends on many factors, including perhaps the existing crime rate, the political affiliation of the city's lawmakers, population growth, economic changes, local news, and the pre-existing laws in the city's county and state. Those factors might also affect the future crime rate trajectory independently of new legislation.  Perhaps cities enacted concealed-carry bans because their crime rate was "going up" lately, and perhaps it still went up after the ban more than in cities with low and steady crime rates that didn't enact bans, but maybe it went up less than it would have without a ban. The data given in the contingency table doesn't help us guess.  Without question, in all four fictitious studies, there was a mathematical correlation between the variables. But only in the skin creme study is it reasonable to surmise that this correlation had a causal basis, and in the video, people were asked about causality, not correlation.  A key lesson in statistics education is that correlation doesn't imply causation. But it can be pretty telling when it comes from a prospective randomized study. In the skin cream example where the cream "didn't help," it's fair to conclude (under the unsaid but reasonable assumption that the treatment and control groups had similar characteristics for other potential causal factors, like severity of rash). Rashes were determined to have more likely worsened after two weeks of cream use than after two weeks of no cream being used. If there were no other differences between the two groups, cream use is probably the cause.  Alas, in the cities example where gun control "didn't work," although crime was certainly determined to have more likely risen in the "gun control" group (where a new concealed carry law had been recently enacted) than in the other group, we shouldn't automatically assume any cause-and-effect relationship.  Studies like the fictitious gun-control one can sometimes do better at elucidating causation. This is sometimes called a "natural experiment," where some factor that can't be causal happened to divide the cases into groups. But that's definitely not the case here. The factor dividing the cities into groups was explicitly described and  to the outcome, crime rate.  Like probably a lot of introductory statistics instructors, I focus a lot on how to interpret statistical findings, and one topic is the important difference between randomized prospective studies (the best we have for assessing causality) and retrospective studies (where we have to work harder to do that and in ways the gun control study here didn't pass muster).  I appreciate any attempts to think about how statistics can inform, but this video didn't do justice to some important issues.

So I got this wrong, but I believe the reason for that is because, to me anyway, the question is unintuitive to begin with. I only realised that I'm wrong when I realised that the alternative to "getting better" was getting "worse", which, in my opinion, is opposed to the more intuitive alternative of "not getting better", "staying the same", "maintaining the status quo" or "had no effect/impact".  The question is phrased in a "Zero-sum game" format, which is extremely unintuitive because the majority of these cases (historically, and in real life) are either a "net-positive" or "net negative" outcome. In the "zero-sum game" format, it's only above the 50% improvement mark where the "change" becomes superior to the alternative, meanwhile for the "net positive" or "net negative" formats of the questions, the answer is the same for the entirety of the 0-100% scale.  Edit - Hold up, my use of the term "Zero sum game" is quite liberal and quite frankly very far from the actual definition of the term (ok fine, I fucked up, completely misused the term). The actual Definition is - "for one group/person to win, another group/person must lose".  I was intending to use the term to mean a situation whereby in a sample of people where they decide to make a change and the resulting outcome is only because of the change introduced, and then if the only possible outcomes are either an improvement or a regression, then I 'was' calling that a "Zero sum game"...... Again, I fucked up!

There are old psychology studies proving that when people are presented with new data, they are unlikely to critically evaluate their beliefs based on the new data, but they are much more likely to rationalize their beliefs using these data. Confirmation bias and "party over policy" effect. The only defense we have right now against that is knowing this bias is real and remembering it whenever we see data that seem to disagree with our beliefs. The worst thing people have done so far is claiming that intelligence or education itself in general provides defenses against confirmation bias. Such claims make it even worse, reinforcing the biases, as university-educated people get blinded by this and thus fall victim to the bias much more easily - they are educated, therefore they _know_ they don't need to think about data.

The problem with this video and similar arguments from so-called science communicators is that there is an underlying false assumption that you are not addressing. Numbers in and of themselves are not Truth. Data merely represents the results of a procedure applied to a model of reality. This is true even if the experiment proports to merely collect statistics. That model is necessarily a simplification of actual reality because it contains many built-in assumptions, because it is impossible to account for all variables affecting the data, and because there will always be unexamined outcomes. Science is not a god. Rather, science is the work of flawed people like you and me. The Right sees "science" as a product of institutions run by the Left. The Left sees "science" that contradicts its orthodoxy as "misinformation" from the Right. Today's Left and Right inhabit different worlds and have different world views, so of course the underlying assumptions that affect data are vastly different.

*Right away this is catastrophically flawed.*  The hypothetical study uses self-reporting, rather than observed characteristics. Which means the control group's reporting of change under a placebo (which _should_ have been used, but, for some reason, wasn't) should, in relative terms, be _controlled_ for, which means removed. It also means the binary response isn't sufficient, as you would need a qualitative measure, which this binary dichotomy doesn't produce.  So, if all that were to take place, you'd have the _actual_ rather than _reported_ improvement, and the question is about _actual_ and *not* _reported_ improvement.   We're still not done, though, because we're extrapolating from a sample of the population, rather than the population. Which means, if there is a positive or negative change, you would have to see both if the amount of change was statistically relevant, AND determine if the sample size was large enough for the resultant change to be considered meeting the requisite confidence interval required to assert the claim. This math is extremely complex, and nobody's doing it in their heads during a street interview.  Please address these flaws.

I know this is nitpicky, but the direction of the arrows in the political question is reversed, when crime improves it goes down, so the arrow head should be pointing down. It might not seem relevant, but you are introducing a piece of information that points, no pun intended, to the opposite direction of what the other pieces of information on the same category are pointing out.
Of course political opinions influence perception of statistics, BUT the change from "rash improved or got worse" to "crime got worse or got better/less" is systematically different because the independent variables explode. It's going from a binary rash observation to a scale type of observation. What does it mean to be "worse" crimes exactly? Who decides how to classify these and so on. It's like going from a simple simulation game to the real world with all these real-life factors and scenarios.  I think the study is flawed.

Eh... what?  The question is stupid to begin with, cause "better" is not qualified. Especially if we are talking on a topic that has no distinct results. If its gets "better" or " worse" does not qualify the slightest as measurement if something was infact useful and what not.  To showcase it a simple example: You can climb 1000 steps up a stair, and 900 down. You might end up thinking you end up higher than before. But we are mixing up two things. First, we have something that equals a step and than we answer a question height. But the definition of a step does not include at a a definition of heitght at all. As a result this question cannot be answered. We can assume on avarage all steps use the same height, but this is solely a assumption. If the steps down are 25cm and steps up 20cm, we up lower than before, even if we took more steps up. Our initial statement did not change, but the height was never qualified.  This is done here too. So actually smart people would say, that no qualification is possible in the first place. And even then... the answer is solely... IT DEPENDS.  There is absolute NO decisive answer for that, because we have to understand how this can be leveraged in the first place.  As we have no evaluation of what better and worse means, and also if the cream did help, we have to make the rather stupid assumption, that an improvement and a worsening is of equal value compared to each other and the every improvement or worsening also has an equal value.  For some reason the ratio was using to determine it was better... which is actually not correct. To simplify it, let's use a very easy example to understand the numbers in the first place. We have 2 Strategies, they gain you money and lose you some money.  Strategy A: 223$ gained, 75$ lost (= 148$ gained) Strategy B: 107$ gained, 21$ lost (= 86$ gained) Delta AB: 116$ gained, 52$ lost  The ratio of gained and lost money has worsened from roughly 500% to 300%. So if you consider it of an invest, the factor is 5 to 3 but +86$ to +148$. So, what is the better strategy now?  The answer is simple, it depends.  75*21$ base start, so 21*223$=4,683$ gained with A and 75*107$=8,025$ with B. So B was better.  However, this is only if we can execute it that way. If we can execute B 75/21-times more, then we have this +71% increase in comparison of B to A. If we cannot not that and only do one at a time, then the situation is totally different.  Execution of A +148$ and Execution of B +86$. Regardless how low we do that Strategy A is 148/86-times better, so +72%.  You can see the ratios are about the same. The question is how can you leverage the execution of A and B.  So let's go back to the original example. Rash can improve or worsen. If we consider it equal value, there is a limit of how much we can use the cream and just using "more" does not make it better, as we have no data on it. So likely we can only chose Strategy A or B at a time and not Strategy B x-times more often than A when using or not using the cream.  So for the cream question the answer is actually that it DID help if you consider realistic scenarios. We cannot use "no cream" x-times more often than "using cream". Obviously. Why such a novice mistake has been made in the video and there has been claimed a "right" answer existing on the numbers, I have no idea...  There is absolute no number and no number comparison that holds any value without an upfront definition and evaluation of what the numbers represent in which way in the first place. For those how are still struggling to understand: You win 100$ and invest 50$ you do it. You safe 100 lifes and kill 50 instead... Would you actually do that? See. Numbers itself mean nothing. I paused and counted the number of the experiment group as well as the number of the control group. 298 in experiment and (~75%) got better, and ~84% got better in the control.
Couple notes:  Sample size for the study was decent (1111) but could‚Äôve been higher.  The sample is fine on gender split but skews white heavily. The P value is 0.01 which seems great until we remember Derek‚Äôs video on the replication crisis (Is Most Published Research Wrong?) A replication of this study (Cognition 214, 104768, 2021) conducted with a larger sample size (3154 with the same skew towards white) found much weaker evidence for the effect and cautions science communicators discussing it.   In my opinion: I‚Äôve seen many experiments in the social sciences fail to replicate, especially ones regarding political divides. This makes me skeptical when hearing about similar studies.  Online polling for these studies also has issues, and this replication notes that the original study didn‚Äôt perform any checks for attention in their sample.  I‚Äôd caution Derek against discussing studies within the social sciences, especially when the results of the study are so heavily debated.   I think presenting these studies as-is (without challenging them) is a failure of science communication. Me: ...why are there less people in the control group than the test group? Thats not scientific at all.
Okay, but this table is extremely problematic as someone with a major in statisitcs. A table like this might sometimes be used to represent RAW data but RARELY (if ever!!!!) as a tool for analysis!  An ASSUMPTION that even smart people sometimes make (especially in a format like this where there's time and social pressure to answer) is that data is presented truthfully. And further psychological research shows that humans are not super great at hypotheticals, meaning even if you tell people that you are presenting something fake, they will still react in a similar-ish manner to if it were true. And then you're just talking about bias in general -- which is, you know, bad in excess but also natural. Prior knowledge is at least somewhat valuable and we wouldn't function well if we changed our opinion every single time someone tells us something that sounds halfway convincing. Thus this finding and study about "smarter people do worse" is not, on its own, concerning. It's not, when viewed in a research context, about smart people literally ignoring facts, it's about my point regarding how we reason similarly to real life when confronted with hypotheticals. Essentially, there are some pretty major reasons to be skeptical of psychological studies like this!   Briefly returning to my original point, in fact a table like this would likely be REJECTED when given for submission in an academic paper, for many reasons. First of all, since it's actually a proportion that you want to study, the proportion would be shown right away -- perhaps with a note about unequal sample sizes. Second, there are quite a few statistical techniques, even some basic ones, that can quantify these differences so we are less reliant on the eye test/mental math/one-off decision making, even basic ones such as the sign test. Furthermore, from a statistical point of view, gun violence has been forced to be a variable with two outcomes: "better" or "worse", which is well-documented to result in a loss of "power", sometimes a major loss, which is the chance the test detects a real difference. In short, not only is the 2x2 table shown not representative of real scientific work, it's not sufficient for analysis by itself anyways. You'd be looking at other things in a statistical analysis, and for good reason. The 2x2 table shown is, simply put, bad science.

We all use logic and reason to some degree to form our opinions. The problem is that you need to start with some axioms upon which to build your world view. When the validity of those axioms come into question then you have two choices. You can revise your axioms, which are your fundamental beliefs, or you can ignore the discrepancy and assume that your reasoning was faulty or that you are missing an underlying fact/premise. Most people, including me, go with the 2nd choice.

I don't think this experiment shows what you think it shows. Instead of creme or gun control let's use drinking water. One group drank water and another didn't drink anything for 2 hours, and then we measure a number of thirsty people before and after. This is a type of experiment where you know the answer beforehand because of the cause and effect relationship: we know that drinking water reduces your thirst and there can be no other readings. So it doesn't matter what the results of an experiment show ‚Äì the conclusion that drinking water reduces thirst is unavoidable. But if it does show that drinking water makes you more thirsty than there are all the reasons in the universe to question how the experiment was conducted and who was the participant, and what they drank because the results go beyond our understanding of basic processes. In this case no empirical data can ever be superior to our intuition.   So in your example when you reverse the columns ‚Äì you're not just simply changing the order, you're altering the entire cause and effect relationship so that the intuitive conclusion is misaligned with the empirical data. But it is not clear at all if the "right" conclusion here is to blindly trust the data even though it goes beyond our intuitive understanding.   This is the old argument between idealist and empirical philosophers, you being an empirical will always rely on empirical data, but any positive science has a fatal flaw ‚Äì the postulate that all conclusions must come from data does not itself come from data and so it is not supported by anything, and hence just an axiom.   Empirical knowledge can change every day with new evidence, idealist knowledge is more permanent.

Ok, so tribalism is a plausible explanation for the results shown. However, wouldn't Bayesian reasoning be at least as plausible? I have virtually no prior belief about whether a particular skin cream works; therefore, I am able to base my answer almost entirely on the numbers shown. I do have a prior belief on whether concealed carry guns reduce/increase crime. That belief is based on many other studies and analyses I've read, as well as personal experience and "common sense". Tribalism may factor into that as well, but it's not obviously controlling. Presenting me with contextless numbers on that particular question may influence my thinking at the margins, but is unlikely to convince me to change a belief based on piles of other evidence. To take this line of thought to a logical extreme - imagine that the study presented the exact same numbers for "red objects dropped" vs "blue objects dropped" and "objects fell" vs "objects floated away" and then the interviewer asked "Does this study show that the color of an object affects gravity?". Since we have an extremely strong prior belief that the color of an object does not affect gravity, it is entirely reasonable for us to reject the study entirely as flawed on its face, even if it appears to show such an effect.  Is there a tweak to the experimental design that would help tease out these separate explanations?

We think or sense something we like - and the brain feels pleasure or pain, to varying degrees. Choosing column A or B is also a decision, and we'll make the decision based on how good or bad we feel about it. The more numeral or scientific or maybe engineering the person's mindset - the more the accuracy of the calculations and the soundness of the process factors into the pleasure/pain we feel. Rationality is the servant of intuition. It is the folly of the enlightened to assume rational foundations where passions lie. These were the succinct observations of David Hume in his 1739 publication, A Treatise of Human Nature. It would seem that this nature remains.   ‚ÄúIn every system of morality, which I have hitherto met with, I have always remarked, that the author proceeds for some time in the ordinary way of reasoning, and establishes the being of a God, or makes observations concerning human affairs; when of a sudden I am surprised to find, that instead of the usual copulations of propositions, is, and is not, I meet with no proposition that is not connected with an ought, or an ought not. This change is imperceptible; but is, however, of the last consequence. For as this ought, or ought not, expresses some new relation or affirmation, ‚Äôtis necessary that it should be observed and explained; and at the same time that a reason should be given, for what seems altogether inconceivable, how this new relation can be a deduction from others, which are entirely different from it... ...Reason is, and ought only to be the slave of the passions, and can never pretend to any other office than to serve and obey them.‚Äù  Hume, David. A Treatise of Human Nature. Edited by L.A. Selby-Bigge. 2nd ed., revised by P.H. Nidditch. Oxford: Clarendon Press, 1978. Book III, Part I, Section I, 469; Book II, Part III, Section III, 415.

epistemology, how do you know what you know? it's not possible to question every little bit of knowledge that you have. you'd spend your whole life on that one task and never examine even half of what you need. instead people have to find sources of information that they trust to help sort though the knowledge. from these trusted communal information sources, people develop mental models about the way the world works, which we call a bias. these biases are there to help one quickly sort though information on their own when they do not have access to a trusted source. ideally, this will allow us all to stand upon the shoulders of giants, but in reality it can be hard to tell what is a good source and what is a bad source. figuring this out is another thing you could easily spend your whole life on. so instead we have to rely on trusted sources to introduce us to other trusted sources. the more sources that you trust that believe a piece of information or a source it trust worthy, the more likely you yourself are to also trust it. it's like a kind of primitive peer review.
I think the "conclusion" here is terribly shaky.  The video opines that the reason for getting the "wrong" answer about the data grid increases with numeracy (when the fake study results are attributed to some partisan topic) is because people are "being tribal" or "the answer is threatening to their ideology".  I think that's a leap.  First, I suspect you'd get similar results on any topic, even non-partisan ones, that people have a lot of experience with and already have well-founded conclusions about.  Try giving them "data" that "indicates" that, say, getting less sleep actually makes you more rested, and see how much resistance you get to anyone giving the "right" answer (the one that corresponds to the fake data but not to lived reality).  Second, most people understand that correlation doesn't equal causality, and the fake data grid only demonstrates a correlation.  There will be little resistance to rolling with the correlation when it's a random thing like "unnamed cream X vs rashes", because there's nothing else to go on aside from the numbers, but the moment you put it into a context of anything real that people know is a complex topic, suddenly they'll start to look askance at the alleged one-off study results, start to legitimately discount the strength of those numbers, and begin discussing the myriad of known confounding factors.  And the more numerate someone is, the more they'll be aware of these kinds of complexities, and how reckless it is to decide an entire topic base on four numbers from a simplistic study of unspecified methodology.  Finally, the video implies that if someone is unwilling to accept one piece of "evidence" as some kind of final word on a topic they've spent years developing a position on based on a countless amounts of prior evidence, that this is somehow "irrational" and "tribal", but it seems to me it's the opposite.  It's entirely rational to not flip your entire understanding of something based on the 999th piece of evidence you encounter after considering the prior 998 you've looked over and been basing your position upon.  Seldom does any subject have a "silver bullet" piece of data that justifies throwing away all of what you already know about it.  Epistemology doesn't work like that.   In summary, the more numerate someone is, the more likely they'll understand the pitfalls of correlation studies, and the more they'll legitimately push back on those grounds if the (fake) study results fly in the face of the weight of the (real) evidence they already know on the topic, regardless of whether it's a political topic or entirely non-partisan one.  Conversely, if the (fake) results concur with what they already know on the topic, few will bother to contest the implications of the correlation, but even then the more numerate people will be less likely to fully affirm that the "right" answer is an entirely justified conclusion based on the meager data (thus the wobbly graphs whenever the topic is a "real" one and not "brand X cream").  TLDR; Things are seldom simple, there are "yeah buts" in nearly every non-trivial topic.

@9:20 The problem with this claim is that it presumes that the evidence is reliable. It is easy to answer a question about hypothetical numbers if we just assume that the numbers were well collected with proper control and methodology (which is extremely difficult to assume; for example, in the skin cream example, unless you're comparing the efficacy of "moisturizing agents in general vs nothing" your control group should be given some sort of generic moisturizing cream to compare against your specialized skin cream). But the fact of the matter is that "studies" and "numbers" are not at all reliable and are empirically very biased by their creators. A study run by a progressive scientist is likely to conclude that gun control decreases crime. A study run by a conservative scientist is likely to conclude that gun control increases crime. The entire "field" of parapsychology existing demonstrates that you can easily manufacture results from thin air. Awful replication rates in any social sciences show the unreliability of social science studies, paper mills, retraction retraction rates, etc. show that none of this gets any better outside of parapsychology with our vaunted peer review processes.  People are incorrect in their belief that they would change their positions in response to this sort of information, but they are not irrational in their refusal to do so. "Data" on these things is biased accounting by someone with an agenda. It is very difficult to find good data.

I have so many problems with the study as you presented it here, especially with clips of the street interviews which I assume is some influencer reproducing it for clicks.  How was the question worded?  Did it ask their opinion with the chart just there, did it ask them, like with the skin cream, to simply explain the graph?  If you ask someone "what's your opinion on X, by the way I have this study here that proves the correct answer is Y" there's little reason to trust or even acknowledge the supposed study, it feels like they're trying to sway the responses with a biased question (which I've had to deal with way too many times answering national surveys).  Lastly, regarding the question of if I'll change my views when I see conflicting evidence?  No, at least not at first.  I don't form my views based on single pieces of evidence, there is often a ton of things that add up to give me confidence that my opinion is correct.  Seeing one thing that disagrees with me doesn't counteract everything else that got me there in the first place.  It's significantly more likely that the new thing is wrong, out of context, or is an exception I can slightly tweak my world view to accommodate.  For example:  Climate change is real, we are in a warming trend.  What about a year that was cooler on average?  Should I change my opinion that I'm completely wrong, that we're actually cooling?  No, it's a trend over many years, individual years are going to fluctuate.  What about that one mountain that has had it's ice cap increase over the last few hundred years?  Still not changing my opinion, that's why it was renamed to climate change instead of global warming, it's a trend across the entire globe, each smaller region will be affected differently.  If the overwhelming majority of evidence suddenly supported a different conclusion, if the new evidence managed to overcome the evidence I already had... well I'd still not switch entirely because now I need to account for why I was so wrong in the first place.  How did I have so much evidence for the wrong conclusion?  That all needs to be accounted for now.  But yes, I will eventually change my mind.

The only reasonable answer to the poorly-formed question, "did the skin cream make the rash better or did it make the rash worse" is "I don't know". The results from the people not taking cream are irrelevant. But just because more people improved when taking the cream than got worse taking the cream does not mean it was the cream that "caused the improvement", because correlation does not imply causation. Any mathematician that does not have some sort of sceptical reasoning like this upon being asked a poorly-formed, confusing question, should be ashamed to call themselves a mathematician. [So, for example, the question *was not*, "did the skin cream make the rash better or did it make the rash worse, compared with no skin cream?", although perhaps this was the intended question.]

This is a perfect example of why its so easy to use statistics to lie: Context.  If you had simply shown people the raw numbers, with no labels whatsoever, and asked them to tell you which ratio was bigger, you would have received significantly more correct answers. Because that's a very simple question to answer, even for people that can barely do math. But, by labeling the numbers the way you did, you added the implication of extra context, without actually supplying that context. So it just ended up obfuscating the question you were trying to get people to answer.  If you had asked me either of these questions, my answer would be: Insufficient data. Because, to actually properly answer a complicated question like "does gun control improve crime rates?", you need more than a single set of numbers. You need to know ALL the factors involved in the study. For example: What did the study consider a crime? Is it just violent crimes? Violent crimes involving guns? Were there any other factors associated with the changing crime rates, like the size or wealth of the city? And, did it take into account that suddenly making guns illegal will make everyone that currently owns a gun into a criminal?  But, because its all fake, you can't provide any of that information. So, the person answering is going to have to fill in all those blanks themselves. They have to invent context to make your question make sense to them before they can even begin answering it. And of course that context is going to be colored by their political alignment. Especially if you're asking people that are currently at a political event. They're already primed to be thinking about everything in political terms.  Basically: Many people didn't get the answer wrong, they didn't even answer the right question. Because you didn't make it clear enough what the right question even was. And yet you still counted those people as getting the question wrong, because doing so supported your own bias about the expected results.

Your graphic says "crime increased" and "crime decreased". Whereas the paper you're showing people clear says "crime improved" and "crime worsened". The column headings on the paper can be interpreted either way, depending on if you're looking at it from the perspective of the victim (crime improved = crime rates are down), or the perpetrator (crime improved = easier to commit crime).  I don't doubt the result of your study - it seems intuitively obvious to me. But I really think you should've re-done it with "crime increased" and "crime decreased" printed on the paper. Just to eliminate that ambiguity.

I find the potential interpretations of the various specific lines to be fascinating. If we use the initial graph as a control group, we see that low numeracy results in people be outright steered wrong, well below 50%, meaning that the counterintuitive nature of the data as specifically presented wins out even over random guesses (50%). The steady rise in results as numeracy increases makes sense. On the other hand, it seems like the intuitive nature of cream making things better for a lot of people freed them up to think in all sorts of ways, leading to essentially random results for the bottom half of numeracy before numeracy skills kicked in. In other words, faced with a seemingly surprising result, people tried to examine the data and then results depended on how well one grasps counterintuitive numbers, while the face value intuitive result launched people with weaker numeracy skills all as a grouo into a wider range of (probably qualitative) thinking.  As for the final graph, we see that Republicans faced with the undesired (read: counterintuitive, to them) data defaulted to their assumptions the most, getting worse in the middle (suggesting that some degree of numeracy encouraged looking at the numbers more, but then misinterpreting it) before numeracy reaches an "escape velocity" at the top end that resulted in a steep improvement in performance that still only eventually reached a coin flip.  Republicans faced with expected data saw the most linear improvement as numeracy increased, suggesting the most clear-headedness (and thus a more skill based outcome) for that group of the four. Democrats faced with the expected results appear to overthink things in the numeracy middle before it then catches back up on the high end, while Democracts facing the undesired results basically saw random results across numeracy. That last one to me seems particularly interesting, as there seems some force at play regarding the nature of the group and/or the nature of seeing data that gun control actually raised crime leading to everyone to think qualitatively (and, thus, more arbitrary in result) instead of quantitatively.  Curious!

This reminds me of the way data is used to discard some questions being tested for use on standardized tests. For most questions, and as expected, as the overall scoring of testers increases there is an associated rise in percentage who get the specific question correct. Naturally, the overall percentage who get it correct helps determine the identified difficulty level of said question.  However, on some questions there is a curious phenomenon that emerges: there is a DIP is rate of answering the question right among the highest scorers. Why? The understood cause is that there is some kind of subtle nuance in the wording or information of the question that introduces some necessary interpretation, with some interpretations resulting in getting the wrong answer as intended but the right answer on the basis of those alternate/overlooked interpretations. That flaw in the question invalidates it for use, leading to it being discarded in its current form.
Regarding the hypothetical cream test. Is it either improving/worsening or is there also a number for people where the condition did not change? That would influence the interpretation of the data.

There is a bit of an issue in your thinking, and that issue is the presumption that opinions are largely data driven, even among highly intelligent people. There are massive philosophical differences which make two people apply the same reading of sociopolitical data entirely differently. As an example, there is no data which could convince me that taking guns away from law abiding citizens is a morally acceptable policy, because my opinion on that is not data-driven. It is philosophy-driven. Even if I were to concede that gun control measures were highly correlative with significant declines in crime, that would not change my opinion on whether law abiding citizens should maintain the right to bear any arm they see fit for the protection of their life and liberty.  The idea that a more rational look at from all involved will result in less polarization ignores the real driver in that polarization, which is philosophy.

Hold on.... The skin creme question right off the bat is intentionally missing information. Is the creme group the same size as the control group? Is it binary results only? Were there people with no change in number of rashes? It's the same question asked 3 ways, but it drastically affects the "correct answer". Basically, if there are 500, 1000 or 10000 people in each group, the rash improved with the cream is the right answer. Of course, it was also made worse more often as well. Assuming there's a noticeable change either way is kind of stretch. Maybe it's a bad example, but I can't imagine any real study with binary results like this. Imagine it was weight loss. Oh, you weighed 200.0 at the start, at the end of the study you weighed 200.1. I guess you go in the "gained weight" category. 199.9 well, you lost weight. But in reality, those should likely be statistically insignificant. Oh, you had 99 rashes at the start, 100 at the end. Are we measuring number of rashes or square footage? It's just a bad example.

This is such a flawed study.  If anything, you can say the creme etc. made the rash better, but not to the same extent as no creme.  You cannot say it made it worse since most participants did improve.  In the converse, if a pharma company went to the FDA and asked for approval for a creme where 223 worsened and 75 improved, they would laugh at you, even thought this video postulates that these results represent a positive causality.  Same with the gun control - more cities both with and without gun control saw improved crime.  Correlation is not causation, and this study was not a positive proof of cause. I watch as people use tribal psychology to explain why "they" support "their" side, even smart people,  But almost nobody then say, "I wonder if tribal psychology is affecting MY political views." And then re-evaluate what they believe to be true.  That should be the main lesson here.   I (unknowingly) participated in a demonstration of tribal psychology in a leadership course 17 years ago. Even though I'm cognitively aware of the manipulation that was done as we discussed it at the time, and the random assignment to different teams, I can still notice in the back of my mind some "doubt", with a feeling that, "Am I sure they didn't just assign all the bad people to that other group and good people to our group." I wonder how this relates to the representation of plain numbers in other ways. For example:  In different types of graphs.  Changing the wording in table and axis headers.  More abstract or more lifelike examples.  Not just showing absolute numbers but precalculating and showing the ratios. Adding human readable natural language context explaining the numbers to see if that will get everyone on the same page or still have people reject that and draw different conclusions. Basically show people the same numbers but in different ways.  Personally I'm a sucker for graphs. I know I'm slow with numbers and calculating ratios, while a good graph can instantly illustrate a conclusion, by a line crossing another line, or showing a minimum, or by just being above another line.  You still have to think if you are looking at the right graph though, as they can be as misleading as they can be useful to support any conclusion. A good rule of thumb seems to be to have multiple graphs plotting data against different things, then try to explain the features brought forward by each graph, and by weighing everything in dismiss graphs that might be tainted by a bias in the data, and be left with the graphs that hold true. That is a lot of work though, and anyone can be picky in picking any graph, so in communication it really boils down to trust in the source anyway. :-/

Derek, I understand the point you're trying to make here, but there are some serious problems with how you're presenting the results of this poll.  #1: You do not tell us the question that you asked the people you interviewed about the guns. You show us shots of them discussing what they're looking at, but we do not know how you phrased the question. Did you ask, "Here are the results of a research study. Do you think that gun control increases or decreases crime?" or did you ask, "do these numbers show an increase or decrease in crime?" The first question asks people to MAKE A JUDGEMENT on the results of a hypothetical study that you have told them nothing about, about a topic that they may already know a lot about. Many people might have already seen many similar, REAL studies in the past that gave conflicting information.  The second question prompts them to interpret some numbers. They may STILL answer that question the same as the first, but undoubtedly some would not. I think that the only completely reasonable answer to the first way of phrasing the question is, "this chart does not tell me nearly enough information to reach a conclusion." Any science student asked to form a conclusion based on nothing but this chart should get a failing grade for their general science literacy. How many people actually answered, "I don't know; this doesn't tell me enough to reach a conclusion"? Why aren't those numbers shown in the results you're showing us?  #2: As many other people have pointed out, the way you present the sample data TO US, in the video, is "crime increased" and "crime decreased". The materials you are showing other people say "crime improved" and "crime worsened" with green and red arrows. This MIGHT result in the same answers and it might not.  The thing that these issues have in common is that you are presenting us, your audience, with a potentially misleading representation of your experimental setup, which, very ironically, leads to the final issue that many people here have brought up: TRUST. Many people have learned to be extremely skeptical of reports of studies that they read about in the news that have political implications. If someone came up to you on the street and showed you a chart that supposedly showed that climate change didn't exist, would you just say, "yep, I guess that's what it says!" or would you attempt to have a conversation with the person to change their mind because of the damage that their message can cause?  Why does it matter WHY these people argued for their belief instead of accepting the numbers you put in front of them? Because if you misunderstand the cause of this behaviour, you cannot fix it. In your video, you've focused mostly on needing to make people aware of their political biases, but mostly skirted around the fact that most people are surrounded by terribly presented information by self-serving sources and even if people know how to read a study with a critical eye, even experts in a field have difficulty sorting through the haystack to find something trustworthy. But unfortunately, ironically, this video (though I 100% agree with what I believe your ideological intentions to be) is actually a PERFECT example of what to be on the lookout for: An ideological message wrapped in the trappings of a scientific study and presented in a way that prevents the viewer from verifying your conclusions by giving them an undistorted view of the setup and the result data.  My challenge to you, Derek: either re-make this video to the standards of scientific literacy that YOU are hoping the general public to reach, or re-make this video with a big disclaimer at the beginning saying: "I performed this poll for the purposes of illustrating a point that I think is extremely important, and is based off of this research paper that I invite people to read. This poll and the way I am presenting the results are not an example of scientific research." You reach a tremendous amount of people and I believe that you have a responsibility to lead by example. I WANT this video to be good because I believe in the ideological argument you're making, but right now, I don't believe it is.
Smarter people are more likely to be skeptical of the study. They're not getting the question wrong, they want additional information. They may be pressured to give an answer when they would be more comfortable abstaining.

Maybe I'm dumb but...doesn't the reasoning for the correct answer to the skin-care question fail to take into account that number of people in the Experimental Condition whose rash would have got better anyway even without the cream?ü§î (We know from the No Cream condition that 84% of the time, the rash improved even without cream, and that 16% of the time, it got worse without cream). This is slightly off the topic of this video but I feel like the question was misleading. You didn't have an equal size of experimental group vs control group. Which forces you to use proportions, not your intuitive quantitative reasoning. Also, the underlying understanding in the first case, is that rashes improve on their own, and the cream proportionately made things worse. But in the second case, if you switch the labels, it means rashes **worsen** on their own, but the cream made things slightly better. Two very different intuitive understandings that you need to keep in mind to turn this table into an intuitive description. This is a really confusing exercise to me, who's very intuitive, i.e. connected to multiple forms of logic. And not always capable of remembering them all at once.  For example, at first glance, I blanked the concept of a control group, and intuitively assigned, in the first case, the underlying understanding that rashes improve on their own, to the efficacy of the cream only, leading me to just go by the large numbers. I'm not formatted to intuitively go to proportions, but neither am I to think about biology when faced with a math issue. I just looked at the people using the cream, and if more improved than worsened, then the cream worked. I didn't need the control group, because I'd blanked the idea there are other factors affecting the state of the rash. And I don't think I'm horrible with numbers. I'm not the best, but I'm not the worst.   So I'm not sure this exercise measures "numeracy" as you say. I think it measures familiarity with math exercises, and indirectly,  how formatted you are. And these people are not formatted, and by definition are open. So open people are open and stubborn people are stubborn. This very basic fact is just hidden in all the jargon. I would redo the experiment, but pick people whom you suspect are the least formatted, and hopefully some are good with numbers too. Here is the problem I see with this study  Me being a pedantic asshole when the cream experiment was being explained thought "looking at some number of people with a rash and not giving them any cream isn't actually a control group. You need to give them some cream with no active ingredients to control for the placebo effect." also " why are the control group and the test group of such vastly different sizes"   Eventually I was like ok I guess they aren't trying to get that info and want me to just do the math. But here is the problem, it doesn't matter what the math says if the experiment was set up incorrectly. And people are much less likely to check if the experiment was set up correctly if they don't' care what the result is. Just to show how statistics can be bent in many ways, to support any standpoint:  - Provided that with cream, 223 patients improved and 75 patients got worse. - Provided that without cream, 107 patients improved and 21 patients got worse. - This means that 107 of the 223 patients would have improved without cream, therefore the cream has actually helped 116 patients. - This also means that 21 of the 75 patients would have gotten worse despite the cream, leaving 54 patients that experienced adverse effects.  Conclusion: The cream is over twice as likely to help, then it is to have an adverse effect.

I think this can be explained by the fact people think in Bayesian Probability terms. You have a prior belief, when new data comes in, it will shift your prior belief depending on how statistically significant the data is. Testing an anti-aging cream on identical twins can indeed produce more reliable results, especially if the goal is to minimize genetic variation in the study. Here‚Äôs why this approach can be advantageous: 1. Genetic Identicality      Identical twins share the same genetic makeup, meaning their skin's genetic-based reactions will be very similar. This consistency eliminates the genetic variability that would naturally arise among random test subjects with different skin types, melanin levels, or other genetic differences.  2. Control Over Environmental Factors      If the twins live in similar environments, the lifestyle and environmental influences on skin aging are also more controlled. This is particularly important because anti-aging results are significantly affected by factors like sun exposure, diet, and stress. With random test subjects, such factors would introduce much more variability.  3. Reliable Comparisons      By applying the cream to only one twin while using the other as a control (using a placebo or no treatment), any observed differences more likely reflect the cream‚Äôs true effects. This method helps isolate the product's impact since the twins are otherwise identical in genetics and, potentially, environment.  4. Consistent Results      With genetic variables largely eliminated, the results are likely to be more consistent compared to testing on random subjects, where diverse reactions would lead to a wider range of outcomes.  In Summary  Testing on identical twins provides a clearer view of the anti-aging cream‚Äôs effects because the genetic similarities make it easier to distinguish the product‚Äôs true impact. This approach is more reliable and yields more consistent results, making it highly effective for objectively assessing the cream‚Äôs effectiveness.  Chatgpt

This particular study may not be telling us quite what you think.   When we're presented with the skin creme question, we assume - because it is simple and a-political - that the data is "good". That the experiment was not contaminated, that the creme is the only variable, etc. So we solve for that.  When we're presented with the gun control question - for as long as we think the numbers are real - we immediately remember all the flawed studies that we have seen on the topic. The variables here are multiple and cannot be controlled, the people collecting data are politically motivated, etc. So we assume the data is "bad".  For example, where the data showed an increase in gun crime, did the increase happen in shootings between criminal and normal citizen, or between criminal and criminal? Did the numbers reflect homicide or homicide plus suicide, as they so often do in real life? Where the numbers show a decrease, what was the crime that did not happen replaced with - no crime, or a "non-gun" crime? The numbers simply don't tell.  So we solve based on real life heuristics. Which is I think correct. This isn't necessarily our politics clouding our vision, this is real life complications breaking into simple math.
