I'd point out that even the most open-minded with regard to evidence aren't necessarily open-minded when it comes to VALUES. A person who believes in maximizing individual choice might oppose a policy that has good social outcomes (oppose controls on firearm ownership or use despite lower crime) because the liberty is indexed with higher value than the related social impact. The capacity to recognize a mathematical relationship doesn't necessarily reflect the partisan position. A totalitarian police state with cameras everywhere and limited choice would make for a fairly stable community order with low crime - think 1984, or Singapore if you're more utopian than dystopian - but most would reject the encroachment on privacy and individual choice despite the otherwise beneficial outcome.  Policy questions thus are issues of value, not of numeracy.  More interesting than supported policy positions is the dissonance between the mathematical facts and the assessed outcome.
‚ÄúIt shows that there is a particular type of problem, where the smarter you are the more likely you are to get it wrong.‚Äù  (0:04-0:08). Such a statement is patently false based upon the most reasonable interpretation of the words and stating it as the truth does a disservice to the paper and the truth. Here‚Äôs why:  To evaluate the truth of a statement we must first ensure we are all using the same definitions for all our words. Dereks' statement has some ambiguity, so let‚Äôs try to translate it to the same verbiage as the paper. ‚ÄúIt shows that there is a particular type of problem‚Äù  - referencing covariance-detection problems, with partisan significance where the correct response conflicts with individuals' political outlooks. ‚Äú‚Ä¶where the smarter you are‚Ä¶‚Äù ‚Äì relating to individuals having higher numeracy ‚Äúthe more likely you are to get it wrong‚Äù ‚Äì there is a higher percentage chance that you provide the incorrect response. Piecing this together, Derek's precise statement would read: ‚ÄúIn reference to covariance-detection problems with partisan significance, the higher an individual measured numeracy, the higher the percentage chance is that the individual provides an incorrect response when such incorrect responses agree with their partisan biases.‚Äù  Taking directly from the paper: ‚ÄúLiberal Democrats become increasingly likely to correctly identify the result supported by the data as they become more numerate in the ‚Äúcrime decreases‚Äù condition; but increasing numeracy had a minimal impact for Liberal Democrats in the ‚Äúcrime increases‚Äù condition.‚Äù To me ‚Äúminimal impact‚Äù does not represent a substantive claim higher numeracy individuals are more likely to provide an incorrect response when presented with data that supports the opposite of their held beliefs. Instead, I would suggest that at best we could say: Numeracy has no significant impact/minimal impact on an individual's ability to determine the correct response in covariance-detection problems with significant partisan significance.  This is in contrast to non-partisan covariance-detection problems, where a higher numeracy is highly correlated with an increase in the likelihood of the determination of the correct conclusions.  A far cry from the original statement.   Moreover, I do not think that the original papers' analysis methods produce the most truthful graphs. For example, would you be able to tell from the graphs that ALL individuals with a numeracy score of 9  correctly identified the correct conclusion in the partisan problems regardless of whether the conclusion supported/constated with their political beliefs?

This is interesting because the interviewer seems to ask for a causal relationship, "does the cream make the rash better?". It's fairly logical to conclude they've set up the study so other variables are controlled and there's likely a direct link between cream and rash. However, the gun study is very unlikely to be a randomized, controlled study, but rather, looking at correlations. So it's not really fair to ask "is the study showing banning guns causes more violence?" I think that the divisive political questions of our times often are hard to get good data on and  it's easy to use a misleading correlation. If the study results conflict with a pre-existing belief, we're much more likely to think about how the study is designed/why a correlation might not be a causation. (For example, for the gun study, I would immediately think, did they control for economic growth? job opportunities? waves of crime moving in from elsewhere?). TL:DR: it would make more sense to create example studies that were more similar in terms of correlation/causation and ask the questions more clearly.

I think there is a sense in which higher-intelligence people tend to intuitively grasp that political issues are issues *because* they are complicated, so simple tables like this probably can't capture the whole story. So we start hedging ourselves and trying to intuit what was methodologically wrong with how the data was collected if it conflicts with our worldview. I'd probably have done the same, immediately trying to ask questions about data collection methodology and so on in the gun control study, rather than trusting that it was a proper placebo or control study the same way I would have assumed it would be without too much worry when it comes to skin cream. One major problem I'd immediately single out with respect to the gun control study would be that it's functionally impossible to randomize your sample because you can only sort based on which cities actually passed certain laws, which confounds with a boatload of other local political things that may have their own effects on crime. I think it's a little suspicious to claim that there is obviously some kind of "right answer" in the gun control study. That doesn't stop me from hedgingly giving the correct apparent statistical answer, but the methodological red flags that smart people pick up on definitely have an impact here.

Only about half way through, but this study is pretty much BS. For starters, it creates two false studies, but the studies themselves are radically different. The skin cream study is privately gathered data, so it not very questionable. It would be like asking if people believed that 75% of people preferred Bob's Barbecue Classic recipe and only 25% preferred Bob's New Barbecue recipe. Even if I knew of Bob's Barbecue and had eaten it, it's not a stretch to say that I'm in the majority or even the minority on my personal preferences. Gun control, however, has decades and decades of statistics and the people looking at the "wrong" table with a high numeracy are more likely to have seen the real statistics instead of the fake statistics.  So in one case, you have a (fake) survey conducted on very private data that can't really be challenged due to real world knowledge or experience, and a second (fake) survey conducted where all of the relevant data has been released for decades and is the single underpinning point behind a person's belief. It's like comparing people who solved a math problem correctly and those who are told to solve a math problem in an incorrect way and get an incorrect answer. If I'm confronted in the street and asked to solve a math problem, I'll treat it as a math problem. If you tell me you've uncovered a study that I've seen countered a hundred different ways, you're absolutely right that I'm going to push back. That's not a case of "smarter people doing worse." It's a case of the people being smarter than the test givers.

It is quite possible that this represents a very statistically rational behavior. When presented with trial data about an unknown skin cream, it is easy to assume this is one of a very small number of such studies, so it‚Äôs rational to make statistical claims based on its data alone. When a contentious issue is discussed, this is likely to be one of many such studies, so its conclusions should be considered in the context of the research around it rather than in isolation. Since any response in a public poll could be taken as support for policy, it is rational to make claims carefully when there is data missing.

But the gnn question was immediately more difficult to conceptualise than the rash cream.  The higher your numeracy skills, the better you are at interpreting and understanding data and statistics.  The rash question is easy, there was only one variable,  you have the all of the relevant data, and it appears reliable, so you can answer purely on the maths. This is result is not irrational. The high numeracy people were applying Bayesian reasoning. They had prior knowledge they believed held more weight than the numbers presented in the experiment. This was even 100% rational, since the numbers presented were completely made up.
for this type of questions we generally used risk ratio or odds ratio to get better understanding about the result. The risk ratio is the ratio of the probability (risk) of an event happening in an exposed group to the probability of the event happening in a non-exposed (or control) group. Since you have a control group (without cream) and an experimental group (with cream), this setup is similar to a cohort study where you're comparing the occurrence (or risk) of rash cure in both groups over a period. You can directly calculate the probability (or risk) of cure in each group and then find the ratio between them, making the risk ratio the best fit for interpreting the effectiveness.

There's an important distinction between "Can I read this data?" and "Is it convincing enough?".  "This seems to suggest gun control works. But if legislation like this gets pushed through after an uptick in gun violence, we may just see regresssion to the mean."  This isn't necessarily about how politicised something is, but more general about underlying assumptions (see Bayseian statistics). Even if the numbers are the same, we'd think differently about studies that suggest blueberries protect against a certain type of cancer, vs. one that suggests they protect against lightning strikes. The difference is how plausible we believe the connection to be.

Here's what I did. I made them into two groups. Group A where the people used the cream. Group B where people didn't. I rounded the numbers to 225, 75 for group A and 108, and 22 for group B. (1)-In group A- for 75% of the people of group A the cream worked and they felt relief from their rashes. The cream didn't work for 25% of people from group A and their rashes got worse. (2)-In group B- for 83.07% of people from group B, their rashes improved. Rashes got worse for 16.93% of people from group B. From the data until now, we find that people who didn't use the cream were 1.1076 time more likely to improve their rashes than those who used the cream. And yes of course the fact that relative one's own group, group A had 3 times more people fixed than worsened whereas group B had 5 times more people fixed than worsened. And that the people who didn't use the cream were 1.4776 times more likely to NOT worsen their rashes than the people who did use the cream. But this should be considered a real world setting and hence we must also consider the amount of data given. (3)-Group A had 298 people which I rounded off to 300 as I mentioned.  (4)-Group B had 128 people which I also rounded off to 130. The result varies only little without rounding off. From this we find that group A had 2.3076 times more data to provide than group B. If we also look at how much data more was being provided by group A than group B and that it was more than how much more group A was likely to fail, in a real world setting, it can be at the very least concluded that group A isn't as worse than what many might have presumed just by seeing how much it was more likely to fail. Also, if it were a real statistic, I believe the cream would be beneficial for people who haven't dealt with skin problems in the past and whose skin isn't reactive. Until and unless the data says that the condition also worsened for people who haven't had skin problems before.

I'm reading the comments and on one hand I'm wondering if the fact that so many people are missing the point of the study is evidence that Veritasium's video could have done a better job at presenting it, on the other I wonder if the comments perfectly validate the results of the study itself.  People are questioning the methodology of the study, even though they are using the illustrative re-enactment of the video, just to make sure the results do not contradict their beliefs. They are doing the same with the potentially click-baity nature of the title, etc. Those are fair items for discussion, but the numbers in the study are the numbers in the study. One could indeed read the study and critique the methodology, or even better, try and reproduce the results, but the numbers are what they are.  The comments section does seem to capture the fundamental epistemological problem that this kind of studies raise: Is being aware of a potential bias sufficient to prevent applying that bias? It probably isn't in many contexts, this being one of them.

I am not sure that it is because of politics. I think it is due to confirmation bias. We look for data or interpret data to fit our idea of how something works.   I think it fits with political concepts well because often the problems are complex and difficult to simply test. There tend to be many variables and complex relationships between the variables. People also tend to be well entrenched in their idea of a solution or cause to a political issue.   This is why in many studies the groups and or data are blinded from the person(s) collecting and/or analyzing the data. So that conclusions can be drawn strictly from the numerical data rather than individual biases. Just some thoughts that I think help/hurt why people would entrench or fail to engage with the numbers: - A skin care study is assessing the entire sample of people effected by the cream/non-cream (100% of the people in the study were measured) while ~500 samples in a gun control study would barely scratch the surface of all of the potential variables and implications of different crimes (boiled down to one number) - Political topics are inherently more difficult because its harder to quantify things like "control" and "safety" as these are relative terms that heavily change based on the population - There's an inherently emotional response about gun control/violence because it directly impacts life and death, along with people being passionate about whichever side they feel best serves the problem  Overall, I think reducing a study about rashes down to a number is reductionist, but logical for people. Compared to something that they feel is inherently more nuanced (due to the emotional side of their reasoning framing it as logic) they would likely substitute (probably accurate) flaws with data collection processes in general, but ones that just so happen to agree with their beliefs. The problem with "smart" people is, that they are good at reasoning. So good indeed, that they are able to fool themselves, that their pre-held believe is true. Cognitive dissonance is holding onto beliefs and convincing yourself, that they have to be right, because you are a good/smart/... person.  If I believe, there is a lot of red cars on the roads and want to make sure that's true, I would see every red car and "conclude" (validate my already existing believe) there is a lot of them. If someone believes there is very little red cars, they would look at every car that's not red as well and conclude there is way more of those, so they are right. If I didn't have a believe I would just look at all the cars I see, count them by color and use whatever percentage is red to reason that both believes could be valid, depending on what you think "a lot" means. And the more emotionality and conviction is behind a believe, the more likely you are to subconsciously search and find evidence to support your believe and misinterpret and ignore opposing evidence.

These studies always show the same thing: That progressive, left leaning people are smarter and better informed. The whole fake numbers to see if you can trick them into thinking that gun control doesn't work is very clever. But only shows that even fake numbers can't really fool them. "But they're supposed to just believe the numbers!" They do, but you're talking about a type of person who values being informed and, on average, attempts to be informed. This exposes them to . . . more numbers. When you get hit with lots of numbers, you learn to parse them and judge them: 'How valuable and informative are these numbers? Do they line up with numbers I've seen? Is someone trying to fool me here?' These are the questions an informed person asks themselves upon learning the results of a study. If you were to ask yourselves these questions in response to the numbers showing that a hypothetical gun control measure was ineffective, you'd be correct to reject them (remember, the numbers shown were fake, not real).  You're also dealing with a population of people who live in a world full of misinformation. When those intelligent enough to do so detect that something is wrong with the information they're presented with, they'll take oblique positions that will restate or insist on what they know to be generally true in order to mitigate the misinformation. They are correct to do this.

"Did the skin cream make it better or worse?" can have more than one interpretation, because it could be better or worse than using no cream or better or worse than it has been before. If we go for the second interpretation that would mean that cream and no cream will both result in less rashes than before.  The latter interpretation is the one I went for because it was just about the rash getting better not comparing cream vs no cream even though the data was given. I am not sure if the question was intended to be interpreted in different ways but I think it has to be considered when talking about answering right or wrong.  It also fits with experiences from the real world as the human body is capeable to heal rashes. This could also be explained by people changing their lifestyle which results in better or worse rashes. In other words: there are unknown variables of which we dont know if their influence is significantly influencing the test results. This is why it is REALLY a lot of effort to statistically prove something is working in a specific way in the human body. We frequently see reports demonstrating that contrary evidence has low efficacy in changing people‚Äôs beliefs on contentious policy issues. This study is in the same vein. The underlying issue was that our assumption of a closed universe turned-out to be false.  TLDR - we should always be open to being wrong, no matter how "absurd" the other side seems.

It's like you reached into my mind and pulled out what I‚Äôve been thinking about for months, but the video is focused more on collective socio-political bias, where I‚Äôve been seeing it in individual terms. Broadly, our biases are shaped by forces that are both psychological and biological / evolutionary. This is a kind of autopilot shaping our responses in ways that seem to be grounded in facts but which may obscure the path through curiousity to genuine understanding. The individual breakdown is a combination of at least 4 things: The mere-exposure effect (MEE), perceptual fluency (PF), psychological asymmetry (PA), and the Dunning-Kruger effect (DKE).  Derek suggests that the answers are very complex and he‚Äôs right because each bias compounds the other, but these aren't things that have collective solutions (even that phrase barely makes sense), so the only way of dealing with this is individually. The MEE and PF make us more receptive to familiar ideas simply because we‚Äôre exposed to them more often. In social or political terms, this means people often echo what‚Äôs popular, easy, or 'safe' to think, because their brains find it low-effort and comfortable because it is already known. There‚Äôs an evolutionary reason for this: novel ideas require new neural pathways, which demand more energy, making the familiar not just appealing but practical ‚Äî efficient. This seems like a potential famine survival strategy from deep in our past, so it could easily also exist in other species even without language, and in other Hominins.  Then we get to PA and the DKE. Together, these biases explain the drive to overestimate our ability to understand complex issues while underestimating others. In group contexts, this manifests as overconfidence in our own views and predictions or assumptions about others. When we sometimes think we know what others will say or what they believe ‚Äî these assumptions build a figurative echo chamber in our own heads. By the time someone actually speaks, we‚Äôre so confident in our assumptions and our cleverness that we often miss what they‚Äôre truly saying.  Yet, the individual paths to overcoming these biases can be drawn out. It starts with recognizing our own patterns‚Äîthe way MEE and PF make us prefer what‚Äôs familiar, and the way PA and DKE trap us in a feedback loop of self-assured predictions. This awareness is the first step toward excavating a deeper layer of (what may or may not be but I can only describe as) free will. By first witnessing then disentangling from these trained, biological, and behavioral responses, we get closer to real choices instead of falling back on our brains‚Äô default scripts.  Maybe this is linked with our potential self-domestication ‚Äì latent survival traits enhanced to a point where we‚Äôve built habits and mental shortcuts that prioritize efficiency over insight on top of our bodies' natural famine austerity measure response. And while it may have served our species (and others) well biologically, individually stepping outside of it might be the only way to break through and actually understand ourselves and others.  Thank you ‚Äî there is a lot of work to be done to escape Mike Judge's prophecy of idiocracy that is in the beginning stages.

I think the major issue here is that the more intelligent the individual, the better they will be at convincing others _and themselves_ of what they believe in, especially on a matter that is polarized based on a person's values which are only justified by logic post-hoc. It's already incredibly difficult to train yourself to approach a question as if you were an unbiased scientist attempting to interpret the data, so throwing in factors that are heavily influenced by emotion and cultural osmosis would tilt the desire to the default belief you've convinced yourself of many times in the past.  Knowing this does indeed help you to understand that we are all humans and utilize the same tools in order to think, but I can't be optimistic that simply recognizing that will resolve polarization issues that arise from adherence to values. A person does not rationally think their way into the values that the believe in, so polarization that results from disagreements about the inherently emotional are going to be inevitable and actions taken by polarized individuals can get very nasty. I believe the best we can do is mediate where possible, but also recognize that disagreements on fundamental values are going to happen, and as such people will consider their values or cultures to be superior in one way or another to a different set of values or cultures.

I feel that the question has been communicated in an intentionally misleading manner, which is why Veritasium can write titles like such. The problem is with the question, ‚ÄúDoes the cream make the rash better?‚Äù This is clearly a yes, as 223 is greater than 75. Assuming the same amount of people was in the control group and the experimental group (lets call it x, x >=298). IF there are people whose rashes didn't improve, or worsen at all, then x should be larger or equal to 299. Then, the percentage of people whose rashes improved in the experimental group is 223/x * 100% <= 223/299 *100% = 74.582%. If we do the same for the control group, it would be 107/x * 100% <= 107/299 = 35.786%. Additionally: 223/x > 107/x. Therefore, as x decreases, the percentage of people whose rashes improved in the experimental group actually is ALWAYS HIGHER than the control group. IF there aren't people whose rashes didn't improve, or worsen at all, then 223 + 75 = 107 + 21, contradiction. If the the groups were divided unequally, and the experimental group got more people, then what is even the point of the comparison? We know that the average stabilizes with the increasing of the testing. Because the number 138 is so inferior to the number 298, the chances of random things happening increases. Studies like these are designed to get the most accurate numbers possible, not to trick dumb people. Its like saying that 1 out the 7 books written by this guy is bad, and another guy that has 3 out of 20 books written by him that are bad, and then saying that the second  guy is the worse writer, that is just not true, because the rest of the books are great books, and the second guy wrote worse because he has a lower percentage of bestsellers. No. These comparisons of "proportional reasoning" should only be applied when the pools are equal. So the first question is just a trick question to make dumb people feel better about themselves. Of course the end result of all of these 50/50 choices is generally the same as the random choice. The problem is that real world math is far too complex and fast for anyone other than an autistic savant to keep up with.  Take the skin cream.  There are about 200 factors that would have had to be controlled for in this experiment.    Just off the top of my head: 1: What creams are being used? (The MOA of the cream will directly change the result, hydrocortisone will likely reduce inflammation via inhbition of the immune system in the short term, but thin the dermis in the long term, making the rash worse... some things are known allergens, some things are toxic to human skin.  They used lead in makeup and probably still use horrifying chemicals in beauty products). 2: What duration? (see above for an example of how time can reverse a result re: topical steriods). 3: Population sample, where are they from, what is their environment, do they have a shared environment?  What are pollution levels like?  How are detergents and soaps controlled for?   4: Genetics (subtype of population sample, but if all your subjects are Asian or Sea gypsies, then you will have wildly different results).   4: Skin types (similar to above, but also not.  Fitzpatrick skin type). 5: Age. 6: Diet (I don't know how many as a percentage, but many rashes are actually just external manifestations of internal issues).   What is 'better' and what is 'worse'?  What is a 'rash'?  Maybe out of your 1111 subjects, 200 had insect bites, 300 had allergic reactions to clothing detergent, 150 had mild food allergies, 150 had allergies to pollutants in the air... etc. etc.    Your 203 and 75 are essentially meaningless math.    And it just doesn't make sense that your population would get worsening of rashes as a trend with both the control and the experiemental arm.. that's insane.  Like everyone had Lupus now? There's a major flaw with this experiment.  Sure, there's some confirmation bias, but people who are well-informed on issues know what the real data says.  They're less likely to scrutinize the numbers closely, because (in theory) it's data and patterns they're already familiar with.  Like, I already know that fossil fuels accelerate climate change.  If you present me with data that goes counter to that, but seems on the surface to agree, I may not catch on simply because I already know what the right answer is.

First, with the skin cream question. I am with the old lady on this one.  1) I would have to know what rash it is. 2) I would have to know what skin cream it is.  Furthermore, there are variables at play that doesn't show up in these fictitious numbers. - Stress induced rash, skin cream relieves stress, thus rash improves. Might as well rub gelatinated water on skin, it's the thought that counts. A.K.A, placebo. - Sun exposure (UV or IR light) that causes a rash (sunburn or other radiation related rash) where you apply a cream with some form of protection against sunlight. Could just as well be sun cream. Could also just be a case of "it was sunny when the rash appeared and after applying cream, it was cloudy". - Dry skin, be it from dry air or showering too much or using sanitizers or not hydrating enough or... Yeah, the cream didn't fix the issue. It just (might) makes the rash heal faster. - Any other, not cream related things that apply.  Numbers mean absolutely NOTHING without context. If you have first degree burns from exposure to open flame and you apply a cream specifically made to heal skin from first degree burns and it makes the burns better, then yes. I would say that using the cream makes the condition better. Numbers would show this. But if you have eczema from an allergic reaction to berries, then no amount of cream is going to fix the rash. It might make it less irritating but it will not remove the rash. Not eating the aforementioned berries will solve the issue.  A counter question, do pain killers actually remove the pain? No, it just blocks the pain receptors so you feel less pain. The pain is still there and only removing the cause of the pain will actually fix the pain. That being said, a pain killer can be just the thing that helps remove the cause of the pain. If you have a sore back, the fact you are moving in strange ways to avoid the pain can make the sore back even worse. Here, pain killers can actually be a remedy. But if the cause of your sore back is a knife stuck in your back, then no amount of pain killers is going to remove the knife.

There is a deeper layer to this, beyond just trying to fit into your tribe. Even an isolated individual can easily wind up deluding themselves. The trouble is how can any of us ever really know if we are right or wrong? The fact is that while there may be objective truths in this universe, there is no guarantee that we can ever be 100% certain of any of them. Ultimately it is your own brain that makes the final call, it has to decide using only the knowledge it has whether a statement is true or false. Sure, a scientifically trained person might nurture a more nuanced attitude, more readily allowing for uncertainty. This works fine when nothing much is at stake, but sometimes your survival depends on whether you get this right. Evolution has not conditioned us to sit on the fence and ponder things, we need to be decisive and act. There is a neurological mechanism in all animal brains which encourages "good" behaviour and discourages "bad" behaviour. For a squirrel, burying nuts for winter is "good" behaviour. Each animal has its particular ecological niche, and a set of behaviours which are beneficial or harmful to the animal. A freshly evolved neural network does not a priori know which behaviours are good or bad, it is guided by natural selection on the long term, and a sort of "trial and error" of each individual throughout life. What is the specific niche of humans? You could say it is general intelligence, the ability to learn and retain new information and adapt to varied environments. Just as the gazel gets faster to evade the lion, there is a selective pressure driving us to better understand the world around us. But remember, who is the final arbitrator? What is the metric of success here? Who decides whether or not you have understood? It is you; your brain which decides. In the past, the kinds of decisions we had to make were often life and death, if you made a bad call you would find out soon after. But since the agricultural revolution, food surplus, rise of civilisations, etc we have had much more free time to consider less critical things like "why is the sky blue?" and "is there a god?" There is no immediate feedback on these more philosophical questions. How then does the brain decide what to do? What to believe? Well it's kind of a "red pill, blue pill" scenario. You can cultivate a reserved, scientific mentality and put every idea through rigorous review and ultimately find that you can't really be sure of anything (red pill), or you can skip all that, pick an opinion, decide that you are correct, reap the neurological rewards from having "understood" something new, and be happy (blue pill). In the absence of some natural selection of "bad" ideas, there is a tendency for people to just believe things because it's easy, it gets you the same endorphins without all the trouble and confusion that goes along with really learning something new.

How large were the test group compared to the control group? The visuals in the video show them as same size. The numbers *suggest* that one group was larger (bigger numbers), but doesn't state that specifically (we don't know how many people saw neither a significant increase or decrease. Likely the majority of each group). The intuitive premise to assume would be equal sized groups, which would mean the cream has an amplifying (or dampening) effect, apart from also being simply bad/good, which could mess with peoples conclusions. This effect is of course only present IF the groups were the same size, but without specifically denying such a thing, it really is not an irrational assumption, and it can influence your idea of whether the cream "works" or not.  I would suggest that such a (potential) dampening/amplifying effect might be relevant for any real life application. Which in turn would  mean whether the cream/gun control is good/bad might not be as open and shut a mathematical question as suggested.   Maybe we want an amplifying effect (remember this is ONLY present if the test/control groups were of the same size!) on our current crime improvement rates, making the improvement happen faster, even if the overall rate of improvement to worsening actually gets worse? Sure the ratio between cities that get better and cities that get worse is not as good, but the overall effect is still positive. The numerical increase in improved cities vs the numerical increase in worsened cities is still in our favor. So after a year (lets say) more people would better off with the amplified effect despite the worse ratio. Ratios are not the only thing that matters (imagine more extreme numbers like positive going from 500-1000 (doubling), but negative going from 10-100 (increasing by a factor of 10). If we assume that the economic loss of every negative city cancels out one corresponding positive city, this would still mean an actual numerical benefit of 400 cities being better off. Which could be a huge net positive.  For peoples answers we should also consider that, if presented with statistics that deny a strongly held and well informed belief, it is in fact rational to (at first) assume an issue with the statistics, or more specifically the way the numbers are presented/used. In todays political climate specifically it is also unlikely that you on camera would admit to a random presented study showing your "opponents" political belief to be the true one, without being able to verify it (less relevant in the actual studies of course).  Degrees of improvement also aren't mentioned anywhere. If crime dramatically "improves" (bad word for this!) in the improved cities, and only slightly worsens in the worsened cities, that means something too.  By introducing real life into what was probably originally assumed to be a math problem by most participants (barring some in this video üòõ), you also introduce all these other factors. There is also an element of Bayes at play here. If you have a strong prior belief, then it would be unwise to overturn it on the basis of one extra piece of evidence. If you were to be presented with a constant stream of data the contradicted your prior belief, then you should change your belief. In the survey which had "gun control" as the measure, no mention is made of the type of gun control, so it certainly would be unwise to substantially modify your beliefs about the good and bad of gun ownership based on a survey that gave you no reason to have confidence in it - and that goes for both sides of the political fence. honestly, I'm a bit sad about the reasoning here, it's fairly incomplete IMO. It's true that the 'tribal thinking' is an aspect of this, but it doesn't have direct impact on the result of the study The only relevance for the tribalism is in 'why do people think this way' and 'how resilient are these ideas'.  what's most relevant here is 'confirmation bias'. it's where people tend to look for things that confirm their beliefs instead of things that disprove them. more specifically:  interpreting things in a way that's in line with pre-existing beliefs.(actual definition adds some extras, but this is the currently relevant part) and let's be honest, it's 100% a massive part of why the study had these results, so I'm really sad it was never mentioned in the vid.   So in this case, where the intuitive answer is "big number" but the actual answer can only be get by looking at percentages. If the numbers look like they don't prove your point (when the 'intuitive answer' doesn't match your point of view) people are more likely to look deeper into the numbers, usually to try and prove them wrong. Which is when they notice the issue with the intutive answer.  But if the intuitive answer confirms your PoV, then why look further into it? textbook confirmation bias.   So the whole thing doesn't have that much to do with math, it's mostly psychology, with a side of math (as in, being smart enough to figure out the solution is only relevant if you're willing to look past the intuitive answer and dig into the numbers.) and psychologically speaking it's not even about tribalism, it's mostly about confirmation bias.

I think the US is more divided than other democracies. And it might have something to do with the way elections are structured. By the end there are only two remaining candidates and only one can win the elections. This inevitably splits the country in half as people who might not have that much in common initially are forced to band together to fight this perceived greater evil. I have problems with this (video): You have a point but I feel like, I disagree, because there's so much context that isn't talked about but is very important for that conclusion. It would be impossible to put it all in one video, but still, I think your conclusion hasn't enough data to support itself. 1. The "correct" answer isn't even the real correct answer, just correct by the arbitrary numbers. People probably don't have an opinion on rash and creams but often have opinions about political things. So this "new evidence" that is even fake in this case confronts their opinion that maybe has some backup and people just try to bring that "new evidence" together with their world view. It would be stupid to come to a new conclusion based on these numbers alone and ignoring all other prior experiences. Especially on political topics it's likely numbers are biased. 2. Post hoc ergo propter hoc: The conclusion isn't even that logical. You could argue statistically every other influence flattens out so if crime rates statistically consistently change in one direction after implementing another policy, that it's because of that. That's kindof true, if the point of time of implementation in different places was independent from each other, maybe stretched out over 10 years, so that general movements in society can be neglected. But also we have a complex system here. Rashes and creams are biology and chemistry (I suppose), implemented policies is ecological. If you change one thing it can cause a cascade of things, because society has many feedback loops. Looking how it changed "after" is very imprecise in that case. And also while the sample size isn't that big (223+75+107+21=426) and crime probably is pretty self similar meaning different crimes partly aren't independent from each other, I think your "right" conclusion isn't that logical from these numbers. 3. There are statistical factors that probably bias the world view of people of different political sides. Democrats more often live in cities, Conservatives on the land. On the land police doesn't play that much of a role as in cities as people more likely solve conflicts on their own. If there is an intruder, the police takes longer so you know you can't really count on it. Being able to defend yourself is likely the better choice there. For cities it's more like opposite. So it's no wonder people categorize these numbers differently. 4. Why do the graphs start at 25% for 0 numerical skill. If these people can't deal with numbers, they would be like 50/50. Or atleast, if they are biased, the numbers for right answers in opposite cases would add up to about 100%. A little sus  All in all my problem is the implicit assumptions. That there is one logical conclusion from these numbers. That these numbers ought to be looked at as facts, even though they could be strongly biased in a real scenario. That number of crimes is the (only) relevant measurement for assertion of policies and the (only) relevant basis for political opinion.  I like your conclusion at the end though. We should also look forward an solve real problems and not only leave ourselves discussing about numbers.

Pre-answer answer: It depends on how you're defining which numbers are included and what constitutes "doing better"  Purely by number, the cream improved the most people even if you count all other parts combined (223 vs. 203). By ratio of just the cream users, it's nearly a 4-to-1 in favor of the cream doing better over worsening In comparison to improvements in both categories, the cream did better 2-to-1 In a ratio comparison, the lack of cream did better than with cream by having just over a 5-to-1 ratio compared to with cream's 4-to-1 If you look at it through raw helping numbers (aka number of people helped vs. number not helped without ratio-ing it), the cream users did have a lot of help but also a lot who also had it get worse, while the control didn't get the same numbers but also had significantly less people who had worsened rashes  It seems by most metrics the cream did better by raw numbers and I think you could reasonably extrapolate it'd do better than no cream in the long run, but based solely on the experiment you might be more likely to recover on your own than without the cream.  edit: Sorry, 3-1 for the cream better-to-worse ratio.

I made a confusion table of the data in a spreadsheet and got a type I error of 78% and type II error of 68%. Regardless of whether the survey was stated as for or against something, error rates that high show the study isn't very conclusive. If one is proportionally larger than the other, it's probably just a spurious coincidence rather than a real phenomenon.  I believe the numeracy value assigned to people represents their numerical intuition rather than quantitative reasoning skills. And just like how when people use their "fast brain" (according to Thinking Fast and Slow), they can get approximate but not certain results, high numeracy doesn't guarantee effective analysis ability.  As other people have mentioned in their comments, when someone lacks strong logical reasoning, they'll often shortcut the actually valid argument in order to get to their subjectively biased conclusion, falling to common fallacies. A better measurement of the population than this numeracy (number intuition) would probably be freedom from bias, since that ultimately seems to be the most powerful skill.

I do have some issues with the study design and think the conclusion do not hold up:  1.) The idea that there is a single rational answer to these examples is wrong. Or to be precise: The most rational answer would be "I don't know". Because all those contingency tables show is correlation. And correlation does not imply causation. We also know that just looking at correlation in highly aggregated data can show the complete opposite of the truth (see Simpsons Paradox). 2.) The fictitious study no means equivalent.  2a.) When it comes to the skin creme question, it implies that what we see is a clinical trial. Something that has at least clear standards about randomization, double-blind testing, etc. So while clinical trials do technically only show correlation, they at least can tell us if what we see is not just mere coincidence (when done properly even with a defined significance). 2b.) The gun control experiment seems completely impossible in real life. Scientists can't just go to cities and say "Hey, please flip this coin and if it comes up heads outlaw concealed carry." So the idea that this can be done in a randomized fashion is completely unrealistic. Also a living, breathing city has way more uncontrolled variables than a person in a clinical trial.  So when presented with (technically incomplete) aggregated correlation data and asked to draw a conclusion about causation, a rational decision maker has to factor in other aspects, e.g. plausibility. The plausibility that the the skin creme example has been done in a proper controlled randomized clinical study and that the sampling was able to filter out all relevant confounders is high. But the opposite is true, for the gun control question. E.g. the assumption that a city which recently introduced gun control had an upward trend in gun crime as the trigger is more than rational.  So all the study shows is, that our political beliefs influence the implicit assumptions we need to draw conclusion from incomplete data. Not that revolutionary of a find tbh.

They may interpret data on neoliberal policies in ways that confirm their pre-existing beliefs or align with their professional interests. For instance, economists or policymakers with high analytical skills might emphasize benefits like GDP growth when assessing deregulation or tax cuts, while downplaying negative effects such as increased inequality or social disintegration. Thus, even highly skilled professionals may allow their analysis to be shaped by social and personal economic incentives, rather than purely objective evidence, when evaluating public policies.
0:47 I think the skin cream made the rash better. Let's say those numbers indicate units of rash.  The cream decreased the total amount of rash in the population by 223 units and increased it by 75 units. This is a net decrease of 148 units.  Applying no cream decreased the total amount of rash in the population by 107 units and increased it by 21 units. This is a net decrease of 86 units.  148 is greater than 86. Therefore, using the cream made the rash better for the population than not using the cream.

I shared this video and discussed it for a bit, and I find the methodology and overall message of this video to be deeply flawed. Something like skin creme is very easily a scientific endeavor; you can do something or you can not do something. This is not analogous whatsoever to comparing 2 distinct policy styles. There is no "do nothing" in that comparison. Additionally, this 2x2 table is deeply insufficient for even trying to represent such a scenario, I suspect a more accurate visualization would be some kind of graph where the X axis is "how strict gun laws are prior", Y axis is "delta of gun law modifications", and the Z axis (or just datapoint coloring) would be "how much was crime rate affected". Without containing at least that much information, the data presented is deeply incomplete and MUST have gaps filled by personal bias. For example: "We saw a majority of pro gun control cities decrease in crime, and the reason that the overall rate of cities decreasing was lower is because they were from areas predisposed to higher crime in the first place" I don't think such a reaction is anything but expected, and arguably correct.  Even the final message of this video I don't think is necessarily correct (the idea of utilizing bipartisan experts to create some kind of unbiased conclusion). Bipartisan doesn't mean neutral, it just means extreme in both ways. I might also point out that this same "reach across the aisle" rhetoric is something that ONLY democrats partake in, and its largely to the detriment of the party and its policies. While its obviously and undeniably a good thing to have an unbiased view of evidence and reality to come to correct conclusions, it is NOT a solution to put a 50% weight on an uncompromising fear mongering machine.

Both sides fail to account that criminalizing possession raises the crime rates even if no other crime has been committed. Stricter laws = more crime. Looser laws = less crime.  If we made it illegal to own a hammer, it wouldn't reduce the amount of hammers in supply or reduce the demand for hammers. The way to understand this is through Bayesian statistics. In Bayesian statistics the reasonable outcome of taking in some evidence does not only depend on that singular piece of evidence but also a bias in terms of how likely something is in the first place. This makes sense statistically, because we kind of join each piece of evidence we have seen and weight them all together rather than only the lastest thing we have seen. If we have seen 100 papers on how suger is bad for your health and then you see one new one that conclude that it is good, then when weighting it all together it does indicate that it is still mostly bad, but there might be specific cases that it is good or that one of those that got it to be good was just hit by a statistical annomaly which you would expect to show up eventually when you have enough papers on a topic.  For the cases shown here we have certain preconceived notions that come from what we perceive as prior seen evidence, and what you could especially see in the shown interviews were that when people find something that goes against that bias they have from prior experiences they do not quite believe it, simply because it has yet to truely show itself to be statistically significant in terms of the experiences they have. We especially see people who talk about wanting to go in and take an extra detailed look at the details that could have lead to such a statistical anomaly. It actually even makes sense in terms of trying to become conviced of something else, because the amount of weight we can logically put to each piece of evidence depends on how reliable that piece of evidence is, and by taking a deeper look at something and not finding faults it gains higher weight. In other words such an action either results in finding it within the statistical errors expected and as such not a need for concern or it will try to put more weight on such a piece of evidence and as such make it facilitate a bigger move in the bias as it now more trustworthy.  If one is too easily swayed by some evidence, then it is way too easy to scam someone into believing something problematic, as you effectively just need to deliver the last piece of evidence, or in other words just need the last word in a debate. On the other hand if you are too hard to sway you can simply stay too long with beliefs that have been shown to not hold true. We see this from some parts of how propaganda works, where you just need something that sounds convincing on the surface to sway the easily swayed, while you just need to repeat things enough without allowing for counterpoints for those that are hard to sway to be locked into one set of belief.  In reality the main flaws that things like failures with logic around politics and propaganda comes down to are a combination of poorly testable belief systems, enough repetitions of the same thing which really should not be counted again and again, and people assigning weight to the evidence they see in a rather poor manner, as it is typically largely based around trust and that trust can easily be placed for all the wrong reasons and itself also pose an extra bias, such as you liking a candidate more because they speak to your current bias, which makes you trust them because of that resonance, and then they claim things which you put some measure of trust in based on that, even though that claim by itself should have not held very highly based on what evidence it was supported by.

Well, looking at ‚Äúwhich number is biggest‚Äù does not seem like a particularly intelligent way of approaching a problem‚Ä¶ You keep calling that ‚Äúintuitively correct,‚Äù but I think that‚Äôs BS. It makes no sense. You‚Äôre presenting groups of different sizes, so it‚Äôs like comparing apples and oranges and expecting a sensible result without accounting for that difference. You obviously have to look at the ratios and compare THOSE between the two groups. And it‚Äôs not that the cream ‚Äúon average made rashes worse.‚Äù The correct terminology is that the probability of the rash getting worse was higher for the group using the cream. Plenty of people used it and had their rash get better‚Ä¶ but based on the  ratio of improvement vs worsening, it seems likely that their rashes got better IN SPITE OF the cream, not because of it! üòÇ  And the gun control version of the question, people are clearly answering based on ideology. I'd argue that in the gun crime variation, the decreased "success rate" can't be completely blamed on political beliefs preventing objective thinking.  There are two more problems:   1: Distrust in studies about politically charged topics. There are too many cases of studies or their outcomes being manipulated, and that makes people distrust studies that go against one's personal perception of facts and logic.   Yes, you can argue that this just tries to excuse the behavior discussed here, but I would argue that it goes both ways: some ignore inconvenient data and claim it is biased, while some studies really are biased and try to deflect with "people just don't want to see the truth.  But there's a bigger issue with this particular experiment...  2: the numbers make a lot less sense in the gun variation than in the cream variation!  The cream variation sounds quite straightforward. Rash got better or worse.  But with the gun variation, it's not as easy: how much better did it get in each city? How much worse? Were there other changes in those cities that could explain the changes?  We tend to assume that other factors were controlled in the cream study. That it was some sort of clinical trial. No participant was likely to have moved into an area with much more poison ivy around (or if they did, they'd be excluded from the trial)  But did the gun control study monitor different factors? Like significant changes in the city's population numbers or a economic downturn?  And how much did the crime numbers change in each case? If there were 800 cases compared to 795 the last year, is that considered as a worsening? Does it count the same as a city that went from 800 to 2100?  When the numbers don't seem meaningful, they probably won't be considered in the argumentations (and, of course, this also ties into the previous point).

I presume the original study was done properly. The data in the video are incomplete and ambiguous, probably intentionally to confuse people on the street. To give an answer on the street, you must assume the number of people in each group. The people on the street naturally assumed the groups were equal in number, they assumed you weren't trying to mislead them.  The better way to phrase the question:  cream group total of 298 people, 223 got better, 75 got worse. No cream group total was 128, 107 got better, 21 got worse.  I had to assume there was no participants where the rash did not change, other wise my totals are incorrect. For example the total of each group might have be 10,000, then I would safely assume that cream had little to no significant effect on the rash (i.e roughly 2% vs 1%).

I have heard of this issue for years now and I think it is important point. That said; One of the glaring fallacies here is similar to the fallacy of Polls. Further they are not only evaluating the numbers they are evaluating the pollster /researcher at the same time.  In the moment as presented in this study it takes only a spilt second to accept confirmation of a long-held opinion. The logical fallacy presented is in fact a numeracy fallacy. The study itself has an unstated assumption that numerical data alone tells a story & reveals causality when there is greater variability in one example. The example of skin cream has very little room for error and argument, because one person's daily hygiene routines are very unlikely to change with the adaption of a skin cream for medical treatment. Therefore, the primary cause of the data is the hand cream. We practice medicine as a science because it has predictable causes and effects for established medicine.  On the other hand, a crime statistic is one with much greater variability that has to do with how crime statistics are reported, socioeconomic factors, pre-existing policies, cultures and perspectives around guns, law enforcement, district attorneys, and so much more. It requires much deeper argument to link gun policy to crime statistics. That is why we should be having dialogue about policy opinions, and policy is not a scientific practice but one of argumentation, opinion, and compromise.  If anything, this study is showing that the people understand gun policy is a much more multifaceted issue than skin cream medication, and we should be encouraging dialogue and compromise instead of staying in echo chambers. People who are shying away from policy discussions are unconsciously dividing the people further, and stalling any possible real change. This interpretation of the study is more consistent with long-standing psychological research that intelligence is a measurable and orthogonal trait in humans: people with low numeracy likely have a low IQ and are less likely to re-interpret the data based on circumstance; people with high numeracy likely have a higher IQ and are more likely to re-interpret the data based on the new circumstance, and therefore change their interpretations.  Edit: Your fallacy in the making of this video is that "rational thought" interprets evidence the same way. How you interpret evidence is just as important as what the evidence is. Studies are open to critique in its methodology and its analysis for this reason. You state how you set up your experiment, what your observations were during this setup, and how you make meaning out of those observations, and see if other people interpret it the same way based on what they know, or in the political landscape, what their life experiences are.

The question of the hand cream doesn't translate equivalently when swapped to gun control.  In the question of the hand cream, all of the test subjects supposedly had rashes to begin with, so you could properly compare the effect of applying the hand cream or not applying the cream.  In the question of gun control, you can't assume all of the people in a society are would-be criminals or would-be innocents, so you can't really measure the impact of the gun control in the same way.  And also the data is presented in a confusing way.  What does it even mean to say crimes both increased and decreased by some amount when implementing or undoing gun control?  I would probably look at that data and think it was presented in a way to try to deceive me, and I would then take the "crimes increased" number minus the "crimes decreased" to try to figure out the actual overall change in number of crimes and take whichever number of "overall crimes" was lowest to be the one that reduced crime more, and I would be skeptical of the data presented in such a confusing way regardless so it wouldn't convince me either way.

Hold on. Why is the conclusion that this result is down to some irrational motivation like tribalism? This question engages a person's rational, deliberative thinking, so there's likely a rational (from the person's perspective) reason for the change. The more straightforward reasoning here is that people perceived an apparent partisan implication in the result and distrust the interviewer as a partisan agent or working on behalf of a partisan agent as a result. In other words, it sounds more like the more people perceive an apparent partisan agenda in scientific data, the more likely they are to distrust it. That's the problem of a polarized political enviroment where any benal factoid can be turned into a partisan issue and suddenly no one can agree on what a fact even is.

At the risk of incidentally proving it somehow, I think this video's thesis is pretty weak, because the paper it's based on is pretty weak. I think that both are trying to avoid some conclusions that would be inconvenient for certain sections of the audience for self-interested reasons.  1) The survey was administered online, and includes the prompt for the control, but not the experiment, which is paraphrased. As we saw in the video, the people interviewed would often be able to correctly interpret the data, but would tell you that the data is flawed somehow. That's a subtlety that a live interviewer might be able to code but that can't be captured in an online survey. I want to share what was presented verbatim next to the selection buttons for the control (because again, we don't have the experimental prompt): "People who used the skin cream were more likely to [get better/get worse] than those who didn't." While the instructions ask you to consider the study, they don't take pains to emphasize you should ONLY consider the study, nor is that caveat included in the participant responses. I'd hypothesize three regimes as you ascend in numeracy that explain the effect: low numeracy individuals don't know how to interpret the data, medium numeracy individuals interpret the data correctly but reject the conclusion, and high numeracy individuals figure out the "trick" of the study and respond accordingly.  2) The control *also* shows dips in the middle numeracy curve of a magnitude comparable to the experiment. Either the effect isn't significant or they've got problems in how they're examining people's numeracy.  3) The conclusion here is that all sides need to depolarize for effective communication, as though all sides equally fall victim to this effect.  Notice how they don't graph the difference in how each group responds based on if the stimulus aligns/does not align with their priors; they throw all four lines of the 2x2 up and let you sort it out. When you do look at these differences, you see *conservatives are much, much more likely* to respond in the manner that aligns with their worldview. The implications of THAT are what we should be considering, not this spurious notion that intelligence is to blame.  In sum, they've taken great pains to pull a weak conclusion from the data in a way that I feel does a poor job explaining the causes of motivated reasoning to the audience. We know that conservatives are substantially more likely to engage in motivated reasoning, and any examination of this effect that avoids talking about this is fundamentally unserious.

I think the takeaway shown here is misattributing the cause of how people with high numeracy scores look at things. It's not that people with high numeracy suddenly throw that out the door when it comes to political topics. It's that political topics are social by nature and thus less predictable. People with high numeracy scores are going to typically be more intelligent and understand that social studies aren't as predictable as "hard sciences" and math. You can't change one variable in a complex ecosystem and think everything else will stay the same.   If you showed me a gun control "study" with such low numbers and didn't get into the details, I'm immediately thinking it is BS,. Then I immediately start thinking outside of the context of the "study." The R^2 of any particular independent variable just isn't going to be high in social studies. The skin studies don't have this issue. And, I still don't see how you could possibly word them in a way that puts me in the same scientific state of mind. Was it a county with no gun control and you see gun crimes vs something else, then gun control is enacted and you see new numbers? Well, then the gross numbers mean something too. It's not a series of independent small trials as it is with the skin conditions. Or, do you give people guns that didn't have them and then see which ones commit gun crimes, compared to those without guns that commit gun crimes? It's still weird and then I wonder what the hell is going on with such high ratios. The idea that rational thinking is "evidence-based" is a misunderstanding of what reason is, and what evidence is. Reason is "explanation-based". Evidence isn't persuasive, not because people are irrational, but because just citing "evidence" doesn't actually offer a new explanation. Evidence comes into play only once two rival explanations agree on what a given piece of evidence means.   This is how we're taught the scientific method at school. The hypothesis comes first. It's actually rational to reject evidence that contradicts a good explanation, when there's no better rival explanation. When some physicists thought they'd measured particles going faster than light, but had no theory of how or why, the correct response was to treat it as an error. Which it was.

It's not the only difference. Gun control is not a political matter as much as it is a matter of realism; nowhere in the world exists a country as rich as the US with as much violent (gun) crime. Nowhere. All countries with comparable wealth and systems have enacted far more widespread gun control measures, and in top of that most have a gun-culture centered around safety, not insanity, as in the US. The issue with presenting data that shows an _increase_ in gun crime upon greater regulation is that it is entirely nonsensical - only if you refuse to actually uphold regulation about gun ownership could the result from auch regulation ever be an increase. It is an irrational question to pose, and not comparable to the skin cream example, because with the skin cream example, the fundamental assumption does not necessarily lean towards one solution. A skincare product in trial can reasonably both be helpful or harmful. Gun control as enacted _in nearly every other western democracy but the US_ is fundamentally a reason for why there isn't the same amount of gun violence in those other countries.
There is a big flaw in the this study though, in the first example with the skin cream you are looking at people who generally have the same amount of literacy on the topic and generally low levels of interest. So that should average out people that just want a quick answer and those that want to look in detail and find the RIGHT answer. Where as in politics people often have more information "their sides info" and a general interest in the subject matter. So rather than a tribal bias you can just as easily be measuring I have a interest in the topic and thus I will pay more attention to get the right data and use this data to justify the personized knowledge they have on the topic right or wrong.  Do the same experiment with the subject being AC power VS DC power being more or less dangerous, general people will likely mirror the first study. Is the gun control one not just a trick question..? A rash is a rash, it is a specific reaction of the skin becoming inflamed, but crime is not just a singular crime, it's an umbrella of many things that break the law, many of which have no relation to guns. A study that vague would be akin to using people without rashes in the rash cream study.
If you calculate the p-value for the effect using the Fischer Exact test you get p = 0.0574, which is not significant.  The skin cream/gun laws cannot be said to have either helped or hurt, because the chance that the effect size could be observed by chance is greater than 1/20. Put that in your pipe and smoke it!   (Note that a chi-squared test is significant (barely), but is not very accurate for small sample sizes like this. The exact test is better.)

The cream study chart is an objectively bad chart. It doesn't say how many were in the control or in the tested group, so you don't know if the chart is showing all the data or if there is a large chunk that it didn't affect at all. Are the control and test groups of this study the same size or are all the results on the chart.  It also had no relative scale of how much it improved vs got worse so it could be just slightly worse or got to perfect health. It also did not use a control of a placebo cream that should have no effect.  If a person is reactive to all creams even placebo creams then their skin is very sensitive so a cream-based solution is less likely to be recommended to a patient like that, as a result, when used in the field, the cream could be more likely to work if it is only applied to people with less sensitive skin. One of my favourite parallels to this is the plastic bag problem. We've been told that plastic = bad, so grocery stores have replaced plastic bags with more eco-friendly reusable fabric bags. Problem is, plastic bags are extremely easy to manufacture and don't emit much carbon per unit, whereas fabric bags require a much more intensive manufacturing process and produce more carbon in (almost?) every step of the product life cycle, including transportation because they're heavier. Some of the cheaper fabric bags are being thrown out after a single use as well, which defeats the purpose of reducing waste to landfills. It's not political, but because plastic has been painted in a negative light for the past several years, we've created a biased viewpoint and either brush aside or are unaware of the numbers that support plastic bags.  That's not to say plastic bags are the best case scenario. At the end of the day, bringing your own multipurpose bag to the grocery store is still the best way to reduce your carbon footprint and the amount of waste you contribute.

Ironically the guy who answered the question with "well it depends on how guns were used and the resulting outcomes" was the most accurate, because he's saying that "the results of a study cannot always be determined based upon the statistics alone, there may be more variables that determine causal factors". It's nuance and ability to question science that is the most useful, and also highly problematic in science communication. We cite studies, we quote outcomes and take things as hard truth, yet we hear another explanation, and another perspective, and suddenly fact seems dubious.   This is the problem of human reasoning--we want to be right and be right quickly. Truth takes time and nuance and a lot of work to build certainty. If there's a takeaway: be wary of fast answers and easy reasoning, if something seems obvious, ask more questions. Further--it's okay to accept things, but it's more important to be open to change and to listen to new evidence and ideas.

The trouble with the data-driven approach is that, while it may be "rational" and "analytical" (some would claim "scientific"), it is driven by mere data. What part of you decides (rationally) about an issue only by considering the data you have? Even worse, the data from just one study, or what you're presented with at the time? What part of you takes into consideration the questions: "What am I missing? What other factors need to be brought into the issue? What is knowable, and what is not?" We also have an intuitive sense. Some would say that nature tends not to be wasteful, and that intuition serves a purpose. It is clearly not always correct, but it does serve to warn us against making a decision that seems rational at the time, but causing us to hesitate because of that sense that something "doesn't fit". There is much more to rationality than mere reasoning, mere logic, mere data. Those have value, as tools, but they are rarely the whole story in life. Consider what would happen to our knowledge of chemistry if we examined only the elements. Wouldn't the purity of that approach yield all you would need? But of course, we can see quite readily that  it would miss enormous considerations. Every set of data is like an element. The next step in reasoning must be towards its context.

OK, so the test is not the same between the skin cream and the gun control example. In the skin cream example, you can likely conclude that the propensity to select for a cream or not is likely independent(ish) of the effectiveness of the cream. In the case of gun control, that's likely not the case. Whether a city ops for gun control tells you a lot about the city and confounding variables that might influence the effectiveness of the measure, such as other programs the city might run that influence gun crime. This is why medical studies assign treatment groups at random, and why post hoc studies in the social sciences are so dicey. In the cream example, you have a priori reasons to think the effect of this bias will be small, but in the gun control example it definitely is not going to be small. The gun control example is exactly the kind of bad study from the social sciences that does post hoc analysis and shows a low p-value for a Chi Squared test and calls it a day. This is the reproducibility crisis in the social sciences in action!
Lies, damned lies, and statistics. People don't trust data if it contradicts their views about something they find important. They feel that way for good reason. Consider the recent story about a doctor that wouldn't publish the findings of a study that recorded no benefit to puberty blockers for the mental health of transgender kids. If data can be created/withheld with bias, then it will be consumed/discarded with bias.

I found it strange that the chi-squared test was not mentioned in this video, because those ratios might be inconclusive when the numbers are not large enough (statistically speaking). TL;DR I did the test, and the association is there at 4.7% type-I error, so Derek isn't wrong. However, let's take an example to illustrate my point: if we change only one number in the table at 0:55 to get 223 & 75 \\ 84 & 21, Derek's ratios will still suggest that the cream is making the rash worse (3x vs 4x), but suddenly there is a 28.5% error associated with that claim!

I think an important point is being missed:  judging an ideology as "right" or "wrong" solely based on certain numeric outcomes can miss critical moral or ethical distinctions. Sometimes, an ideology remains 'right' by its own standards, even if it leads to outcomes that appear "worse" by purely material or numerical metrics.  For instance, imagine it were proven beyond any doubt that randomly enslaving 1% of the population at birth would lead to a 50% improvement in the economic conditions of everyone else. Most of us would still agree that no amount of economic benefit could justify the immorality of slavery. While that's an extreme example, these value conflicts surface in numerous ways in society.  For those who value individual freedom, any scenario involving guaranteed safety or improvement for a group at the cost of severe restrictions on individual liberty is ethically unacceptable. Some argue that personal privacy should be protected even if sacrificing it could lead to greater public safety.  Meanwhile, proponents of more collectivist or utilitarian ideologies might argue that sacrificing individual rights for the collective good can be justified under certain conditions.  These examples highlight that an ideology's values‚Äîsuch as freedom, equality, or the common good‚Äîoften extend logically and reasonably beyond what outcomes or numbers alone can convey. It‚Äôs a reminder that metrics and data, while important, are often manipulated to fit pre-existing ideological frameworks. The underlying values, rather than just the numbers, ultimately shape what any group considers acceptable or "right." Recognizing this is crucial if we are to have an honest discussion about the true reasons behind ideological divides.

Hold on. HOLD ON.  The two examples are NOT the same. In one people are assigned into two experimental groups. In another cities are split into two groups based on their *pre-existing decision* on gun legislation.  These are two FUNDAMENTALLY different sampling processes. The city example would be like taking a group of people and splitting them by skin cream usage. Whether or not they used cream would clearly be related to the nature of their rash so you would not be able to reason reliably from that kind of skin cream data. Perhaps the cream users rashes got worse because they had worse rashes to begin with! The high intelligence people on both sides of the political divide are actually correct - the city example is essentially meaningless without an understanding of how the decision to enact gun control policy came about.
The reason why accepting the group belief as your own belief is not rational is because it is a unconscious factor which plays of off fear and other worries and insecurities. It does not enter into the equation when people think, it just pushes people in that direction like an invisible force, that's how the unconscious works when left to its own devices like that.   It is logical as a decision to accept the group belief with survival as the primary goal in mind, but it's not a given either. You could think of hypotheticals where not telling the actual truth of the situation to the group, puts the entire group in danger long term, but secures your place in it short term, like with the discovery of something threatening which people wouldn't believe you on. So you could then also say that this level of decision making is more primal/instinctive, since it deals with survival. Maybe not so coincidentally, the subconscious governs instincts, worth noting.

For the most part, we make judgments based on intuition and then use reason to craft post-hoc explanations.  The smarter a person is, the better they tend to be at post-hoc rationalization but not necessarily at reasoning impartially toward a conclusion.  The problem is less pronounced when we don't have a strong intuitive investment in the outcome (e.g. whether a skin cream works).

I'd link the study if YouTube allowed it, but it turns out that Critical Thinking skills only loosely correlate with intelligence or schooling. This is because Critical Thinking skills are learned, not inherent, and schools are BAD at teaching it.  The most fundamental basis of Critical Thinking is the ability to approach a problem without preconceived notions, and learning to do this in the real world is a matter of building a habit so that you are always prepared to accept new data, rather than fall back on existing knowledge. Without that, people try to make the world fit into their preexisting framework (see: cognitive dissonance, confirmation bias, etc.)  Point being, this is an education issue more than anything else.
