Analysis of Democratic Party Bias in the Video:  1. Topic Selection Bias: - The video focuses on two politically charged issues: gun control and climate change - Both issues are traditionally Democratic Party priorities - Notably absent are key Republican concerns such as:   * Immigration policy   * Tax policy   * Religious freedom   * Abortion rights  2. Framing Bias: - In presenting the gun control issue, the Democratic position is framed more positively ("reduces crime") - The Republican position is somewhat oversimplified - The Florida sea-level rise example implicitly accepts climate change as fact, aligning with Democratic Party positions  3. Solution Bias: - The suggested solutions lean towards Democratic Party approaches - The example of successful bipartisan cooperation focuses on climate adaptation measures - The recommendation to avoid partisan terminology uses "climate change" as an example, which itself is a Democrat-preferred term  While the video attempts to maintain objectivity in its presentation of cognitive bias across political lines, its choice of examples and framing reveals an underlying Democratic Party bias. This bias might be unconscious but reflects the creator's own political leanings in the selection and presentation of content.

Sorry but I think this is more about confirmation bias in political topics, with some distrust of people presenting political data thrown in, than it is about "tribalism". Not saying tribalism isn't an issue though.   From what I've seen the main way tribalism rears its head is lack of dissent. If a topic is controversial in my social circle, the main thing I see is a group of rational people simply staying quiet to avoid criticism. When I ask them privately I often find out they're quiet because they don't want to piss people off. It's not that they've molded their views to the norm. (Though I'm sure it can shift them over the years.)  In my experience, smart people often do have independent views, but they're also socially aware enough not to share them if it will have a negative impact. Now confirmation bias when looking at data... that is certainly a thing among smarter people. And it's also not surprising that it would be more of a thing. I developed my views as a young intellectual looking at the data, and got very used to being right. So now as a middle-aged person, if I'm not very careful, I tend to assume that I'm still right regardless of the data. It takes active effort to avoid this convenient energy-saving approach.  So to summarize: interesting data, but I'm not sure you're drawing the most accurate conclusions from it. There's a little more nuance here.

@7:15 - "The only difference is the context"... I don't think that's true... In the skin cream example, it's an unknown skin cream. You don't know the ingredients. All you know about this topic is what the question presented you with - it's fresh information about an unknown topic. In the gun control context, you have a lifetime of looking at statistics and hearing 'evidence' outside of this fake study. It's not "the only thing that's different". It would be like saying "Smoking increases risk of cancer, or Smoking decreases the risk of cancer." with those same numbers... We have a lifetime of data in our heads about this topic - so no study is going to tell me that smoking is all of a sudden not causing cancer - especially when it's N is <500 people.  Repetition error is probably a big problem here... You hear a belief over and over, you'll be more likely to believe it to be true regardless of if it is true.
Thinking a bit about this study I think the numbers in the fake studies makes quite a bit *less* sense for the possible outcome of a change in gun control policy than they do as the outcome of using a creme for a rash or not.   Why? Well a rash is expected to change by itself over the time of the study. Either time heals, so even no treatment other than waiting could be expected to have some positive result. Or, probably less likely, but depending on the type of rash and when the study started tracking each patient, it could be expected for a rash to grow worse without treatment. But for the control group of cities that did not have any change in gun legislation, wouldn't they be expected to be an about 50-50 split between "more crime" or "less crime" as nothing there changed. That is, unless there was some *other* factor that that also affected the crime rate in the control group. But if that other factor was strong enough that crime went in one direction over the other about 5 times out of 6, then that means that asking "Did crime go up or down?" would be a horrible question for a study to look at. "Did crime here increase more than the nation's average?" or better yet, "How *much* did crime rate increase or decrease in this city?" are questions that could make sense.Or *at* *least* add in a third category for "Pretty much no change in crime rate here".   Yes, I understand that I'm sort of criticizing the methodology of a *fictional* study here. But this difference between how reasonable outcomes were for a study on a skin rash and for one on gun control *could* also have an effect on the thing the study was trying to measure, the political bias. Because data that doesn't make sense *could* be harder to interpret, especially for participants who scored high on numeracy. I do get that they needed to keep the complexity down for the fake studies to make questions that people could answer though, so adding two more numbers for "No change" to the examples for might not have been a good option. But I do think it would have been better to make up some numbers that made sense for *both* the political and non-political questions.

To be fair, the study isn't statistically conclusive. In the skin cream example, the bottom graph is only 11 cases off of having the same proportion as the top group. That's not a lot of cases. The numbers don't prove that the skin cream makes the rashes worse or better. What you can conclude however is that the skin cream doesn't work or provide a significant enough change to warrant its application. But you cannot conclude that it has  a positive or negative effect. That's why people were able to input their biases into the study when applied to something they care about. It's because the actual answer for the study is that the dataset is too sparse to conclude anything besides the fact that the change (whether skin cream, gun control, of whatever else you want) doesn't work.    This video makes it sound like if you reverse the numbers you can arrive at different conclusions: That the first set shows the skin care had a negative effect and the reversed order that it has a positive effect. But the real answer should be, in both cases, the skin care had very little effect on the outcome, regardless if the direction was slightly positive or negative

Seems like just a dumb trick question honestly.  If we assume 298 people in each group the control and the cream group.  Then 107 improved in the control, vs 21 worsened, vs 170 had no improvement and no worsening.  Then the cream group has 223 improved,  75 worsened, and 0 had no change.   So 54 worse than the control and 116 improved over the control group for a net gain of 62 improved over the control.    If on the other hand the whole point is to try and claim that the cream group had 298 participants and the control group only had 128 participants, then it should be stated in the question.   Without any other data, I think it's normal to assume the control and experimental group have the same number of participants, otherwise it would need to be stated, as it's a critical piece of information in any study.  Basically it's a stupid trick question that people get wrong because they make the perfectly reasonable assumption that the control group is the same size as the experimental group.

Knowledge is a pyramid, you cannot accept a new truth that contradicts the entire foundation you have built in your mind, you need to remove the stones and replace them with new ones that match the new piece.  The phenomenon observed in the video has nothing to do with the political context (except for the fact that when it comes to politics, everyone thinks they are an expert), but rather with having prior knowledge about the subject in the experiment.  If the first experiment were done with skin care experts, they would also have difficulty accepting data that contradicted their beliefs, because it would mean discarding several foundation stones of their knowledge pyramid.  Random people have almost no foundation on the subject, so it is easier for them to absorb the information.

Unequal group sizes can really mess with the interpretation of results. When one group is way bigger than the other, it can actually skew the data‚Äîeither by amplifying or diluting the effects you're trying to measure. This can lead to misinterpretation if you're not careful.  Plus, with unequal sizes, you need to be cautious even when using percentages to balance things out. Sometimes, normalizing the data or looking deeper into the results is necessary to get a clearer picture.

8:20 This actually has nothing to do with the political context, but rather with having prior information on the subject.  If the first survey were conducted among skin care professionals, they would be quite skeptical of results that contradict their previous beliefs on the subject, because they believed that they were well-founded and tested.  This actually happens frequently in the scientific community; all old knowledge that has already been extensively tested takes precedence over new data that contradicts it, no matter how valid and well-structured it may be. It takes time and several tests to digest the "new truth".  The real phenomenon that should have been highlighted by the video is how when we enter a political context, suddenly everyone is an expert. People trust their sources and repeat what they say as if it were proven academic knowledge, and the fact that this happens to both sides turns it into a question of faith and alliance.

I think this is a product of how smarter people (at least attempt to) view these questions with a lot more nuance and greater context when it comes to political issues that they are informed about.  With the skin cream examples, most participants who are not dermatologists have nothing but the numbers in front of them to go off of when evaluating the effectiveness, but for most political issues (gun control included) many people have plenty of opinions or data that they have internalized ahead of time. This can be controlled for by being very careful with the presentation of the question, for instance, specifying that the participants should make their judgment solely based on the numbers presented, rather than any data or analysis that they had been previously exposed to.  I think the most productive solutions to the political polarization that you see around these issues comes from mutual discussion and sharing studies, methodologies, information, and ideas openly and honestly. I don't think being political is the only difference between these examples. By virtue of being political, it will have been discussed and researched by many on both sides. They will have been presented with arguments for why numbers that seem to point one way will point in a different way. And those arguments aren't necessarily wrong! When you ask "did the treatment improve/worsen the condition?", you are asking for an interpretation of the data, which means accounting for things like lurking variables and random variation -- this is what the guy at 6:36 is getting at. As a result, people necessarily will bring in other information they have about the world and the situation to adjust for this. Unfortunately, that prior information is biased, and so the conclusion will reflect that bias. But when you ask the same question about skin cream, people don't care, haven't done their research, and so they fall back on the similar but distinct questions "which treatment group has a higher proportion of improving/worsening the condition?", which is an objective numbers game.  The real thing here is that people forget that statistics can lie, until they're being used to present an argument you disagree with.
Derek I have to say I'm a bit disappointed you used the common terminology that considers Republicans "Conservative" and Democrats "Liberal", when the ideological opposite of "Liberal" is "Illiberal", and the ideological opposite of "Conservative" is "Progressive". Up until the GOP's recent tack towards illiberal authoritarianism, there were just as many liberal conservatives as there were liberal progressives, often referred to as "moderates" because Liberalism implies that no opinion is technically correct and differences of opinion are to be respected, those who espouse contrary opinions to yours are not to be dehumanized or charged with attempting to cause harm simply because of their beliefs. I believe that the loss of understanding of what the term liberal means is why democracy is on the decline here and abroad. I wish you would do everything in your power to refuse to use the term liberal to refer to anything other than the philosophical definition of it, and reject the conflation of liberal with progressive wherever you can. Liberalism is the founding principle of this country and our democracy, but the term has been co-opted for political purposes and is being distorted to lose its meaning. I think we are living through the consequence of this right now. Nobody, neither hardcore MAGA supporters nor impassioned progressive activists seem to remember what liberalism actually means, and the false dichotomy between liberal and conservative is to blame.   Gun controls like background checks are acceptable to a liberal, because they involve asking if each individual is capable of handling the freedom responsibly, and if insufficient evidence is found to show they aren't, then it defaults to allowing them the right. But the "we should ban all guns" crowd are espousing illiberal ideology - that "if I cannot understand why you want to have a thing/do an activity/hold a belief, then I choose not to respect your right to do so when a handful of others may use that right to cause harm".   A progressive might see a "pro-life" advocate arguing that women are obligated to be mothers and react strongly, condemning the entire notion as a tool of the patriarchy and decrying that person as a selfish, misogynist bigot. A liberal will simply respond with "it is your right to have that opinion, and it is the right of others to reject that opinion". The liberal isn't bothered that some people think how they live is wrong, they only are concerned with preventing the government from becoming a tool that allows some to impose their beliefs onto others, or to interfere with their decision making process such that they can't follow their own individual moral compass.  Liberalism means accepting that, when in doubt, we put the individual liberty first, and we care about the means, rather than just the methods, of improving society. (sidenote, libertarianism is just liberalism blended with a stubborn refusal that there is no forest, only trees, aka there are no collective problems only individual problems. Its liberalism with blinders on.). A liberal knows you don't need to make owning a gun illegal, you just need to make using it in a dangerous way illegal. Yes - a life may have been spared if this person who had a gun was prevented from having a gun by a blanket law banning all guns. But per liberal calculus, you are not allowed to weigh the value of a life against the privileges of millions. They are measured in different units and are incomparable, and no objective result can be obtained from the comparison. If a bad thing is happening (deaths from gun violence) and there's a way to stop it (banning civilian gun ownership) that does not first ask if the people being affected by the prevention are all contributing to the problem, then it is neither acceptable to implement that solution, nor is it acceptable to ignore the problem the solution is trying to solve. The Liberal response must be to insist there must be another solution to the problem, and to assert that, even if the other solution is less absolutely effective, it is still correct.   The core problem of governance is that every law and ruling has unintended effects. Every single law or ruling hurts some people and helps others. The goal with governance should not be to eliminate the problems we face, because as you try to stomp out problems in society with extreme prejudice, the bootprints are the nucleation site for new problems. The true goal when putting forward new legislation or enacting a new policy must be to create as few new problems for people as possible, so even if the solution isn't complete in its mission, it is the best solution for not creating new problems. If all we ever do is beat our own drums and ignore the problems that other Americans are having with our solutions, then it just becomes an oscillating pattern of outrage.

Sorry, but the gun control question *is not* the same question as the skin cream question contrary to your claim at 7:00.  In the skin cream question, the patients who receive skin cream are chosen randomly.  Random selection is a kind of intervention.  Interventions block the action of ùëêùëúùëõùëìùëúùë¢ùëõùëëùëíùëüùë†.  In the gun control question, the cities are merely observed to have enacted legislation.  Observation does not block confounders.  Therefore, the people answering are rightly injecting the effect of confounders based on their subjective knowledge.  If you wanted to fix your experiment, you should word it something like: "We chose random cities and forced them to enact gun control legislation.  This is what we observed.  Did gun control increase crime?"  The keywords here are "random" and "forced".  This is the basis of a randomized control trial, which is the most basic experimental setup for causal identification.

Actually for the skin cream question you can't just look at proportion. You have to do a chi square in order to say whether the difference is due to statistical fluctuation.  Moreover the gun crime question is different from the skin cream one because the skin cream data presumably is from a controlled experiment like a clinical trial. The gun question data are observational and many factors might not be controlled for. The populations might be different in other ways than captured in a crosstab. That is never the correct way for that kind of investigation where many factors might be relevant.

I've done research in this area (numeracy and decision-making) and I would argue to take some of these studies and their results with a grain of salt. That isn't to say you should assume the studies or the results to be wrong or meaningless, but a number of the primary current numeracy researchers and researchers like Ellen Peters (second author on the paper referenced) and Ed Cokely (big numeracy guy) have a pretty strong bias in favor of their pet hypotheses and theories (they aren't unique in this, I've just been around it being in the same field). They really push to make their results seem more counter-intuitive and buzzworthy than it often deserves. Many of them also receive way way way more grant funding than the average researcher and thus have a greater than average financial incentive to publish attention-grabbing research like this.  Again, I'm not saying it's all wrong or implying it's fabricated, just maintain a healthy bit of skepticism.

The data used in this imaginary experiment was deliberately chosen to trigger spontaneous answers. Firstly, very different sample sizes were chosen for the experimental and control groups, making a direct comparison difficult. Secondly, a very strong difference between the two results (improved/deteriorated) was chosen in both groups, and prime numbers (223 and 107) were even used on the left-hand side to discourage probands from calculating the ratios in their heads accurately. They also only give two possible answers (whether the experiment showed that the skin condition of people treated with the cream was more likely to ‚Äúget better‚Äù or ‚Äúget worse.‚Äù) which may lead probands to think that the table must show a clear difference between the two groups. I also found no information on how much time the probands had to answer this question‚Ä¶ However, a look at the statistics shows that it is debatable whether there is a significant difference between the groups at all, as a normal chi-square test gives a p-value of p = 0.0472 and using the Yates correction, p > 0.05. Also the entire experimental setup is vague, controls missing, etc. So if I had to answer this question I would say that the experiment and data is not good enough to  make a statement about the creams effect on skin condition (even if you look at the results without a statistical test). As a side note, please never use the word ‚Äòsignificant‚Äô when you don't show results of statistical tests like at 1:42. I'd like to see what the trial results look like when you use more ‚Äònormal/scientific‚Äô data.

On the "people from opposing sides look like each other", you usually can find that wide differences of point of view can originate from a small difference in core beliefs/opinions.  If you take something as trivial as "life is hard therefore people should be rewarded for making the most out of it" as opposed to "life is hard therefore everyone should get some help for living a life that is less hard", you can build two very different views on the world based on the same observation that life is hard. Those views will both be mostly rational and make sense to people following them and the opposing reasoning will seem stupid, it all comes down to finding the difference in the basic predicates. the study used here is crappy to some extent. comparing cream and rashes with gun control and crimes is such a long shot. the variability between the two cases is just too different.  cream to rashes may have multiple variables at play, but those variables can be controlled to lessen its effect to the data like time of exposure to the sun, sweatiness, or the air condition inside the room you mostly stay in throughout the study. controlling these variables can normalize or skew the data gathered in the study.   on the other hand, political topics like gun control and crimes have other variables such as socio-economic status, discipline, law enforcement integrity, socio-political biases, and so on. these are variables that you CAN'T control. Hence, it's chaotic data and less consistency in agreement.   this better explains the result of the study: no matter how good you are in numeracy, you cannot predict too many variables in action at once.

The title is nonsense, and the supporting graph at 7:35 is nonsense. A drop from 100% to 90% is indeed a 10% drop. But a drop from 50% to 40% is a 20% drop, not a 10% drop. And a drop from 10% to 0% is 100% drop. We should measure drops by *ratio* , not by *difference* . Fortunately, other parts of the video are interesting.

The first time I encountered this phenomena, or similar, was that drama from a few years back when the White House press secretary was accused of posting a doctored video from a press conference. I'll try to keep it short but after not being able to see exactly what was doctored I ended up downloading the video, loading it into my video editor, and saw that it was just an encoding artifact which happened three times, at 42 frame intervals (frames 20, 21 and 22 were duplicates, then frames 62, 63 and 64 were duplicates, and then 104 and 105... frame 106 was when the video had actually been edited to show a slo mo replay).   News reports of this story from reputable news sources, some with interviews with "digital media experts" all said pretty much the same thing: "the video HAS been doctored and it is not an encoding artifact because if it was you'd expect to see the same glitch at regular intervals". I guess the people with the expertise to look for the truth just didn't want to override their political desires or assumptions. I remember trying to make people aware of the truth but nobody was interested - at least not in the left-leaning online spaces I usually inhabit.

Classic case of reasoning fallacy
Up and coming electrical engineer here with a minor in math. I'd say that if you are smarter, in this context, that means that you use mathematical operations to explain the behavior of the statistics. You will find that ratios will explain the results and why one is better than the other. However, what does worse mean in this context? It would be something like the disparity between knowing the right answer and still choosing to believe otherwise. Since it would not make sense to say smart people do worse when a smart person finds the ratios, because any smart person will find the ratios and trust the math behind the statistics. Which then produces a flaw in this research: how can a smart person be claimed to do "worse" if they believe that the data presented has many factors that can skew the statistical observations? You can't claim that a smarter person does "worse" if the basis of which the data presented is able to be scrutinized by belief. If you were to classify these people as doing "worse" then that would, in turn, classify the people that did better as gullible people who believe anything they are given even if the math behind it was correct. Meaning the people that did better actually did worse in terms of the scientific process. Therefore, this research proposal should be more about whether people are informed of the scientific process and not strictly math. Furthermore, the people in this video were never seen to pull out a calculator(optional) and find the simplified ratios, does that mean that they can be qualified as smart? Then that means that there wasn't truly a 9 on the numeracy value which then changes the observation. Any mathematician or scientist can be presented big numbers and you will find they never assume just because a number is bigger does that mean that, in the end, the answer is the larger one (no offense to anyone).   If you want a better prompt, it could be something like presenting the numbers of student test scores. You would have people that read the book required to learn the material in paper or online and compare. This would solve the issue of the previous prompt being something that people would not apply their beliefs. You would then see the variety of beliefs since there a lot of factors to be considered. That would mean that the hypothesis has nothing to do with smart people (sort of) but something along the lines of: If people are given statistical evidence, then how does belief change that? You could then go about this whole rant regarding theory of knowledge and the clash between belief and fact but I am just an engineer and that is not my job haha.   Not trying to offend anyone or anything, just something to distract myself with. Feel free to correct me or add something since that is part of the scientific process. A lot of people with ADHD, and ADHD-I (or ADD) in particular, are excellent problem-solvers not because they have something extra, but because their thoughts are less filtered by executive function, meaning intuitive solutions are less likely to be dismissed right away at the subconscious level. That's the thing with intuition, any solutions to a problem it produces can easily be dismissed by executive function. An example of this happening is when you've forgotten a name or particular word, and the longer you actively think about it, the longer it will take to finally remember, because executive function interferes and blocks subconscious thought processes from reaching consciousness. To remember a name or word on the tip of your tongue, try remember it once, and then stop trying - and wait a little. The brain is always "thinking", after all - and sometimes it's often best to not actively think, especially when it comes logical reasoning.   This is something one can practice and improve in various ways, effectively with the potential of making you "smarter" than you already are. The first step is to dismiss the notion that thoughts have inherent value, good or bad. Do not attribute values to thoughts beyond the value of "usefulness". An utilitarian and pragmatic approach is optimal when it comes to meta-cognitive strategies, and "usefulness" is a far superior value to filter by than any other. Train yourself in not dismissing all thoughts as cumbersome, tiresome, a bother, or otherwise useless. After some time, executive function will adopt the new filter, and you'll experience more intuitive moments while problem-solving. This, in turn, will make you measurable "smarter" because you're using your intelligence more efficiently.  Perhaps, one day, you will have your brain do your thinking for you, while you sit back enjoying the pseudo-visuals that occur while your brain visualizes problems and potential solutions. One of the most surprising discoveries of my life, is the fact that higher problem-solving actually involves very little thinking. It's more about feeding some input into a machine, and simply not actively think about it until the machine is done with one or more results. You only have to customize that machine through learning a certain skill or field.

The first question is confusing in part because the marginal totals are not shown on the table, and they are difficult numbers to work with.  V‚Äôs decision to present the results in terms of odds (3x vs 5x more likely = 3:1 and 5:1) is confusing because almost no one has an intuitive feel for odds and they are highly nonlinear.  Also, this experiment is not particularly good, as the control group was not a placebo control. ¬†  However, V‚Äôs comments starting @1:44 are highly misleading at best.¬†  ‚ÄúUsing no cream, your rash was significantly more likely to improve.‚Äù  In any traditional academic paper, this would imply that a statistical test had been performed and that No Cream was statistically significantly better than Cream.  This is not obvious at all from the data, but the p-value is just over .05 ‚Äî not unequivocal that there is a difference at all (using standard NHST).  @1:46, V says ‚Äúin fact, it‚Äôs fair to say that, on average, the cream made rashes worse‚Äù.  It seems reasonably likely that, compared to nothing/no cream, the cream was about 8.5 percentage points or about 10% less likely to result in improvement ‚Äî but this was not statistically significantly different, and exactly p=.05 is marginal.    However, a more usual interpretation of the statement ‚Äúthe cream made the rash worse‚Äù would be that the majority of people using the cream got worse ‚Äî which is not at all the case, as 75% improved even using the cream.  It is true that ‚Äúon average, the cream made the rash worse than the control group‚Äù, which because of the lousy design was not placebo, as most knowledgeable readers would think, but nothing.  So sure‚Ä¶ it‚Äôs true in a sense, but none of this is very good exposition of what was actually shown by the data (not to mention the absence of a ‚Äústayed the same‚Äù group, which surely would exist).

I think it is because things like crime rates and gun control have *other* variables that can *largely* influence the numbers, compared to something simple as "a hand cream", which many people will either consciously or instinctively recognize when it comes to a subject like gun control. Trying to compress complex issues into simply two variables without any control group / and presenting it as "the ultimate truth" can be extremely misleading. For the hand cream, you only need to change the results of one variable for people to flip the switch. However, for a subject that has incredible amount of variables, then you would have needed to change the result of *many more* variables for people to change their mind. Which is a lot harder than just working with two. (Which is usually where the actual issue is, because some of the "other variables" we have collected over the years will vary greatly, and not all of them are sourced properly).   In other words, due to people's lack of knowledge of hand creams, the first question was presented like a math question to them where only two variables mattered. Like "Tom bought 472 apples to make an apple pie for his birthday next month, if he gave away 72, how many apples will he have for his birthday party?" type of math problem. However, the second one was no longer treated as a simple math question, but rather people start asking "well who the heck buys 472 apples to make an apple pie? He might not have more than 400 apples left because most of them would rot away!"

For example people will develop a interconnected world-view so related topics are linked via shared cause or comple interaction, this is why a political discussion/debate can jump from topic to topic without any specific resolution.  The issue with this is that data that doesn't align with the world-view becomes biased against, and supporting data favored. Given sufficemt quantities of information against the world-view, and a cessation of supporting information, someone can change their view and principle on a given matter. It should be noted that such a change is cognitively 'painful', and can lead to a great deal of uncertainty and trepidation, about their other opinions, and the prospect of investigating those pillars/branches of their world-view.  I think that people who are more intelligent (have more excess cognition and interests) maybe able to readily pickup amd discard ideas based on the data. However I suspect that such people are less likely to be passionate about any particular position. The emotional investment in a position/stance often necessitates bias as to guard ones own heart, and mind from the cognitive backlash.  I suspect that not simply due to the aging process of the human mind, but that depending on level of investmemt and base intelligence, there are a limited number of times someone is going to radically shift their world-view.  It is no wonder therefore that you found the results you did. I assume the participants were told about the study afterwards, and that we dont have people of both sides now with false information rattling around their minds lending reinforcemnt to biased ideas, of one leaning or another.  To be clear data and studies are important, but at a population level I suspect principles, ideas, narattive, and vision, are more impactful when it comes to giving people the world-view to start with; on which they hang that data, like decorations on a Christmas tree.

The conclusion made here is rather naive, in my opinion. What I see is that on a non meaningful issue people are more ready to accept information provided to them while on a meaningful issue people less ready to accept information provided. This is the mechanism that has enabled single study science to be accepted as science fact and in turn gives rise to the "reproducibility crisis". Regardless of wether we behave like this because we want to belong to our group, we should strive for everyone to not accept information that is presented as fact without further context.  The issue is much larger than it first appears. Science is in a state where it sees itself as an authority where it by and large go unchallenged. The truth, that science is supposed to be after, is in most cases much more complex than what we expect. From a security point of view this is a huge attack vector and is open to anyone who spends a bit of time to figure out how it works to take advantage of.   To be clear, when I say "science" I am referring to the current practice of science and not the idea of science.

Are no one going to point out its impossible to answer this question "correctly"? Firstly, if we assume that both groups (real vs placebo) where equally big, then you could say the real cream was better (more than doubled the amount of people getting cured), where the ones who got worse was allergic or something; AND there is a big hidden number of "NEUTRAL" testers, who had no change at all.  Then another set of unknown variables come up if we assume that the groups are different size, if its relevant exactly who takes it (if environmental or genes have extra effect when combined with medicin), if its some other substance/food that a portion of the population use that has cross effect with the cream (both good and bad; could even be with the placebo idk). The skin cream and gun control questions cannot possibly have a definitive answer, first of all, the total size of each group or the amount of instances that got neutral in each group is not mentioned, and even if that information was provided, whether the overall outcome is better or worse depends on what is being prioritized. The proportional reasoning seems to imply that the ratio between improvements and enworsements is what matters, but that isn't specified in the questions, so it could just as well be something else like the difference between improvements and enworsements relative to the sample size, or that enworsements always outweigh the improvements no matter what, etc. and depending on the context, the result may be entirely different.

Thinking, Fast and Slow by Daniel Kahneman (name is suprisingly similar to the man in the study Derek presented) is very pertinant to the topics in this video. Its underlying thesis is that, generally, we are highly emotional, reactive beings and that logic is merely a tool that our emotions point in whatever direction agrees with those biases. If you believe something to be true, your powers of reason will be applied first and foremost to finding "evidence" in agreement with said belief.

11:07  Avoiding contentious terms is fine for problems that can be addressed without a model of the underlying cause -- ie. you're treating symptoms rather than root causes -- but it isn't applicable to things where the root cause needs to be addressed. In the case of sea-level rise in Florida, there are plenty of mitigation strategies that can address symptoms such as flooding, housing and habitat loss due to coastal erosion, etc., but addressing sea-level rise is not the same thing as addressing *climate change*. The "solutions" to climate change are not strategies to address a specific collection of symptoms; they're strategies to address an underlying root cause. For that, it's necessary to use the contentious terms that actually describe the causal model of the problem.

A fairly similar experiment was done in Northern Ireland, where there's a deep divide between Catholic and Protestant communities. In that experiment, people were trained to build relationships between nonsense words through reinforcement. Eg you'd be shown the word "Faa" and have the option "Mep" and "Blo". It was predetermined that Faa = Mep, so subjects would eventually learn this relationship over time. A second relationship would be built between "Mep" and "Gar", and finally the test subjects would be promoted with "Faa" and only the options "Gar" and "Kli". Most people built the relationship of Faa = Gar without it being taught.  Where it becomes interesting is when the words aren't random syllables. In the Northern Irish study, traditionally Catholic and Protestant names were used, and test subjects from Northern Ireland would repeatedly create the relationships between the Catholic names or Protestant names, entirely unprompted and even if it was not the pre-determined relationship. What's even more interesting is that test subjects from England didn't do this as they have no history regarding this sort of stuff.

The problem with this experiment is when you ask people to consider a study on a nameless skin-care product that they have no prior knowledge of, you're testing their ability to come to the correct answer based on the numbers. But when you show people a study on a matter they probably have a lot of prior familiarity with, like climate change or gun control, you're not testing their ability to find the empirically right answer, you're asking them to rationalize the study itself based on all of the knowledge they have on the subject matter.  The questions shouldn't be does "X lower gun violence", or "does Y affect climate change", the same way you would ask "does Z reduce the rash". You would have to ask them does THIS specific study show a reduction in gun violence, climate change, etc.

The wording of the questions is really weird, and *doesn't match the actual poll.* The screen graphics show "crime increased" and "crime decreased", but the real card that you showed people said "crime improved" and "crime worsened". It also didn't say whether the change reflected places where the guns had been *legalised* or *banned,* it just said "guns legal" and "guns illegal", which doesn't tell you what the _change_ was.  Finally, it doesn't tell you _how much_ the crime increased. It's counting *the number of cities* not the *number of crimes.* If you have 100 cities where crime increased but that is _a very small increase_ (ex., 2% higher crime) that's probably still better than having "only" 80 cities where crime increased, but where it increased a lot (ex., 40% higher crime).  So, overall, I'd suggest getting some smarter (or perhaps more honest, as *this seems too bad to be **_just_** incompetence)* people *to write the questions* next time - and _show the actual questions that you asked_ on the graphics, instead of different wordings.

Your counterexample with the sea level rise is a loaded question. There is an assumption in the question that the sea level is rising. Could it be that the land is sinking, or the shore is eroding? Yes, but the loaded question does not allow for either of these possibilities and assumes that it is PROVEN that sea level is rising. Also, even if sea level rise (apparent rise, also including the previously mentioned possibilities) is present at all, is VERY difficult to measure because the measurement error is probably larger that the actual change. I constantly see bias in survey questions which is why I never answer surveys.

One of the things I have the hardest time accepting is those instances where the right thing to do is the wrong thing to do. ¬†  I had a falling-out with a friend many years ago (well over a decade ago).  I tried to reach out, tried to apologize, tried to make amends, tried to give them the opportunity to apologize and make amends for their part in the misunderstanding.  I tried to foster communication and reconciliation, or even just the understanding for an amicable break with no hard feelings.  I tried and tried and tried to do everything my power to mend what had been broken.  In my mind, from my experience at that time, to my whole world philosophy, "giving up" was the worst possible thing I could do.  Unfortunately, the other person felt differently.  From their point of view, my insistence pushed them even further away.  They wanted nothing more than to turn around, walk away, give up on our friendship, and move on with their life.  They felt that confronting things was too painful, and going our separate ways was the best option.  Everything I tried to do to make things better actually pissed them off and made things worse.  It sucked big time.  If either of us had been inclined toward the other way of dealing with things, we both would have been more stress-free.  The friendship would either have been healed, or been broken with little fuss, and we would have been as okay as possible.  But because our relative methods for dealing with interpersonal conflict were so opposite, we hurt each other in deep, deep ways.  Sucks.  I felt in my bones that I was doing the right thing.  But it had the opposite effect.  In the gun control / gun rights debate, and similarly in the abortion debate, many people have many strong feelings on how best to save innocent lives.  And each is coming at the problem from their own point of view.  Almost nobody is really truly committed to killing as many innocent people as possible.  But the way to save lives is approached in different ways, based on notions that have been ingrained by some philosophy.  When you're desperately trying to "do the right thing," and another person is also desperately trying to "do the right thing," and those two ways are at odds with each other, coming together on a compromise is difficult.  Stopping to research what, statistically, is truly THE solution, takes time, effort, and even the best statisticians don't agree on methodology and such.  If I read a study, that seemed to have the best of all possible methodologies, a meta-study, culled from a wide data set, taking in factors of this and that, race, gender, poverty, etc, etc, something that proved to my satisfaction that something I always thought was the best way to save lives, actually cost lives instead- and/or the thing that I always thought was costing so many lives would actually save many more: how would I feel about that?  Would doing the "wrong thing" to achieve the right results be something I could condone?  I honestly do not know.  We have such things baked into us, usually from an early age.  It's a struggle for the best of people, and the rest of us average folks struggle even more.   I certainly wish that more people would be more willing to listen to the "other side" rather than villainizing them.  Our political scene, in America especially, is polarizing for sure.  We need more voices of reason, rather than voices of division, to bring people together to solve our problems.

Okay I'm 6:30 into this and there's something really bugging me. Why are people falling into the trap of assuming that the binary choices they're being presented with have any correlation between actions and result?  And why aren't they questioning if there are other possible reasons for something occurring?  It's alarming how easily even the questions rope them into a thought process that is simplistic.  In the case of the first skin cream example, anyone with a modicum of statistical training will immediately realize that the proportion of people whose rashes improved without cream was much higher than those who had the cream, and that a much larger percentage of people who got the cream worsened.  However ...  This begs the question - why would a cream make something worse?  It's highly unlikely given that it's almost certainly formulated with things proven to be beneficial for skin.  So was the cream responsible for the rash getting worse?  Was it possibly genetics?   Age?  Was it possibly ANYTHING else?  And why is no one asking "Was there no one who neither got better nor worse?" ¬†  I think given the data, there's no assured conclusion to be reached; the best you could do is a reasonable guess/opinion.  And in that regard, I'd be more likely to conclude that the cream had very little if any effect, and it's more like a sample of 326 people, 230 who improved and 96 who didn't, and I want to know what kind of rash it was and what about all the people whose condition didn't change?  And then the gun control thing is a classic example of how easily some people are manipulated for political agendas.  Why assume that gun control has any effect on crime either way?  Places with strict gun control laws (e.g. Chicago where I live) are also usually run by Democrats , and it's no secret that Democrats have a propensity to be soft on crime, defund police, and they have pretty much stopped enforcing laws as any meaningful deterrent and keep turning criminals back out on the streets with a revolving door. ¬†So was it gun control that had an effect or something much more basic?  Not mention, how about the influence of the increasing coarsening of societal norms?  Back in the 1960's for example, when things were still relatively civilized, there were practically no guns laws and there was very little gun violence.  I would argue gun control has a small effect if any on crime rates one way or the other.  The one irrefutable truth however is that criminals by definition don't obey laws, including gun laws, so why would anyone want them to be the only people carrying guns around in a gun restricted city?  Especially a city with a reduced police presence...  Point being, this video is very illustrative, but what it really shows is the absence of critical thought and the acceptance of false binary dilemmas. I'm sure the people who came up with this "study" knew what they were doing, so my question is: Why did they present such a blatantly flawed premise to base it on? What agenda are they pursuing to make a point?  Nothing like starting with a conclusion and then building a data base to support it. And here I was convinced this just was a trick question because there was probably an unknown third group whose rashes stayed of a very similar severity. With such an unknown third group, proportional reasoning doesn't really work, after all.   If there were an equal amount of participants in both groups, (with about 170 in this third group, in the test group that didn't use the cream), then using the skin cream would be more likely to cure you than not using it (even if it's still also more likely to make things worse) which certainly complicates the discussion  If we assume the worst-case scenario for this hidden group (worst-case for the argument that you shouldn't use the cream, that is)  People using the cream: Improved: 223 / 298 = 75% No change: 0 / 298 = 0% Worse: 75 / 298 = 25%  People not using the cream: Improved: 107 / 298 = 36% No change: 170 / 298 = 57% Worse: 21 / 298 = 7%  You can probably see how you could come to a different conclusion like this

There is a problem. When, for reasons of education or family tradition, your political vision admits that your vote can change, that your vision of things can be wrong, but the other group accepts without thinking anything that their leaders tell them, even when those same things are opposite to what they had been told in previous elections. The example is that of Peronism in Argentina. Peronist voters have a narrow-minded vision that their leaders are right, that the others are traitors, even when that vision at times was statist, then privatizing, then statist again. Peronism is well known for its repeated violations of human rights, however the last Peronist government said that they were the only ones who respected human rights by changing history to suit them. And this is when the rationality of the other group goes out the window. If one group is always rational, open to changing its idea, and the other group will never do so, that is an evolutionary disadvantage, and so in Argentina Peronist governments are required to do little or nothing, and non-Peronists are required to have a Swiss government.  Polarization in ideas arises when one group, or both, cover their ears and shout to avoid listening to the other. I think that evolutionarily it is a disadvantage in these cases to try to change one's view even when the data convinces us, because we know positively that the other party would never do so.  If one group is capable of admitting some change of position, and the other never, that is a disadvantage for one of the groups, and stubbornness ends up being an advantage for the other.

The problem with finding "Middle ground" is that science is sometimes (Not always, but sometimes) literally all on one side of the aisle. Your example of not mentioning "Climate Change" and instead focusing on "Sea level rise" is fundamentally ceding ground to ignorance and hamstringing your efforts to effectively combat the issue of "Sea Level Rise". Climate change IS what is causing sea levels to rise and is the best predictor of future sea level rise. Sea levels will continue to rise if climate change isn't addressed. And your efforts to combat "Sea level rise" will be a losing battle until either all the sea ice on Earth has melted or greenhouse gas emissions have reached net zero.  "Climate Change" is already language that has been depoliticized. The term used to be "Global Warming," which is itself a more explicit term that implicitly targets fossil fuel use and its impact on atmospheric heat. The shift to the term "Climate Change" was itself partially politically-motivated, an appeasement to right-wing efforts to "Debunk" Global Warming. You never win by ceding ground to opponents of science, you just delay.

Anecdotally, the best way I've found to communicate with people you don't agree with is try to understand the underlying values that drive them to weight different outcomes as more important.  For instance if you are a pro-2nd Amendment person, maybe you very highly value self-defense or personal freedom over security.  If you want more gun control, maybe you value reduction of human suffering and general safety over more abstract things.  The exercise of trying to understand WHY someone thinks they way they do and not WHAT is incredibly valuable.  It's a good mental practice and a whole lot harder, but more rewarding then, "They think that because they are Evil and/or on the OTHER side".

On one hand, you have a simple question about cream and skin rashes.¬† On the other, you‚Äôre dealing with an issue where people‚Äôs lives are at stake, and the stakes couldn't be higher.   The complexity of the question increases exponentially, because now it‚Äôs not just about applying proportional reasoning.¬† You have to take into account the real-world implications, which automatically triggers a deeper level of emotional and cognitive processing. Plus, the answer to a politically charged question like gun control doesn‚Äôt just feel like a neutral calculation ‚Äî it reflects your beliefs and who you are as a person.¬†  So, people are dealing with social identity and the pressure to conform to their ideological tribe.¬† The data is no longer unbiased, and even if the numbers are the same, our interpretation of them isn't.    In essence, we‚Äôre no longer reasoning in a vacuum...  We‚Äôre processing data through the lens of our values, our emotions, and our social connections, which complicates how we think about the information... This makes the test results much more nuanced than just blaming numeracy or intelligence...

I should probably look into the details of the study because something here doesn't pass the smell test. If the study was conducted exactly how it was presented here, then I don't think you can jump to the conclusion that people are less rational, or more likely to reason incorrectly, when it comes to their political views. It seems that at the very most, you could only conjecture that people are more skeptical when their political beliefs are challenged. It looks like the participants' reasoning with numbers hasn't changed, but instead that they doubt the very numbers themselves.  The skin cream study is both low stakes and obscure. The participants most likely don't care about that particular skin cream, nor do they know anything about skin studies. On the other hand, their political views are very high stakes to them, and most likely, they've thought about these political issues before. So rather than immediately jump ship because some random stranger on the street showed them a picture, it makes sense that the participants will be skeptical.  But, if the study was conducted differently than how it was presented here, for example, if the data was given to the participants from sources/processes that they trusted, then perhaps I'd be more inclined to believe this result.  I will say, though, that perhaps the whole point of the study was to show that people will rapidly jump to the defense of a political belief without fully understanding the challenge. Like, if you were presented with data that countered your politics, the best answer would be to say "assuming that this data is accurate, ...." and then give the numerically correct answer. So maybe the study was to demonstrate that people don't do that but instead immediately vocalize mistrust in the result.  PS: One last comment I'll make. I didn't get this from the video, but I wonder if in the political question, participants just skipped the numerical reasoning completely as opposed to doing the reasoning but rejecting the result due to skepticism of the data. If so, that could demonstrate that they expect to be trapped in the interview, or that they are confident that they already know the answer despite whatever could be presented, or maybe even that they have a messiah complex and feel the need to preach their politics. There are still many explanations that are different than people don't think rationally when it comes to political *data*.

I don't doubt the overall conclusion, but to offer a complication, I would argue that at least some examples included, like the primary gun control one, do present far more room than a skin cream study for lack of controls. I know of a question that people better at math tend to get wrong more often than people not good at math: Cover all but the top two numbers.  Now call out the sum.  Uncover the next number and call out the new sum.  Continue to do this for all of the numbers.  Do this and get your total before reading on.     1000     40 1000     30 1000     20 1000    10    Now add the numbers with a calculator.   Do your numbers match?   Most people get the answer wrong when doing the summing one at a time out loud.    In my experience, people who are more comfortable with numbers do it quickly with confidence and get the wrong answer.   People not as comfortable with math go slower and more carefully and get it right.  I don't know if this will work as well when you have been forewarned that most people get this wrong.  If you print the numbers on a card and do it for people without explanation I think you will find that most get the sum wrong.

The famous people eat more icecream in summer and people get less sick in summer. So icecream is healthy and lowers illnesses. A study about gun control is not the same as a study about a skin lotion. The latter can be controlled for moderating variables and correlations, the former can't as easily.  A city that puts all criminals in prison and introduces gun control will have less crime, but is it due to gun control?  So I feel it is a bit premature to push it all onto tribalism and bias. The smarter people may simple mistrust the number for reasons outside the study. Facts are facts, but they can be presented and interpreted in many ways. So it totally makes sense that smarter people may not believe certain conclusions if the study is not about verifying that conclusion but just about gathering simple descriptive data.  To a less intelligent person a research about gun possession and gun violence may be enough. To a smarter person a causal study of the interdependence of city size, criminal numbers, ethnicities, wealth and policing approaches, gun numbers on gun violence might be enough. Surely they will stick to their prior formed opinions if the study does not address the for them relevant questions.   So this study falls into the same problem, it is useless as it has not checked the correlation or moderating effects of presenting a more elaborate study that actually addresses the complex reality of the presented data. It would be very interesting to see if the smarter people would show the same bias if they got presented a study that satisfies their expectations towards a quality study

Regarding the skin cream, I wouldn't say using the cream made the rash worse, as was being stated over and over. It just didn't necessarily perform as well as not using the cream (especially not proportionately within the given group numbers). Those are two very different things.
As an engineer, I automatically solved as a ratio. My professor drilled it in my head as a solution for many equations with too many variables. As a ratio you can potentially eliminate many of the unknown variables and solve for x variables with x-y unknowns.
Honestly, my answer would either be: - If all the constraints are constant (i.e. better means a constant amount of improvement in some form such as pain scores or rash sizes) the effect is likely negligible since approximately 3/4 of people improved with the cream while approximately 5/6 improved with no cream or viceversa. - if the constraints are not constant (i.e. people didn't apply a consistent amount of cream) the data collected is likely too unconstrained or unconditional to actually provide meaningful data for comparison.  Either way, you should likely just do a better test with larger equal sample sizes, and established constant definitions for categories (i.e. amount of cream applied).

There is a pretty glaring problem with the questions here, because the conclusions are somewhat arbitrary. Let's take the gun question for example, where crime decreasd in 223 vs 75 increased with gun control and 107 decreased vs 21 increased without gun control. The logic of the study as portrayed here is 75/223 is bigger than 21/107, so by that proportional logic crime increased with gun control. But actually, this logic is arbitrary. Because the phrasing of the study does not indicate crime increasing or decreasing by different amounts, we will assume when crime changes it does so by one. So, if crime decreases by 223 and increases by 75, that is a total decrease by 148 crimes. But if crime decreases by 107 and increases by 21, that is a decrease by only 86 total. So actually, in absolute terms, crime DECREASED with gun control. Even with skin rashes i would argue the proportional logic is somewhat arbitrary, but absolute numbers actually make a lot more sense when looking at crime statistics. Of course, we don't know the actual amount of the increases, so even this conclusion isn't solid. The fact that political leanings impact the outcomes is still interesting, but I don't see there really being a true "correct" answer.

I think there is a better reason for this. If your reasoning goes against your preconceived beliefs, but you have powerful preconceived beliefs/intuition/instincts, it's actually way more likely you made a mistake in your reasoning.
Updating beliefs purely based on explanationless data is a Bayesian approach to knowledge, and I think the majority of people intuitively don't subscribe to such an approach, because it is wrong. If you have an explanation of the world, and someone provides explanationless data that contradicts it (but without an alternative explanation), then it is simply not convincing, because there could just as rightly be another explanation that makes the new data remain consistent with your existing worldview.

They have specifically studied the political breakdown in terms of 'tribes' before. I know there are a few dozen studies just in the arena of marketing and public messaging about how to appeal to right-leaning groups versus left-leaning groups. There is even some research suggesting this might be a 'brain structure' related thing (although I do not believe they did anything to establish which direction the causality flows). Left-leaning groups are more concerned with large-scale things like the whole nation or whole world and just want the playing field to be fair and even for everybody, while right-leaning groups just want their side to win, and no principle other than that exists. Like back when compact fluorescent lightbulbs were popular and they were being promoted as being good for the environment, they did comparison studies of how to sell them to different political groups. In left-leaning areas, the messaging that focused on saving the planet worked best. In right-leaning areas, that messaging actively discouraged sales, but messaging about helping their own electric bills worked. When collecting shoes for charity, the most effective messaging for left-leaning areas was 'help the needy', while in right-leaning areas it was 'help your neighbors'. And they can see structural brain differences between these groups. I think it is too easy of a trap to fall into to make an assumption about which is "the correct" structure, or even that the structure leads to the positions held instead of the reverse. But it is real, so we do have to deal with it any time we're considering large-scale policies that are going to affect everyone.  And you mentioned gun control in this video... there is some very good (IMO) research on the topic and I think the reason we have so much conflict over it is because of what that research found. Guns simply have nothing to do with violent crime rates. Which can be surprising when you first recognize it, and notice the places in the world that have no guns but yet have extremely high rates of violent crime, and then notice places with extremely high gun ownership rates but almost no violent crime... but there IS an explanation. There is exactly 1 factor which accurately predicts the level of violent crime in a society.  Income disparity. The size of the gap between the rich and the poor always predicts violent crime rate. Where it is bigger, violent crime is higher. 100% of the time. With no exceptions anywhere in the world, not even if you consider historical societies. And where it is smaller, violent crime is lower. 100% of the time. With no exceptions anywhere. If you just look at prevalence of guns, you have to start dropping data points and saying 'oh those societies are not enough like ours to count'. If you include EVERY society, guns just don't correlate with violent crime rates. More doesn't prevent crime, but it also doesn't drive it. Income disparity, however, causes crime and drives it. Always. But nobody wants to tackle THAT problem, so we bicker about other stuff.
I do think there's more to it than just tribalism. In the skin cream example, I wouldn't HAVE any other studies on this specific formula to compare with.  I'm not saying I'm a perfectly logical being, I'm sure I've got loads of unexamined biases!  I'm just saying, the bigger and more pressing the problem, the more likely people are to consider all the context they've seen, and not just the info right in front of them.  I think that's a pretty intelligent thing to do, actually. Regarding minute 7:20, it would be necessary to analyze the data carefully. For instance, if ideology leads one in every two people to change their view, it might seem that it affects the more intelligent group much more significantly. This group could go from giving the correct answer 90% of the time to only 45%, while another group with a 30% accuracy rate would drop to 15%. This drop in accuracy appears three times larger for the intelligent group, but, in reality, the effect of politics is identical for both groups‚Äîit changes the response of 50% of those who initially answered correctly.  On the other hand, the question regarding firearms seems somewhat controversial. Ehhh, is this really an interesting result? It's obvious that polarizing issues will cause people to default to their entrenched beliefs, or in the terms of the study, use system 2 vs system 1 in a response.    the result that this is stronger in people with higher numeracy is the most interesting part, but the study didn't control for many relevant confounders. Like, if they had measured consciousness, it might have explained the difference completely.  The result is weak, particularly for its use here asserting that one side is worse than the other by a significant margin. Failing to control for well known constructs that undoubtedly affect the results is sloppy at best, biased at worst.   The bias only increases by inclusion of a topic that conservatives are known to be entrenched in one direction, and failing to include a topic where liberals are entrenched in the other direction. I'm curious to know if this experiment took itself into account: Did it control for the fact that people are rightly suspicious of statistical evidence presented as "fact" by "an authority"? For areas like skin cream where getting the right answer is irrelevant to their daily life (their tax rate, their energy costs, their ability to purchase certain products, etc), they have no reason to suspect that there are interested parties willing to skew the data, or even if they did, that the skewed data is unlikely to affect them. Yet, for politicized subjects, the very reason they are politicized is because of how likely they are to affect people. Because of this, there's a greater incentive for someone to skew data (governments, companies, scientists trying to get tenure, etc). Similarly, this experiment intentionally asks people to ignore individual past experience without regard for personal fixed points or their own previous research. No matter how compelling the data is, I will not believe that I am a 600 foot tall lizard creature, because I have direct personal information that contradicts that claim. As another example, to convince me that the Moon landings were faked, the evidence would have to be far better and more exhaustive than the significant, and extensive evidence I already personally researched. This experiment seems to present the fictitious data without taking malicious actors or past experience with the subject into account.

Why, in the skin cream experiment,  do the two groups have different number of total cases? Both comparing absolute numbers and comparing ratios are wrong because the control group is not really of control. A control group should be identical to the experimental group except for one parameter. A group of smaller data size tends to be less convincing regardless. Even if we use ratio, the group with less number of cases is subject to higher error. For example, if one guy in the experiment decides to change his mind, it affects the ratio of the smaller group much more than that of the larger group. That using ratio is the "right answer" is wrong from the start.

Skin cream problem question doesn't give enough information.  How many people were sampled for each test? If 1000 people with rashes were given skin cream and 223 people rashes got better while 75 people rashes got worse... the cream is 22.3% effective at treating rashes. 7.5% of the people who took the cream had their symptoms get worse.  If 300 people are taking the cream and 223 rashes got better while 73 got worse... the cream is 77.6% effective at treating rashes. Of the people with rashes that took the cream, 24.3% of them got worse.  If you compare it to the control for 1000, rashes of 10.7% improved while 2.1% of them worsened. If the sample size is 300, then 35.6% improved while 7% worsened.  The numbers change ALOT depending on the sample size.  For example... If the sample size was 1,000,000... effect of both creams are negligible at best and the difference can just be attributed to standard deviation.  Also,  what about the people sampled? Are they people that tend to have rashes often?  How would you define the rash "improving"? Less rash = improvement? I think the answer you provide for the first question is wrong. Let me explain.  There is obviously an unknown number of people with neutral outcome. It does not matter how big the groups are, just that the sample size of each group are the same. The numbers tell us, that from the first group 107 people would get better anyway, and 21 would get worse anyway. Therefore, actual change that happened by using the cream was +116 getting better, and +54 getting worse respectively. This means that the actual ratio of change in outcome for neutrals is 116:54 in favor of improvement, which is a bit more than 2:1. Therefore, if you used the cream, both your chances of getting better OR worse increased, however overall, the chance of getting better increased by twice as much compared to the increase of the risk.  Its like if you buy something for 10 and sell for a 100, and after that you buy for 10 and sell for 20. Even if the second trade is not as good as the first, you are still better off doing both than just the first. Even if the overall ratio of profit to investment is lower, the total gain in the end is higher, so you should still do both.  Only way your math works, is if the groups are of different sizes, and nobody had unchanged-neutral outcome. But that kind of research feels illogical to me, its more of a "gotcha" than actual interesting research.

Who wants their rash to get better or get worse? They both can sound the same - which is good for the rash that wants to continue to exist.
These are _not_ the "exact same" questions, because people know how rashes work. They usually get better by themselves after a few days - unless if you have an ongoing illness, in which case they might get worse. Either way, "change" is a baseline expectation, and everyone understands that in advance.  But the crime rate in a given city usually hovers around the same level from year to year, changing a tiny bit at the most. If we _don't_ pass any gun control laws, but we observe crime significantly increasing or decreasing, there would have to have been some other factor involved to cause the change. It's perfectly sensible to be suspicious that the numbers are baloney.

The skim cream question is poorly worded. The rash gets better for most people who use the cream and for most people who don't use the cream. So the cream makes the rash better than it was before. But an even higher proportion of the people who did not use the skin cream saw their rash get better than it was before. So given the choice between cream or no cream, no cream is more likely to result in the rash getting better (even though either is likely to result in the rash getting better than it was before). Another possible interpretation of the question is "which treatment results in the better expected outcome?" There is not enough information to answer that question. Perhaps no cream makes 80% of the rashes slightly better and 20% of them much worse but cream makes 70% of them much better and 30% of them a little worse.

How about we point out the fallacy of thinking both questions only differ in being political? The first one about skin creme shows changes, whereas "no changes" are undefined. There the relation between improvement and decline matters (x / y) - how many had an improvement compared to a decline. As of the gun control example the absolute differences matter (x - y) - how many crimes were added vs how many crimes were reduced. If you have +100 and -20, you have a net +80. If you have +300 and -150, you have a net +150. This is assuming gun ownership would increase the amount of crime AND decrease it simultaneously (or vice versa). Comparing this in varying cities would cause a misleading statistic unless stated... in that case the relations would be relevant again. Still, too vague.  And regarding the "political" part, this is about entertaining fictional scenarios vs reality. This is akin to "let's pretend eating tide pods improves health", and playing along can be considered foolish. I have a different take.  The cream appears to have some effect, as a higher percentage of users experienced improvement compared to non-users. However, the higher worsening rates for cream users indicate potential side effects.   Assuming that each group have same size here are two scenarios.   Scenario 1:¬† and¬† (468 Total¬† in each group)   In this scenario:   Used cream group:   Improved: 223   Worsened: 75   No Change: x = 170   Total N = 468    Didn't use cream group:   Improved: 107   Worsened: 21   No Change: y = 340   Total N = 468     Improvement Rates:   Used cream: 223 / 468 ‚âà 47.65%   Didn't use cream: 107 / 468 ‚âà 22.86%    Worsening Rates:   Used cream: 75 / 468 ‚âà 16.03%   Didn't use cream: 21 / 468 ‚âà 4.49%    No Change Rates:   Used cream: 170 / 468 ‚âà 36.32%   Didn't use cream: 340 / 468 ‚âà 72.65%    Inference for Scenario 1:   The improvement rate is higher for those who used the cream (47.65%) compared to those who didn‚Äôt (22.86%).   However, the worsening rate is also higher for those who used the cream (16.03%) compared to those who didn‚Äôt (4.49%).   A much higher percentage of people who didn't use the cream experienced no change (72.65%) compared to those who used it (36.32%).    This suggests that the cream has some effect, as a higher percentage of people saw improvement in the group that used the cream. However, it also appears to have potential side effects, as the worsening rate is also higher in the cream group. Overall, the cream seems somewhat effective but with potential risks.    ---   Scenario 2:¬† and¬† (Total 298 in each group)   In this scenario:   Used cream group:   Improved: 223   Worsened: 75   No Change: x = 0   Total N = 298    Didn't use cream group:   Improved: 107   Worsened: 21   No Change: y = 170   Total N = 298     Improvement Rates:   Used cream: 223 / 298 ‚âà 74.83%   Didn't use cream: 107 / 298 ‚âà 35.91%    Worsening Rates:   Used cream: 75 / 298 ‚âà 25.17%   Didn't use cream: 21 / 298 ‚âà 7.05%    No Change Rates:   Used cream: 0 / 298 = 0%   Didn't use cream: 170 / 298 ‚âà 57.05%    Inference for Scenario 2:   The improvement rate for those who used the cream is much higher (74.83%) compared to those who didn‚Äôt use it (35.91%).   However, the worsening rate is also substantially higher for those who used the cream (25.17%) compared to those who didn‚Äôt (7.05%).   A large percentage of people who didn‚Äôt use the cream experienced no change (57.05%), while all participants in the cream group experienced either improvement or worsening (0% no change).    This scenario implies that the cream has a strong effect, as nearly all users saw either improvement or worsening, with very few remaining unaffected. However, the high worsening rate in the cream group indicates potential side effects.   Conclusion for Scenario 2: The cream is likely effective in prompting a change (whether improvement or worsening), with a higher chance of improvement. However, it also comes with a notable risk of worsening symptoms.    ---   Overall Summary   In both scenarios, the cream appears to have some effect, as a higher percentage of users experienced improvement compared to non-users. However, the higher worsening rates for cream users indicate potential side effects. The cream may be effective for some people, but it also poses a risk of adverse reactions.

This dovetails nicely with some of the newer practices in politics, specifically "Deep Canvasing" in which people who support a particular issue or candidate go door to door, not just to find out who the resident is supporting or why, but also to share why they are supporting their choice, specifically to share personal stories about what made them decide to support it. There is evidence that this sort of canvassing can actually change minds and persuade voters, because it humanizes the people holding the alternate side, making us see them as fellow citizens with deep lives. This not only softens any defense based on "Those others are horrible people trying to hurt good folks like us" but also serves to expand our tribe, allowing us to feel that changing our opinion is not going to cut us off from humanity writ large.
