The great problem with data in politics is that it's SO EASY to manipulate studies.  Each side has a block of 'Institutes' that conduct studies where the study design virtually guarantees your outcome.  Minimum wage for example.  I saw a meta paper examining the state of economic studies on the minimum wage.  Sure enough they ALMOST divided perfectly into halves.  The ones that chose one methodology for trying to establish controls showed no effect of minimum wage on employment.  Those using a different method to control for other factors showed a substantial negative impact on hours worked.  I say ALMOST because there were two outliers that used the methodology that did not show effects, but those studies DID show small negative effects.  But generally, which methodology you chose ABSOLUTELY DICTATED your outcome.  Then, politicians from each side go on talking head shows and talk like the only studies that exist are the ones that agree with them.  And we've seen how this can happen even in hard science.  How many studies showed that [insert anything here] causes cancer?  And then you read the particulars and find out that they stuffed the mice full of 10x their body weight of that substance every day for months.  And that's before you get into p-hacking or outright fraud.  The entire anti-vax movement came out of a single study that was a dude just straight up lying about his data because he wanted to be able to sue the drug companies for big money.  He's ADMITTED in court that he lied about his data.  But the antivax movement remains strong.  So the term 'Studies show...' is the most overused starter phrase in politics.  And the most worthless.  And people know it, so they're RATIONALLY skeptical of the 'evidence'.  What's needed more than anything is better agreement BEFORE a 'study' is done on what are and are not valid methodologies.  There needs to be tighter peer review.  And any paper that doesn't go through peer review shouldn't be reported on.  No pre-print reporting.  Don't waste our time telling us what the National Institute of Pre-Determind Biased Outcomes concluded about the effect of abortion on crime or whatever.  But that doesn't sell ad impressions, does it?

I don't think the gun control study can directly be compared with the skin care study. The skin care is presented as a clinical trial, so the assumption is that it was controlled and the cream was the only factor that differed, which make people more likely to focus on the numbers. The gun control study is different in that it doesn't account for a number of outside factors, so people will be less likely to trust the numbers and more likely to let their conclusion be influenced by their believes, because they know the "study" is flawed and those numbers alone can't provide a definitive answer. For the study to be of any value, instead of gun control they should have picked a subject that is highly political, but can also be measured as accurately as a clinical study.

This is an interesting study because of the way the two versions of the fictional study were presented.  In the skin cream version, the 2 pools represent those who DID or DID NOT use the skin cream and there is no room for interpretation.  In the gun control legislation version of the study, the 2 pools represnting cities that DID or DID NOT pass gun control legislation, each of the people polled skews the interpretation of the study.  It is conceiveable that some people considered the study to compare the presence of firearms, while others compared the presence of legislation (which does not necessarily dictate the presence of firearms, the same way speeding still exists in the presence of speed limits).  It seems to me that the pollee's interpretation of the gun control version of the study is not taken into account in the findings of numeracy vs politically weighted interpretation of the study. In the study on the gun control question, there are major problems with how the question was designed and asked. The table shows the number of cities that improved/worsened, not the total amount of crime, and there is no information given about significant confounding factors (such as legislation in cities neighboring each of the cities). Thus, the information provided in the hypothetical is not sufficient to draw the conclusion they expect.   For example, if you make guns illegal in a city surrounded by cities where they are legal and easy to obtain, then people from those cities would travel to the city where they are illegal, increasing the violent crime rate where they were made illegal and decreasing it where they are legal, and the statistics would make it appear that the gun ban increased the violent crime rate, when in fact it decreased it overall (because fewer criminals, such as burglars, who live in the city where guns were made illegal would decide to bring a gun to the scene of the crime).
The question in itself doesn't really give enough context, because correlation isn't causation. If the numbers given imply strict causation, then the question is strictly numerical.  Unfortunately in the real world, we're many times unable to infer strict causation in statistics.
I think you mostly skipped over an important point, which is that people already "know" a lot about gun control (or at least think they do).  For some made-up skin creme that nobody knows anything about, this one study is the only information they have to go on so of course their opinion would line up with the data as long as they have decent numeracy.  But for gun control a perfectly rational person should be applying Bayes' theorem to combine this new information with what they already know, and since this is just one study it should only shift their credences a small amount either way.  There are two missing question types I'd like to see added to the experiment: something people have experience with but that isn't politically charged and also something that feels politically charged but people don't know much about.  You could do the first by just replacing the skin creme with some real product that people use a lot, while the second would be tricker but you could maybe do a question about whether or not to ban a fake drug or something like that.    That doesn't explain people misinterpreting the study itself, but I'm not entirely convinced that is exactly what happened.  There are two separate questions to be asked here: "what does this particular study say in isolation?" and "what is your opinion on the subject after hearing about this study?".  I skimmed through the paper and it looks like they did not explicitly separate these questions out, so while the researchers obviously wanted the answer to the first question they probably got at least some people answering the second instead.  If your position is "this study shows one result, but based on my prior knowledge I disagree and think the opposite is true in reality." that would probably be hard for a lot of people to articulate clearly, much less boil down to the correct yes/no answer to put on a questionnaire or whatever. Since you were interviewing him and gave him time to talk he was able to express his opinion clearly but I could easily see someone like him checking the wrong box on a survey despite fully understanding the data, especially since his rebuttal will always be the last thing on his mind.  Of course there are also going to be people who just skim over the numbers and stop as soon as they find something that agrees with their preconceived notions, but I would expect those to mostly be the less numerate people while "smarter" people would be more prone to overthinking things instead...

If numeracy also correlates with scientific literacy then it makes sense that this highly flawed fictitious study would raise concerns in numerate people if it did not match their perception of reality, i. e., the more outrageous the claim the higher the burden of proof.  In this case we have two treatments, gun control and no gun control but there are no actual controls for confounding factors, so the experiment is uncontrolled.  There are clearly strong trends in gun crime that are unreleated to the treatments because even in the null treatment there is at least a three fold change (either up or down depending on the table headings) .  Clearly there are very strong confounding factors at work and in the absence of even a graphical presentation of variability, one would have to be highly impressionable to put any weight on such a study.  The main thing this study confirms is that there are too many people doing studies who don't actually understand experimental design.

Now if you're actually smart, you would have done a 2-proportion Z test and found that the P-value is 0.976, meaning that there is no significant evidence showing that the rash cream helped with rashes. In fact, if we reverse this test testing if no cream helped rashes better than cream, we get a P-value of 0.024 (alpha = 0.05) showing that there is significant evidence to show that no cream helps rashes better than cream.

Human beings, and indeed all mammals have an autonomic system called affective(emotional) empathy.  The way in which this system works, assuming that trauma hasn't inhibited or blocked this response.  Is that when we interact with another being, human, pet, or really any living thing.  Our emotions trend toward the emotional state of that other being, or interlocular if you prefer.  We literally give up how we are feeling in favor of matching the emotional state of whom we are interacting.  This carries over into our logic.  There is for example a certain wisdom in crowds.  If a restaurant is always busy, there is a reason for that.  Either the food is very tasty, or it is inexpensive to get a lot of food.  Maybe even both are true.  This, I think only reinforces the trend toward tribalism.  Those in 'our' group are safe, whereas, those in that other group could be predators.  So we tend to error on the side of caution. Now what do you do about purposefully tainted, fabricated, obfuscated, misleading, and cherry picked data? People like to believe that the "numbers" are always indisputable but they are subject often by the bias that existed before the data was even collected. Sometimes this happens because the studies are determined without acknowledgment or consideration for the bias, other times the bias is exactly what they intend the study/numbers to confirm and as such are flawed because of the desire to confirm the bias regardless of what the "empirical" data shows. As such just as important as the data should be from each study, so is the background, funding, association, political leaning, outside motivations, financial situations, honesty, and integrity of every entity involved in the study should also be of equal or even greater importance. In the end it is very difficult if even possible for data to be as accurate as most people want to believe it is.

9:40 I think attributing this phenomenon to the need to fit in with our "tribe" is highly speculative. This experiment, as it is presented, provides no evidence for this conclusion. This is, itself, an example of taking a preexisting belief and attempting to fit it into data that doesn't directly support it.  This also doesn't prove that beliefs aren't "formed" by careful examination of the data. These people have all already formed their beliefs on gun control. The study demonstrates their ability to change those extant beliefs. It does not show how those beliefs were formed.  Maybe these people formed their beliefs based on the data they had available to them, and are now resisting new, contradictory data.  This study provides no insight into how beliefs are formed only how they respond (after being formed) to new data. And it provides no evidence for what causes those responses. To make blanket assertions about either is not scientific.  All we know from this study is that people with strongly held beliefs tend to interpret data in a way that reinforces those beliefs, even if doing so is incorrect. This study doesn't tell us why nor does it tell us how those beliefs are originally formed.

The fake study about gun control is not comparable to the fake study about skin creams, because we assume the skin creams were randomly assigned to each individual. In the case of cities, gun control legislation was not randomly assigned to each city, so there very well might be common causes which lead to an increase/decrease in crime, as well as an increase/decrease in gun control legislation. This is the difference between an interventional study where the researchers can conduct a randomized control trial, and an observational study where researchers collect data and have no direct control over the independent variable, or "treatment". For more information about this, I recommend the book May Contain Lies by Alex Edmans.

We've conducted similar experiment back in the day, and asked college students to interpret the stats of the local football and basketball teams. Those who identified themselves as die-hard fans of their respective teams were significantly more likely to misinterpret the data to make their teams 'look' better in their conclusions than the data actually suggested. Those who were asked the same questions but without any indication of which teams they were asked to analyze tended to give more accurate and correct assessments.

If buying eggs is not important, and you run out of eggs, do I go outside just to buy eggs? Nah I'm lazy. But bread is very important, and you run out of bread. Ok, since I will go outside and buy bread (it's so important that the need to buy it exceeds my lazyness), then I amortize the cost of going out by buying eggs as well. Buying eggs when you have to buy bread is psychologically cheaper than only buying eggs. With ideas is the same: rewiring your ideas is a costly operation, and you will avoid doing that unless something important is happening which will amortize the cost of rewiring your ideas. Your brain will prevent you to pay that cost otherwise. So it's cheaper to assume that the data is wrong, a lot of context has been thrown away, or just apply some cheap bias, to avoid going into the very expensive journey of facing a cognitive dissonance episode and rethink a lot of stuff. Is it stupid to assume that there must be something wrong with the data? Depends on the kind of problem. For things with social impact we know intuitively and also by experience that trying to reduce social phenomena to numbers almost always goes wrong, so that tool of rejecting the data is not even a stupid thing to do. It's the perfect tool for the job of avoiding cognitive effort.  However, with the cream we don't usually have any preconceived ideas, so there's nothing to rewire and we accept the reality whatever it is.

I don't think this necessarily has to do with tribalism but how Epistemology works in general:  It is the theory (in this case our worldviews) that shapes the way we interpret the information, not the other way around. If data contradicts theory, we don't ditch the theory right away, but we try to find out what went wrong from bottom (data collection) up (theory). As a retired analyst, this study does *not* prove what they are claiming it proves.  The two sets of "numbers" are not the same and to say they are is straight up fraud.  "Lies, damn lies, and statistics", where you pick a small set of numbers from a very large and complex group of them to "Prove" a point when it is not actually proven at all and can be completely the opposite.  The first question on skin cream, each point represents a small (single person) and simple (skin cream or not) variable.  While there are outside contributors, they are likely to be covered by a large enough sample size.  Thus the results are likely to be fairly accurate on using vs not using the skin cream.  The second question on gun control, each point represents a large (city) and complex (crime rate) variable.  There are hundreds to thousands of outside contributors, many of which are likely to cause a larger change in crime rate than enacting a gun control law.  Just showing a very simplified chart without going into any controls to take into account outside contributors will always result in people who agree with the results just accepting the results and people who disagree with the results actively wondering if the contributors were taken into account.    What the study does prove is that people are likely to disagree with "simplified results" on "complex problems" that are counter to their own experience unless they know how those "simplified results" were obtained.  The better someone is at processing this type of data (numeracy score) the more likely they are to question a simplified result to a complex issue, especially if they disagree with the result.  That is because using such "simplified numbers" as prove of something that they actually are not has reached the point of mass saturation in society today.  What they should have done is instead of skin cream, they should have picked a bipartisan issue (positive or negative) with complexity as the control.  Even better if they had two such controls, one of which is bipartisan negative and the other bipartisan positive.  As it is, their study is nearly worthless.

Let's say the total n for each treatment group is 1,000. If you don't take the cream, you have a 10.7% chance of improving, and a 2.1% chance of getting worse. If you do take the cream you have a 22.3% chance of improving and a 7.5% chance of getting worse. So I don't think it's as cut and dry as one is better than the other. If you want the best chance of getting better despite risks, you'd take the cream. If you were risk averse to getting worse, you'd avoid the cream. It's more accurate to say that the cream is more likely to have positive and negative effects than to say it is patently worse.

The politicized version is flawed on its face: any random person is unlikely to know any actual stats on skin creams.  The real finding here is that EXTERNAL knowledge (real or imagined) influences things.  Honest people knowledgeable on the actual stats are well aware of the fact that crime is inversely proportional to legal gun ownership.  On the left, you have people ignorant of the stats parroting what they were told, or aware and lying to push gun control.  On the right, you have people aware of the stats, or or ignorant and parroting what they've been told (and just happening to be right).  In short, they dismiss the stats that don't align with what they thought, immediately seeing them as wrong, because it's a subject they either know about or THINK they know about.  This probably has relation to the Gell-Mann Amnesia effect, as well: when reading an article about a subject of which we're knowledgeable, we immediately notice what it gets wrong, but turn the page and read an article in the same publication on a subject we don't know much about, and on average, people just take it at face value, "forgetting" that the publication just got the previous subject completely wrong.  People don't know about skin cream, so they have no reason to question the numbers; people know or think they know about gun control and crime rates, and so they dismiss the numbers that don't align with what they know or think they know.  End result?  Left believes the fake numbers when they don't align with reality (more gun control = less crime) and ignores them when they align with reality (more legal gun owners = fewer violent crimes), and vice versa for the "right."  You could likely get similar results with a non-politicized subject, by framing in terms of a field of expertise, then asking people with that expertise and those without.  The experts will likely ignore the numbers that don't align with reality and give the answer that is correct for the subject, whereas the laymen will just evaluate the numbers provided.  This is correctable with the right methodology, though.  If properly advised that it's a hypothetical study, not real numbers, then you would get people capable of higher order thinking getting it right (because they're able to divorce themselves from the subject framing and look at it as a pure maths problem), and those not getting it wrong (because they can't separate the maths from the framing).  Similar to the classic "if you didn't have breakfast yesterday, how would you feel?" question.  Those capable of higher order thinking would rightly respond "hungry" as that is what one would expect to feel if a meal they normally eat was missed.  Those incapable of higher order thinking respond "but I did eat breakfast" or "I never eat breakfast," missing the point of the question and unable to understand and evaluate a hypothetical.  As to your crime comment in the ad spot, the "crime is down" depends on two things, 1) More than 1/3 of precincts nationally no longer report stats (resulting in fewer reported crimes, despite the Crime Victimization Survey data confirming what is obvious to anyone looking: crime is continuing to go way up), 2) starting measurement AFTER the massive crime spike during the lockdowns.  So yes, it's down 3% from the peak reached after the massive increase a couple years earlier, IF you exclude more than a third of the country, with the most violent cities being part of that third.

8:58 the problem here is that people aren‚Äôt willing to change their beliefs based on evidence that somebody else constructed, because people aren‚Äôt willing to trust somebody with the opposite worldview to correctly gather the statistics and present them in an objective way that accounts for all the meaningful factors.  I‚Äôll give an example of a scenario where I DID change my perspective on a debate, albeit a silly one; the new mace weapon in Minecraft. Originally I was on the side that it was a fun and unique weapon that added lots of interesting mechanics to the game, and that the high level PvP players who complained about it were just overreacting, but after a multi-day back to back argument about it, I finally decided to load up the wiki and start gathering the numbers. This meant taking note of how much damage the mace did per block fallen, then applying damage reduction formulas for the protection enchantment and armour. You know what I found? The original mace could insta-kill a player with full prot 4 netherite armour in only 12 or 13 blocks of falling. I IMMEDIATELY changed my perspective on it, and went HARD into denouncing it in its current state. It doesn‚Äôt matter how rare it is, the strongest possible armour in the game couldn‚Äôt prevent it from killing you by a jump off a villager‚Äôs house.  And you want to know what‚Äôs worse? *I did my math wrong.* It wasn‚Äôt actually around 13 blocks, it was only FOUR OR FIVE. My math was wrong because I applied the armour formula before the protection enchantment, and if you know anything about each formula, you‚Äôd know the enchantment is a flat 64% reduction for max level on all armour, but ARMOUR reduces less and less damage the stronger the attack is. So, if you apply protection first, it only lets 36% of the original damage through to the armour formula, which blocks a greater percentage of it than it would if 100% was let through and only THEN applied protection. Even now, after all the nerds, a mace with density 5 only I‚Äôm pretty sure is STILL capable of killing at under 20 blocks (but I might be wrong about that, it‚Äôs been a while since I‚Äôve done the calculation), but it‚Äôs much better than before.  So what‚Äôs my point in all this? I did the calculation, and I was able to form my own conclusion out of doing so, INSTEAD of having to trust that someone else did it correctly. This is why every time I recited this fact to anyone who tried to argue from the same perspective I used to hold, I walked them through the FULL calculation I performed, even though that usually resulted in them responding with ‚ÄúI ain‚Äôt reading allat üíÄ‚Äù. If you can‚Äôt trust somebody else to do it right, then you need to verify it yourself. That‚Äôs how people come to change their minds in light of evidence, convincing THEMSELVES what the stats mean instead of BEING convinced by someone else.

Yeah this one group shows a higher proportion of people with worse symptoms than the other, but why aren‚Äôt the experimental group and control group the same size? How were people selected to begin with? You said a rash, but didn‚Äôt specify if it‚Äôs from the same condition, so is it the same condition in all individuals? As an economist‚Ä¶ this doesn't surprise me in the least. Humans aren't actually logical decisionmakers; we decide based on intuitive, emotional, neurochemical triggers, with our logical and deductive reasoning chasing along behind trying to justify the emotional decision. Without emotion, we can't really assign value (in economics jargon, utility) to any outcome.  This is borne out in neurological studies of certain kinds of brain damage. Occasionally people have some kind of trauma to the brain that effectively shuts off their ability to feel emotions, and they become utterly paralyzed by even the simplest of choices. With no ability to feel which option is more desirable, there's no impetus for decisions.

It's not just tribalism though. Facts on their own are not very useful. You need to embed them in a self consistent model to give them sense. Most of the facts that are embeded in that model will not be personnaly experienced. Most of the time, the model itself will be given by external sources you will have to trust.  For instance, if a Thermometer gives a temperature of melting ice way above what it should be, you don't question the established temperature of melting ice (the model), you question the thermometer (the "fact" given to you by the thermometer). You do so because you trust encyclopedias, teachers, and so on more than one device.  If some fact don't fit readily in your model, you can either bend the fact, question the reliability of the fact or update your model at a great cost.  Solving the contradiction without introducing new ones may require to reconsider the trust you put in your sources, and thus whole sections of your model may lose their support.

Howdy hi hi,      I think a big part of what this shows is there is a biological trend toward held bias.  While we were evolving, survival often times valued being right less than having an answer that increased the odds of survival.  For example, a person turns around and sees a person standing close to them and is startled and perhaps lets out a startled cry or scream.  Then then see who it is, and says something like, oh hi Mom.      The sudden loud noise made by our subject is pro-survival because if the person standing close were a predator.  That scream might scare off the predator.  But if they are wrong and it's just Mom standing there.  It isn't a hindrance to survival to simply express oh you startled me!        What does this mean?  I think it means that we are biologically programmed toward behaviors that can assist in our survival more strongly than we are programmed to reach the correct answer.  But given enough time, most people will eventually reason out why the intuitive answer was wrong. **************** Edit and post script.      Human beings, and indeed all mammals have an autonomic system called affective(emotional) empathy.  The way in which this system works, assuming that trauma hasn't inhibited or blocked this response.  Is that when we interact with another being, human, pet, or really any living thing.  Our emotions trend toward the emotional state of that other being, or interlocular if you prefer.  We literally give up how we are feeling in favor of matching the emotional state of whom we are interacting.  This carries over into our logic.  There is for example a certain wisdom in crowds.  If a restaurant is always busy, there is a reason for that.  Either the food is very tasty, or it is inexpensive to get a lot of food.  Maybe even both are true.  This, I think only reinforces the trend toward tribalism.  Those in 'our' group are safe, whereas, those in that other group could be predators.  So we tend to error on the side of caution.  Doing so increases our chances of survival.      And so, thank you good sir for producing this video and posting it.  Very thought provoking.  I hope your day treats you well.

This study is unfortunately flawed, because although it is presented as if gun control and skin cream are equivalent, they are not.  In the skin cream example, everything people know about it is contained in the table.  With the gun control example, people's understanding of the world and how it works are additional data points that are not represented in the table.  In other words, gun control is a lot more complicated of an issue that cannot be boiled down into a simple "it worked" or "it didn't work" otherwise it wouldn't be an issue at all.  All this study proves is that gun control is more complicated of a question.  That said, I do think that confirmation bias is a real thing, and if people see data that is consistent with their ideology, they are less likely to question it.  However, the reverse is simply that they are more likely to question the study itself which is a good thing. Science should be rigorous.

Before the answer is given, here's my logic and reasoning behind the skin cream results:  1. The most obvious error to me is the discrepancy between the amount of subjects in the experimental group and the control group, assuming I was not aware of the true experiment, and only reviewing the results from the skin cream experiment, my first observation would have been how the experimental group was just larger than the control group, allowing the perception of the results to initially be skewed until more rigorously checked. 2. There isn't enough data (in my personal opinion) that definitively proves anything. Variables such as: usage frequency of the cream, amount of cream used each time, types of rashes the subjects were experiencing, types of rashes that resolved vs persisted and/or worsened, and in a very precise study, the general lifestyles of subjects. There are simply too many unknowns for me to draw a conclusion as to whether or not the cream was truly responsible for the results generated.

I'm not sure depicting the gun control issue as a dichotomy between "the claim that gun control increases crime" and "the claim that gun control decreases crime" is correct. Many opponents of gun control don't argue this because of alleged effects on crime, but because they view gun ownership as a basic right. The (potentially positive) consequences of compromising that right are not directly relevant from their perspective. Many issues can be approached from several perspectives; it's easy to talk past each other when failing to recognize differing priorities.

Edit: To anybody who reads this and rushes off to say "that's the point of the study!"‚Ä¶ please don't.  Enough people have already said that, and you're all wrong.  See the clarification.  Don't respond unless you actually have something more to say.  I see a flaw with this study:  The researchers are treating this as a math class problem.  The subjects are not.  The researchers assume people are coming to the their answer just by looking at this specific set of numbers.  But on such an important issue, they are naturally bring *all* of their info to bear, not just this chart.  Edit:  [clarification]  When some rando comes up to you on the street, and presents a math class problem about unnamed rash cream, people are likely to take that at face value, and think 'oh, we're doing a math problem now,' and play along.  But when some rando comes up with a chart purporting to give statistics about a major political topic, they are far more likely to think 'oh, this political agent wants to talk about this political topic'.  They know the odds are high that such an agent is going to use loaded language, manipulated data, and other tricks, to con them.  They aren't having the conversation the researchers think they are.

Surely the purpose of that skin cream study was to determine the marginal benefit of using the cream.  Since the results don't tell us how many people saw no change in their rash, we are forced to assume that.  We could assume the answer is zero, that literally everyone in both groups saw their rash get better or worse, but that's implausible.  Or we could assume that the experiment group and control group were the same size, which does make sense.  So let's do that.  That allows us to determine the net effect of using the cream relative to not using it.  After all, that's the point of having the control group at all.  If 223 cases improved, compared to 107 in the control, that means the marginal benefit was 116 cases.  If 75 worsened compared to 21, the marginal cost was 54 cases.  That means the marginal change is a net improvement of 62 cases.  The cream helps.

There is something else going on as well.  There is more to the data than mere proportionality.  The consequence of the skin cream not working was "rash gets worse". Specifically, answers that favored minimal lethality over mere proportionality. For the skin cream question, they way you presented it, the correct answer is both: The cream made the rash better and worse. Presumably, the sizes of the groups are not 298 and 128, which is what it would take for every participant to have seen an effect - either better or worse. Since it doesn't make sense to assume someone chose those group sizes, and it's unreasonable to assume every person saw an effect, we have to assume there are people who had no change, and those people make up the difference to the total group size. So if we assume the total group size was 500 for each, in the cream group (in the first presentation) there are 298 people who got better, 202 who stayed the same, and 75 who got worse, and the control group had 107 people get better, 372 stay the same, and 21 get worse. In the cream group (in the first presentation) more people got better than control (298 vs 107) and more people got worse than control (75 vs 21). So the answer to the question "Did the cream make the rash better or did it make it worse" is yes. It made users more likely to get better, more likely to get worse, and less likely to stay the same.  The only way this question requires proportional reasoning is if we make the baffling assumptions that every user saw an effect, AND one group is 233% the size of the other for absolutely no reason. Now, if the question was "Is this a good cream?" or "Is it a good idea to use this cream?" then we have another scenario.

5:14 I am going to stop you there. Here is the problem with this study - skin cream to rash resolution is a pretty straightforward causal link. Gun control is just too complex of a subject to make this type of causal relationship.   To use another similar, currently relevant example, it would be like saying that when the Feb lowers interest rates it causes a recession. You can back that up ten ways to Sunday by showing how when the Fed lowers interest rates a recession almost always follows historically. I could make the same argument that anyone that does not agree with me is wrong, empirically.  I think we can all agree that the Economy, like crime rates, are both complex in nature, and respond to an undefinable number of inputs, therefore making them difficult - if not impossible - to predict with any accuracy. This seems easily explainable as people with higher numeracy being people more likely to include additional factors in their calculation besides the study itself.  If, correctly or wrongly, someone has the perspective from prior experiences that gun control is bad, then they will of course consider how the data showing the opposite result at a surface level could've been collected or summarized in a misleading way, whereas someone with less numerical literacy may not be as aware of ways in which data could be summarized in a misleading way, and they may be more likely to assume the data in front of them implies its surface level meaning.  The same applies for people who, correctly or wrongly, have the pre-existing perspective that gun control is good. They're not just going to overturn their entire perspective because you showed them a little two-way table of data they haven't even been able to validate yet.  So, it's not necessarily that the "smarter people are more likely to get the question wrong" but more like "people with higher numeracy scores are more likely to consider nuances based on prior experience with an issue, and this may in some cases lead to a more correct or less correct answer."

It's not the "exact same question and data as the skin-cream sample" though. And it's not really just a "political context", it's a "further knowledge" context.  It is additional data on a well studied subject. So knowledge of old data scews the valuation of new data. Kind of like if you posted the same question with car crashes while not wearing a seat-belt. People who know the underlying large dataset, will not reason with the new data on a well studied subject the same they would reason with data on a new subject. So most people would answer "seatbelts save lives" no matter what imagined data you provide, with only the high numeracy people routinely calulating the data sometimes. All the while the skin-cream is truly neutral, as a new skin-cream is totally new data on a new subject.  Also even the posted graphs show, that numeracy actually informs accuracy. It's just that most people in the middle don't have the numeracy to check all data on validity and therefore fall back on previously researched large scale data.  The premise of the underlying thesis is bad, as it tries to pass "extensive knowledge" off as "political tribalism".

I've learned not to trust studies on certain topics in general. Also, the wording is confusing. The term "crime improves" vs. "crime worsens" can have a double meaning. Most people would interpret that as there is less crime and more crime, but taken literally, "crime improves" would mean better crime, and "crime worsens" would mean worse crime. So in one city people are better at doing crime while in another they are not nearly as good at crime. Also, it could be seen as people in one city committing less serious offenses, and in another, they are committing more serious offenses. The presentation of the facts itself is ambiguous.

There is one cognitive bias exhibited by the guy doing the walkabouts (a meta-bias, if you will): it's the idea that if there are two opposing viewpoints on a subject, then there is a better position to be taken halfway in-between. "If only we could just talk to each other, everything would be so much better". But if it's a debate between palaeontologists and creationists, for example, there isn't a synthesis of the two positions that holds any water. One is simply right and the other one wrong. And even if you get consensus on the _facts_ of a particular issue, then the question of what steps should be taken to mitigate it will once again be divided by belief systems.

I've been working for the federal government of the United States for 25 years. The statistical reporting is bogus - the FBI reports change what they count and how they count it based on what they want people to conclude. Gun-related statistics, for example - when gangsters shoot other gangsters, they count those deaths among the mass shooting and gun crime statistics, but most of those shootings go unsolved or unreported beyond the dead bodies, so they don't count the crime itself, or they fudge the numbers - if 15 people are gunned down while a democrat is in office, that's just one instance, though it still counts as a mass shooting, but if a republican is in office, that's 15 shootings and 15 instances crime. Instead of saying ‚Äúsmart people do it worse‚Äù, the real picture is ‚Äúpeople have difficulties separating their political ideology from facts and reasoning‚Äù.
The issue I see with this analysis is that when people are introduced to something that they themselves have no information about, like a new skin cream, they will generally follow this new data. There is no other data to compare to other than what has been presented since it is a "new" skin cream. There is no history they can pull upon, so they will start their opinion about the new topic from this data point. Here, numerical literacy will set the new opinion based on the new data more accurately to the new presented data. What else is there to make a judgement upon?  However, in other matters such as climate change or gun control, they may have quite amount of considerable alternative data that they may use to support or refute the "new" presented data. One single data point, such as a new study on gun control, is insufficient to demonstrate a refutation of a current position that has been set in the mind from past data or opinion (though may be easily added to someones support of a position due to the alignment of past data and opinion). People tend to need more data to refute something then needed to support a currently held position.  I do not believe this study demonstrates "smarter people do worse", I believe it shows "smarter" people have more historical data points to which they may refer to when evaluating new data on a subject. If the investigator made up a new issue within the realm of political opinion that had no previous history, I don't believe the outcome would be any different the skin cream (though finding such a topic would be near-impossible, since politics always appears within a scope and set of matters people have already concerns and opinions). But, say a study against/supporting banning a particular snake, which would save/not save countless lives, I doubt you would see any difference of results as with the skin cream. Banning something is a political act and it is very likely no one has data about this snake before the question was asked.   This study actually only shows that it takes more than one data point in contradiction before people change a previously established position that was built upon considerable more other data points. And, really, is there a surprise then? To find that it takes as much or more data to change someone's mind is not "delusional" at all. It is the very opposite. If one data point in contradiction changed our minds, our lives would be chaos.   I think the conclusion about people and their rationality is not supported by your argument. If the argument is that we all need more data and information and keep an open mind, then - obviously - that is true. Opinions and beliefs should be malleable. Principles should be concrete. That said, how many people actually know the difference?

Problem with representative democracy is that strangers, who do not know you, cannot represent you. The premise is simply false.  Voting is entering a contract, asking to be ruled by a handful of strangers. Extending them Power Of Attorney, four years into the future ... If you sign that, whatever happens, you have no right to complain, because you accepted the deal.  Here is what we should do instead : *Government by lottery*  1000 citizens randomly selected. 200 replacements selected every year, giving five years in government for each. Then perhaps a quarterly online voting session for the rest of us; Yes/No to the bill with slimmest decisive vote, in the 1000-man parlament during that quarter.  This setup would be next to immune to many of the problems plaguing our system today ... For example:  1) Four most controversial bills can only be passed/rejected via popular vote.  2) Candidates won't need a party-organisation, media-attention or donors to get elected. So, party leadership, media and money become powerless.  3) Predicting who is likely to get into government is impossible, so special interests have no way of preparing candidates, and no incentives to keep them close post term.  4) All 1000 have incentive to make society better, as they soon return to where they came from.  However ... the most impactful difference would probably be the fraction of psychopaths in government, automatically going down to population average (~2%).

I don't think it's reasonable to say that the gun control question is exactly the same as the rash question:   When a fictional study is talking about a rash, "better" or "worse" can just be summed up with "did the rash cover more area or less?".  But when a fictional study is talking about crime "getting worse" or "getting better", the concepts get very murky.  If there's one fewer murder, but ten more instances of petty shoplifting, does that mean it "got worse" because the total count of crimes increased?    We can tell people to just look at the numbers, but we can't realistically expect people to completely shut off their ability to reason in order to answer a hypothetical.

I wanted to suggest a follow-up question. Science depends on highly numerate people objectively dealing with the data. And in most situations we do. I think that there is increasing evidence that when our beliefs, or the pressure of our situation is sufficiently connected to our research, our objectivity falls sharply. There are of course those who commit academic fraud for research grants, or fear to publish research for fear of ridicule, or live under authoritarian regimes. But these are obvious and usually conscious decisions to be unobjective. I am much more concerned about the reflexive, subconscious ways we deal with data without even being aware of our biases.

I am going to ask you a question, and I am going to predict the answer you will have pop in your mind at first, and predict that will be a wrong answer. This works on most people and you can try if for yourself on others to see too, its an interesting conversation starter.  A bat and a ball together cost 1.10, the bat costs 1.00 more then the ball, how much did the ball cost?    You might have an answer of ten cents flash in your head right away with bias inaccurate fast mind but if you check that answer with your slow but more accurate conscious awareness, you can see that answer is wrong but it takes effort to do.   The answer of ten cents is not the right answer but most people have that pop in their head because of the fast thinking mind that we rely on most of the time.    The fast unconscious mind is taking everything in and trying to make sense of it really fast.  Its 11 million bits a second.  But sometimes it makes mistakes.  The slow conscious mind is 40-50 bits and lazy but it can check things and bringing the unconscious mistake to conscious awareness it can correct it.     The next thing to understand is about carl jung and the 4 ways the unconscious complex he called shadow deals with reality.  The shadow is an unconscious complex that is defined as the repressed and suppressed aspects of the conscious self. there are constructive and destructive types of shadow. Carl jung emphasized the importance of being aware of shadow material and incorporating it into conscious awareness lest one project these attributes onto others. The human being deals with the reality of shadow in 4 ways.  Denial, projection, integration and/or transmutation.     Now I believe what is happening when a question that exposes a conflict in a belief, idea, something that someone said, or even about someone they idolize and the question gets avoided, that is the fast unconscious mind going into denial and the response is often a projection.  This also can trigger and emotional response activating the amygdala more and the pre frontal cortex less where rational conscious thought is said to happen and the amygdala starts to get the body to flood itself with chemicals/hormones.    Its like the fast mind knows conscious awareness will say its wrong. so it blocks it off to defend itself from admitting its wrong.  in cases of denial and because it blocked off the rational mind, the responses are often irrational.  Like personal attacks do not address the issue or answer the question.  I think we can agree people have a very hard time now days admitting when they are wrong, I am not exempt from this myself I do realize. And we can see how badly questions avoidance effects us if you watch political meetings and watch them avoid questions all day long.    Ok, so the first thing to go over is denial as that is the main one I expose with questions.  A disowning or refusal to acknowledge something I think is a good definition for it here.  There is a really good 2 minute video I use as an example of this.  A streamer named vegan gains claiming lobsters have brains after some one said he can eat lobsters because they do not have brains.  He googles it and starts to read what it says.  When he gets to the part where is says neither insects nor lobsters have brains, he skips it and says they literally are insects then skips over that line and continues to read the rest.  Just like in the fast thinking video, his fast mind already read that line and refused to acknowledge it in unconscious denial, and just skipped it.     The person then tells him he skipped it and he reads it again and sees the line this time.  Still being defensive of his claim and refusing to accept he was wrong, he tried to discredit the source and its the lobster institute of maine. And while JP find those words difficult, other people understand them easy.  Even he does pretty much any other time they are used.    So projection is next up. Psychological projection is a defense mechanism people subconsciously employ in order to cope with difficult feelings or emotions. Psychological projection involves projecting undesirable feelings or emotions onto someone else, rather than admitting to or dealing with the unwanted feelings. Many times a mind in denial will use projections for responses.  Someone getting mad and telling the other person to not interrupt when they have been doing that a lot themselves would be an example. I have done this myself. The people who tell me I dont understand my own questions and my point is wrong when they do not even know what the point is are all examples as well.  I ask them to steel man my position to show then understand my point and they just avoid that question as well clearly showing they do not understand my point.    Now we have integration and/or transmutation.   Integration is when you bring an unconscious behavior into conscious awareness and accept it.  I know that I interrupt people talking sometimes even though I think that is wrong to do.  I have a conscious awareness of it, but I have not been able to completely change the behavior.... yet.  That is where transmutation comes in. Transmutation is to completely change that unconscious behavior. As an aside, I personally just scrutinize the hell out of the methodology in the studies regardless of what it says, as that's usually where studies fail if they do. Though I also check the data as well to make sure the given conclusion is in line with everything. In essence, I outright ignore the conclusion when going into it, and get invested in the process, so that regardless of whether or not I agree with the methodology and/or the conclusion, I can still follow it and criticize specific problems if I have any.  Though this does require a level of scientific and statistical literacy that you have to learn first, which can be difficult, but I think it's worth it.
